content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I was gifted Bastion by a friend a few years ago. WHY DIDN'T I PLAY IT UNTIL NOW??? IT'S SO MUCH FUN!!!Wow. I haven't enjoyed a game this much in a long time. The story is great, the visuals are beautiful and colorful. The whole atmosphere is really lovely. The music is so good and it is fluid in that you can flow from one mood to another easily when the narration changes, you enter a specific area on the map, etc.But what really keeps me coming back is the combat. I don't usually love hack'n'slash, but these weapons & abilities are SO much fun to use. I love all of them, too bad you can only use two at a time. The option of using spirits and idols to make the combat easier/harder depending on different variables you can choose to control is just brilliant. And the eventual upgrades you get, are awesome. The (increasingly difficult) maps & monsters are all introduced at a good, flowing pace, and in the end are all super fun to fight. I'm probably going to keep playing and toy with the difficulty and different weapon combinations for a while, even after I've beat New Game Plus.I was very motivated by the narrator and other rewarding, and interesting parts of the game to keep on playing and complete the story. Too often I don't finish games, but the Bastion called my name every hour of the day since I began playing. Even after you've completed the story there's still more stuff that you can do. Or, rather you can do other fun things while taking your time with the story. It's cool. The currency, and the rate at which it is acquired, is really in sync with natural progression. Everything about this game is just, "in sync". It flows. It makes sense. Nothing worried me about it. It is most excellently designed.Whoever came up with the idea to introduce New Game Plus after you've beat it the first time, knew how important that feature would be for people like me who couldn't get enough and wanted to keep playing.So, you should get this game. It's really perfect, especially if you like rpg's, this is a special one. There's really no way you wouldn't enjoy it, unless you have real poor coordination and fall off the map all the time (but this is just another fun thing about it). Also. Most of the world is destructible so that's fun (it's so pretty though, why would you want to do that? Maybe to make more room for fighting monsters, or getting past obstacles...) So much fun. Get it!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2012
												Bastion will forever live as one of the best games I have ever played. With a beautiful art and animation direction surrounded by a glorious and trully brilliant score, sound, and narration, Bastion grips the senses from the very moment you wake in a ruined floating city. As the entire experience is brought together with a powerful and driven story with unforgettable characters, it undoubtedly stands as a groundbreaking isometric role-playing game and an impressive debut game from Supergiant Games.	Not only does the main story impress, but every weapon training level provides an entirely different style of combat not only with the respective represented weapon but the very grounds upon where you must prove your tactical prowess is carefully crafted and detailed to offer an eye-catching and grip-tightening hold on the challenger. Similarly, the four trips to Who-Knows-Where pit you against wave after wave of enemies to test one beyond their normal gaming limits and bring one to a peak of their reaction-timing and accuracy mastery. Bastion includes 24 Steam Achievements that will each take the player to the edge of their gaming ability and focus. It will most certainly build a better gamer out of you. Bastion is absolute gaming perfection. 	With every brutally powerful enemy and cryptically beautiful scene, The Kid must traverse a broken sky for the materials needed to bring life back to his dying city of Caelondia and undo the damage wrought by The Calamity. As The Kid travels, he'll discover more than he bargained for surviving in vicious wildernesses, salvaged from fractured villages, and sacrificed to melted mountains. He'll face beasts of the wild, the warriors of The Ura, and even be tested by gods above to save the very fabric of reality, all the while unravelling the secrets of not only the city's fate, but his own past as well as his future.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Have you ever asked or been asked if video games are art? Look no further than this game to seek your answer. This game's beautiful art-style and stunningly moving (and reactive) narration is so powerful it will bring tears to your eyes, and is by far the best written game I have ever played (and I prefer games that focus on storytelling).Don't let the cute art-style or isometric perspective fool you - this is a tragedy set in a post-apocalyptic world (that's right, a post-apocalyptic world featuring every colour of the rainbow) that will have you battling both your conscience and fate through a linier narrative. The battle system may be simple, but there is enough variety of both melee and ranged weapons, stat-boosting tonics and difficulty-enhancing totems that you will find exactly the kind of game you are looking for, regardless of your tastes. Unusually for a linier story replayability abounds as this game features a 'New Game Plus' mode, 'Score Attack' mode, in-game challenges and multiple endings to the 9-hour story for you to sink your teeth into.If ever you have bought a game out of curiosty or on the word of another, let it be this one - you will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Crisp, detailed artwork. From the clouds rolling over the map, to the in-game items, everything is thoughtfully crafted and coherent. A single aesthetic for the entire game scales from little elements to full-fledged splash pages.The music does well to pair with the artwork. There's no let down. As much mood is created visually, there is equally fine musical pieces that create the sensations of adventure and tension in all the right places.  There's a major "cool" factor with the audio in general. The gruff but smoothly delivered voice-over fits the writing styles comfortable brevity. I never felt tired of sitting through narration. It was quick, to the point, but stylized to keep the entertainment flowing. The tunes mix atmosphere and raw, bluesy-western sounding guitar. Like our hero was born "cool" right out of the womb.  How easy it would've been to fudge these artistic choices and end up with something cheesy. Bastion is coherent on all fronts visual and auditory.  As for the mechanics and gameplay? I think they play second fiddle. Passable by all means - nothing seemed to be lacking, unresponsive, imbalanced, etc. But this game, in my opinion, is primarily a sight and sound to behold by the senses. Eat it up!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2012
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Bastion. A Narrated Story About The World Falling Apart.Genre: Fantasy isometric hack and slash aRPGDeveloped and Published by: Supergiant Games & Warner Bros. Interactive EntertainmentPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux, iOS, PS3 and Xbox360. Business Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsThis hack and slash aRPG has the player controlling Kid, a youth surviving the events of the Calamity. Said event destroyed much of the world that he knew and now he must traverse it, seeking to restore the Bastion. The Kid is a silent protagonist but the narrator following him around definitely isn’t. The narration is the main selling point of Bastion and where it got a lot of its praise from. The narrator’s deep tones are used to describe both the story, the interactions between characters and the player’s actions with an almost AI level of cognition. Falling off a ledge, getting hit by enemies, not figuring out where to go next gets either encouragement, prodding or almost sarcastic remarks from the narrator depending on the situation. But the narrator remains ever steadfast, determined to help the Kid out. It won’t comment on every single action taken but it’s enough to be interesting during this four hour or so campaign.  There's the Bastion level where you’re able to trigger parts of the story plot, customize the Kid’s weaponry and choose which level to go next. On each combat level is a piece of the Bastion (shards) that you must locate (usually hidden behind bosses) in order to reassemble and power it up. On combat levels, pieces of the level come falling down from the sky so you won't always know where to go next. I’m pretty mixed on this idea. I get that they didn’t want the entire level to be seen immediately nor wanted to use darkness to hide it, but it often leads to you running into walls a lot of the time. Combat ThoughtsCombat is a repetitive hack-and-slash with guns, hammers, blades and many other assorted weapons. Kid can only have two weapons equipped along with a special ability. The special ability can be summonable monsters to special weapon attacks and require dark potions to use. The Kid can’t recover his health over time, so the player will need to keep an eye out for health potions and use them when low on health. There’s an upgrade tree for weapons that changes the ability and strength to the player’s preference. It’s a good idea to figure out what weapons you’ll like early on. Each weapon upgrade requires a unique material as well as a number of spirits/currency in order to be applied. The currency can take a while unless you wish to grind the proving ground or monster waves (remembrance) level. There's also collectible items (Mementos), Vigils that change monster behavior and stats for increasing your risk/reward. All of which help take the edge off the repetitiveness of Bastion but only a little bit. For the most part, I found I ended up setting these to what I preferred and forgetting them. Unless you visit the challenge levels and complete them for the rewards, there's not a lot to choose from in the normal course of the game. Combat is pretty solid though the main problem is definitely the lacking variety of enemies. You’ll see the majority of them pretty early on and they get reused a lot. The way to defeat them is also pretty samey. Line up a shot, hopefully triggering a power-shot which gives it an extra boost, dodge out of the way if the enemy gets too close and shoot again. Rinse and repeat. A lot of the time it can feel like long battles of attrition between the health potions and seemingly endless stream of monsters. PC Settings, Visuals and SoundtrackBastion has a reasonable selection of options to customize the experience. It does give you a selection of resolution options depending on your aspect ratio. Though anything outside of a 16:9 resolution will be letterboxed. Fullscreen is on/off though you can force borderless windowed mode through a launch option. Read about how to do that on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. Visual settings are extremely limited to vertical sync on/off and anti-aliasing up to 4x. I’ll grant that it’s a 2D game so lots of graphical options are probably unnecessary. However, Bastion makes up for it with a plentiful audio menu. (Where the brightness slider is located, strangely). Music, FX and narration volume can all be adjusted here with sliders for each individual one. Keyboard, mouse and controller are all supported for Bastion though controller seems to be the preferred method. Bastion still holds up as a good looking indie title with its cartoony, colorful visual style. A style that has been very well implemented and holds up all game. The soundtrack is very well done and remains one of my favorite albums from gaming. I recommend picking up the soundtrack[supergiantgames.bandcamp.com] after you've finished playing the game.Final ThoughtsBastion is a solid experience from beginning to end. The narration is very well done, constantly keeping the player engaged and not getting overbearing or annoying. The story and combat are both solid and reasonably enjoyable for the short experience. Though I do feel like the customization/crafting system requires a bit too much grinding and the combat system can feel far too repetitive at times due to the small pool of enemies. Still, I think it's worth giving Bastion a look over, even after all this time. Read this review and more at A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												Honestly one of the best games I've ever played.The artwork is gorgeous, the soundtrack stunning (and one of my favourites of all time) and the storyline is, whilst not necessarily ground-breakingly original, re-inforced through characters who stray from the flat, one dimensional NPCs we're used to.Everything in this game is beautifully balanced: the Kid's silence is offset by the Narrator's frequent and colourful dialogue, the visuals do not detract from a core mechanic that works well and the characters themselves balance one another.One of the best features is that the game does offer a dynamic core mechanic: the difficulty can be stepped up through activating Idols, and the variety of weapons and skills allow for a challenging experience...should you desire it!Overall: a masterfully made game! And, lest we forget: Logan Cunningham...the gaming world's answer to Morgan Freeman!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2013
												Bastion is a memorable experience that transcends its parts.Gameplay is typical ARPG, with lots of weapons upgrading. This game gives you about a dozen melee and ranged weapons to choose from. Too many to upgrade them all fully, but it does mean that you can select weapons that match your preferred style of gameplay, and upgrade them with effects that you prefer (knockback, damage over time, crits, etc.). This is all very intuitive. But the gameplay itself is dull and repetitive.What makes Bastion work, though, is what's happening when you're not blasting, pounding, or burning alien critters. The just-in-time narration is excellent, and teeters between over-the-top seriousness and great dry humor. This narration that comes as you need it, mid-gameplay, works wonderfully and much better than cutscenes. There is a lesson here for other games.There is a compelling story here that takes effort and attention to comprehend. You have to continue past the main game into other modes to get the full story, or just look it up on Google when you're done. I frankly found the story to be a bit too abstruse to keep track of. I never developed too much interest in the characters who may not be what they say they are, or may be betraying you or not, or ... whatever. Blah blah blah. But the way the story is plugged directly into the gameplay via clever narration, gives you some very memorable experiences. No spoilers here, you'll have to trust me.I can't not mention the soundtrack. It's an excellent mash-up of old-West and Far-east, with electric drum beats and a stellar blues number thrown in for good measure. It reminds me of the old-West sci-fi soundtrack that accompanied the TV show "Firefly". There is no denying the spiritual influence. Listening to the song "In case of Trouble", I see scenes from Firefly in my head. This complete soundtrack stands alone wonderfully; my only wish would be for more vocal numbers, because "Build That Wall" is so moving when it's presented in the game.In summary, Bastion works because the whole is far greater and more memorable than its parts. Each element of this game augments the others - the average gameplay is elevated by the narration and the always-appropriate soundtrack, and the story that I struggled to care about still gave me chills and a jaw-dropping experience near the end, fueled by a sudden change in the gameplay and the always-appropriate soundtrack. Bastion is, most of all, a COMPLETE game experience, with a start, a middle, and an ending, where each element was clearly planned and thoughtfully executed, with polish and shine. Compare this to most games that simply end with a boss fight and a tacked on cut scene that explains what happened and teases a sequel, and you'll appreciate what a rare bird Bastion is in today's game market. Whether or not this particular title works for you, I hope you will agree with me that we need more games like Bastion.

Posted: February 12, 2014
-Quick review-Bastion is a good game, has excellent music, plays like a dungeon crawler, and has a great story that you can complete in maybe 5-6 hours.


YouTube™ Video: Atratzu Reviews: Bastion - No one told you it was indie game month, did they? 

			Views: 112		

			Bastion is an indie RPG with excellent music, amazing narrators voice, unique style, and a whole lot more emotion then you'd ever expect.		

-Detailed breakdown review-Story: you play as one character known simply as “the kid”, the kid is trying to collect shards to bring back the Bastion. The Bastion was a place everyone agreed to meet if there was an emergency. Through great story telling, a great narrator and many twists and turns in this puzzle-piece-world you find yourself sitting back and enjoying a story being told with some good natured humor as well.Music: The game has extraordinarily good music, a video game itself needs to have good music, or else it takes away from the experience, but bastion has very suitable music and a soundtrack that I personally wouldn’t mind downloading.Play-Style: You can swing a hammer, shoot a bow, poke with a stick, go click-happy with double revolver pistols and many other choices of weapons and combinations. Pick your favorite weapons; upgrade them at the forge to make yourself into one lethal mean killing machine.Achievements: I tend to play video games like I’m in a race to complete them, so I have played through the game’s story about 4 times now gathering achievements. In addition to playing through that many times, it took me only 21 hours. (Such as 02/12/14)The achievements themselves aren’t overwhelmingly challenging, which is good sometimes you just want a relaxing game, if you’re going for a 100% completed game, this one is very doable, look up the guides for the harder achievements, and prepare yourself for a some-what challenging experiencePrice: I consider price by how much time I’ve put into a game, how enjoyable it was, and if it’s replayable. Full price for Bastion is 14.99 at this time. I would suggest waiting for a 50% or 75% sale before purchasing. But I would highly recommend this game to anyone who’s looking for something new to play.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update May 27, 2016:added link to my new/updated Bastion YouTube Review.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2012
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Bastion. A Narrated Story About The World Falling Apart.Genre: Fantasy isometric hack and slash aRPGDeveloped and Published by: Supergiant Games & Warner Bros. Interactive EntertainmentPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux, iOS, PS3 and Xbox360. Business Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsThis hack and slash aRPG has the player controlling Kid, a youth surviving the events of the Calamity. Said event destroyed much of the world that he knew and now he must traverse it, seeking to restore the Bastion. The Kid is a silent protagonist but the narrator following him around definitely isn’t. The narration is the main selling point of Bastion and where it got a lot of its praise from. The narrator’s deep tones are used to describe both the story, the interactions between characters and the player’s actions with an almost AI level of cognition. Falling off a ledge, getting hit by enemies, not figuring out where to go next gets either encouragement, prodding or almost sarcastic remarks from the narrator depending on the situation. But the narrator remains ever steadfast, determined to help the Kid out. It won’t comment on every single action taken but it’s enough to be interesting during this four hour or so campaign.  There's the Bastion level where you’re able to trigger parts of the story plot, customize the Kid’s weaponry and choose which level to go next. On each combat level is a piece of the Bastion (shards) that you must locate (usually hidden behind bosses) in order to reassemble and power it up. On combat levels, pieces of the level come falling down from the sky so you won't always know where to go next. I’m pretty mixed on this idea. I get that they didn’t want the entire level to be seen immediately nor wanted to use darkness to hide it, but it often leads to you running into walls a lot of the time. Combat ThoughtsCombat is a repetitive hack-and-slash with guns, hammers, blades and many other assorted weapons. Kid can only have two weapons equipped along with a special ability. The special ability can be summonable monsters to special weapon attacks and require dark potions to use. The Kid can’t recover his health over time, so the player will need to keep an eye out for health potions and use them when low on health. There’s an upgrade tree for weapons that changes the ability and strength to the player’s preference. It’s a good idea to figure out what weapons you’ll like early on. Each weapon upgrade requires a unique material as well as a number of spirits/currency in order to be applied. The currency can take a while unless you wish to grind the proving ground or monster waves (remembrance) level. There's also collectible items (Mementos), Vigils that change monster behavior and stats for increasing your risk/reward. All of which help take the edge off the repetitiveness of Bastion but only a little bit. For the most part, I found I ended up setting these to what I preferred and forgetting them. Unless you visit the challenge levels and complete them for the rewards, there's not a lot to choose from in the normal course of the game. Combat is pretty solid though the main problem is definitely the lacking variety of enemies. You’ll see the majority of them pretty early on and they get reused a lot. The way to defeat them is also pretty samey. Line up a shot, hopefully triggering a power-shot which gives it an extra boost, dodge out of the way if the enemy gets too close and shoot again. Rinse and repeat. A lot of the time it can feel like long battles of attrition between the health potions and seemingly endless stream of monsters. PC Settings, Visuals and SoundtrackBastion has a reasonable selection of options to customize the experience. It does give you a selection of resolution options depending on your aspect ratio. Though anything outside of a 16:9 resolution will be letterboxed. Fullscreen is on/off though you can force borderless windowed mode through a launch option. Read about how to do that on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. Visual settings are extremely limited to vertical sync on/off and anti-aliasing up to 4x. I’ll grant that it’s a 2D game so lots of graphical options are probably unnecessary. However, Bastion makes up for it with a plentiful audio menu. (Where the brightness slider is located, strangely). Music, FX and narration volume can all be adjusted here with sliders for each individual one. Keyboard, mouse and controller are all supported for Bastion though controller seems to be the preferred method. Bastion still holds up as a good looking indie title with its cartoony, colorful visual style. A style that has been very well implemented and holds up all game. The soundtrack is very well done and remains one of my favorite albums from gaming. I recommend picking up the soundtrack[supergiantgames.bandcamp.com] after you've finished playing the game.Final ThoughtsBastion is a solid experience from beginning to end. The narration is very well done, constantly keeping the player engaged and not getting overbearing or annoying. The story and combat are both solid and reasonably enjoyable for the short experience. Though I do feel like the customization/crafting system requires a bit too much grinding and the combat system can feel far too repetitive at times due to the small pool of enemies. Still, I think it's worth giving Bastion a look over, even after all this time. Read this review and more at A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Cool story-telling game with a neat combat system.As for the narration, unfortunately for me who wants to focus as I play the game especially during combats, I started to feel annoyed by the narrator. It's a good concept, but not everyone will enjoy endless babbling on whatever you do. Had a hard time whether or not I should mute the narration, but at the same time I also needed the narrator to learn the story. Sure, I can just use subtitles to learn the story... but I still can't just read as I fight the enemies, plus the high needs to watch where I stand else I fall to death. Quite a dilemma right there for me.Struggled with the control a little at the beginning of the game. The character's movement was a bit clunky. Nevertheless, it's a very well-made game. Choices of upgradable weapons as you find them along the way enables you to try different approach to fight the enemies. The game also has the feature to buff the enemies to increase difficulty. Combats feel fresh with those changes. Challenges/trials are given for you to master your favorite weapons. There's no need to grind through the game to level up, or even completing the story. Difficulty level is just right.Not to forget the great soundtrack!If you are interested in Supergiant Games' creations, I recommend to play starting from Bastion. I played Transistor first so I couldn't help comparing the two and struggled a little in Bastion... but definitely can see how much Supergiant Games has improved! Now I'm so looking forward to the upcoming Pyre!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is art. I don't say that lightly. While i wouldn't call it perfect, It achieves what so many games try and completely fail to do. it should be mentioned in the same breath as half-life, bioshock,metroid prime and shadow of collosus. its get narrative structure right. It tells a story that adds to the gameplay instead of pausing it. Aided by the soulful narrative work of Logan Cunnigham and gripping music of Darren Korb and Lisa Barret, the team at Supergiant games crafted an expereince that will keep you spellbound.That is not to say the gameplay doesn't deserve props. Even without the top tier story, the narration, the music, and art the gameplay deserves top honors as well. With a huge arsenel of weapons that completely change gameplay, and constantly evolving obstacles + enemies, it will take a decent while for you to get bored. As an isometric smash em up action, everything is so crisp, with barely any fat. the controls are simple, yet give way for complex gameplay. special shout out to the unique way bastion handles difficulty levels. very unique and refreshing. with up to 10 extra buffs you can apply to enemies in exchange for more experience and money. I've never seen that before in a game and thought it was ingenious. much better than unlocked "insane" modes. Replay value is there, but not as high as some would like ( I expect) and i wish the story was longer as it feels (slightly) rushed at the end(i want a second one!!!!!!). But these are the most minor of gripes. This game is a steal at anything less than 15 dollars, and is worth more.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												I've heard so much about this game over the past four years. I was pretty skeptical of all the hype and glowing praise this game has received, but never one to judge unfairly, I picked this up on sale for about $5.Bastion is good. It is very good. I don't think it's the greatest indie game to have been made, but I can certainly see why people like it so much.At its heart, Bastion is an isometric hack'n'slash with small elements of dungeon grinding. You have a melee weapon, a ranged weapon, and a special attack. That's it. You can guard and evade roll, but you essentially only have three attacks the whole game. To make this simple formual work you are granted nearly ten different weapons to choose from, all upgradable, and all of which have their own unique special attacks. Further expanding on the simple gameplay is the ability to equip various drinks to give yourself buffs (i.e. extra damage, extra health, etc.)The game is balanced pretty well. I'm a vet myself, so I didn't have too much of an issue playing through this. There were a few hairy moments here and there, but ultimately Bastion isn't too hard. Unless you want it to be. In which case you can invoke the power of the gods, thus augmenting the enemy builds. While you can make them faster, more agressive, and sturdier, you also get an EXP and money boost for your trouble. Very well balanced.So the controls are tight, the gameplay is good, so how about the story? I won't give anything away, but it worked. Nothing too crazy, but it held my attention and inspired me to push on. The story itself might be simple, but the biggest draw of the game is the narrator. This was one of the biggest things I heard about this game: the narrator. All I'll say is: play it and find out on your own. It's pretty cool.While only clocking in at about 6 hours, Bastion manages to give an engrossing and surprisingly deep gameplay experience. Between listening to the narrator and watching the hand drawn world literally fall into place with your every step, Bastion manages to combine tight action gameplay with a unique art driven narrative. Go buy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Intro: Bastion might not be something to get a ton of hours out of or regularly play, but its one of the most original RPGs. The game's simple, but felt very unique and just a joy to play. Its also a nice change from having to put in 30+ hours for RPGs. While shorter games are often considered inferior, sometimes you want to play an RPG you can finish in reasonable time.Gameplay: The gameplay of Bastion is a top-down isometric Action RPG with linear level-based progression. It feels comfortable and familiar. There's a handful of weapons and skills to use and the levels are really enjoyable to play through. You can also shift the difficulty to make it much harder, but more rewarding. There might not be that much replayability, but there is a new game+ and score attack mode for anyone who loves the game enough to go for highscore runs or just play it again with their same gear.Story: Bastion's strongest point is the story. Jesus Christ, this game has a magnificent story. Its depressing, but beautiful. Its one of those games that really can leave an impact on you. Certainly a game I won't ever forget.Unfortunately, I don't want to say much more on it because I refuse to spoil it for anyone who hasn't played it. Just trust me on this :)Also, the story is narrated. It really sets the mood of the game. I couldn't imagine playing the game without the narration.Visuals: The artstyle is as good as they come. This is one of those games where you want to put posters of it up on your walls. Its quite colorful and looks hand-painted. Truly beautiful and unique.Music: The music is also excellent. Very interesting style. It blends a lot of different types of music together and creates this heavy electronica-inspired western style music. It might not sound good from my words, but it really is a wonderful a soundtrack. This is one of the few games that I download the OST to and listen to in my normal day.PC Version: There's a few different ways to play the game when it comes to controls. It all runs very well. No issues. There's not much to say here about it. Plays wonderfully on keyboard+mouse but just as well with a gamepad.Conclusion: Bastion is just a total masterpiece. If you haven't played it you need to. Its one of those must-play indie titles that people will still be talking about years from now. My review doesn't do it justice. Go play it now!

												There are many games out there that can tell you a good story.  Some of them tell one so great you'll gush about it to anyone who'll listen.  Bastion does something a little different.  It's not the story itself, but the way it's told.  Lush environments assembling themselves under your feet at every step, robust landscapes waiting to be explored, and a gorgeous narrative alongside the natural squeak and strum of strings blend together to create a masterpiece.In short, Bastion will not disappoint.  You'll even want to spring for the soundtrack.  10/10.I expect 'Build That Wall' (Zia's Theme) will sit at the top of my favourite track list for a very long time.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												It's wonderful that in the days of the AAA triumph and corporations tightening their grip around the gaming industry's neck we can still see examples of truly wonderful pieces of art, the memories of which linger long, long after the main storyline is finished and detailes became fuzzy. And Bastion is one of the better examples of games as art, where the story is conveyed in its own unique manner that couldnt've been done in the form of a book or a movie. The plot of the game is intelligent, serious, romantic, touching - it has it all for those of us striving for a bit of fairy-tale brilliance in our boring working lives. Mechanics blend into the mix perfectly, being simple enough not to get in the way of the story, and yet complex enough to give some room for imagination and all kinds of neat little tricks that hardcore gamers are prone to. And narrating... Do I even have to mention how good it is and how fresh the whole idea feels? Supergiant Games really made a huge leap forward with this one, a leap that teaches the lesson to all developers out there, trying to make their own perfect games.Maybe over the years people will forget Bastion and move on to newer titles... But I, for one, will return to this vivid and picturesque world from time to time. Because I lived a whole new life there - short, but nonetheless beatiful.

												Where do I start, this game drew me because of its beautiful art work and when I saw the trailer, it had a very unique gameplay experience which was delivered at the time, you would hear live narration which are a result of your actions in the game.Bastion has a nice fresh indie touch to it, the third person view from the top also gives you a nice immersive feel, which you don't get to see in a lot of games these days.It has a very beautiful sound track which keeps you hooked onto the game for long.Warning, this game can get very addictive, letting go of the controller seems impossible.For everyone who're looking out to buy the game, please do, you'll get your money's worth from it!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												A worthwhile adventure. The rundown...The beautiful hand-drawn animations, fun combat, cool story presentation, and great music all come together to make this a great game. Gameplay: Mostly centres around combat, which is very well done, and fun for the duration of the game. As you progress you unlock cool weapons that make a lot out of simple controls. Story: Not particularly amazing BUT the narrator who guides you through the game is so cool. Really incredible presentation, with lots of style - think Firefly (the TV series) mixed into a fantasy world.To consider...- It's got a New Game+ feature so that you can hunt achievements based on modifiers you find. This is good, because the campaign is only about ~5 hours.- Really meant for a mouse and keyboard! The aiming is a little wonky with controllers.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Bastion is, and will, probably always be one of my favorite games if not THE favorite game.Bastion at its core is not a really unique game, with simple but fast and fun gameplay.But Bastion relys on something else entirely,the atmosphere.The Graphics, the music, the narrator, everything fits together so perfectly.I listen to the music on my way to school pretty much evey single day. The Graphics  matches perfectly my interests - Blooming, colorfull fantasy and a somewhat Steampunky Atmosphere. Everything is wonderfully designed, every level has a unique feeling to it and nothing seems to be repetetive.And then there is the narratorBastion would probably lack something if the narrator wouldn't be there. Everytime i hear this old fella i feel like coming home, with such a wonderfull gravely and 'Old man from the west' Voice that you will easily get into the game in no time.Here is a real advice though:Go into the game with no real expectations, take your time, play it at a time where you don't have to worry about things, get yourself your favorite Drink and enjoy this wonderfull piece of an Adventure.I highly reccommend you to buy this game, especially when its on Sale.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Typically when a game's length comes into question, it's because of triple-digit hours on one save file. However, Bastion is one of those rare flames that petered out too quickly. Whether this complements the strong gameplay and story or serves as a complaint of an unfinished product is up to the reader. I am certain of this, though: some developer somewhere is scribbling down ways to turn Bastion's novel approach to RPGs into a multi-million dollar project. Few games can claim that they revolutionized the industry, and when they do, it's the one simple, novel idea that makes the mark. For Bastion, that's the velvety narrator who comments on nearly every aspect of gameplay. Fall off the landscape? He's got something to say about it. Thwart a boss without getting nicked? Expect a new piece of dialogue. Choose any two weapons? Prepare to methodically run through every combination of equipment. But he does more than simply comment. The narrator tells the story from the perspective of a weathered, rustic old man who's made mistakes and bears the burden of regret. At the same time, he speaks of The Kid as a champion–someone who can make things right. And that's where you come in: as The Kid, you have the opportunity to fix a sort of man-made apocalypse called the Calamity. Finding survivors along the way, The Kid has to restore power back to Bastion, the protagonists' headquarters. By finding crystals through linearly explored areas, The Kid grants Bastion energy, and buildings for some reason. Players have the illusion of choice when deciding which structure to erect, each of which grants some sort of ability or perk. The Arsenal, for example, allows the player to choose which weapons he'd like to equip, as well as a super power. Alternatively, the Shrine invokes the gods, which can make the game more difficult with a slight boost to experience and money; it's worth mentioning that the ways in which a player may increase difficulty are creative and keep the game new. However, all aspects of the game maintain a pine-fresh scent. Initially, Bastion's quick-paced, action-based gameplay is good, simple fun. Truly, without activating an idol or two, the game is a bit on the easy side. Though, should you falter, you're granted one reprieve. An additional pratfall results in running the entire level over again. Normally, a lack of checkpoints in extensive stages is a critical game design flaw, but with adjustable difficulty, this is more than fair. For those looking for a challenge and adrenaline rush, the penalty of running some of the longer levels over again can be enticing; however, those who enjoy whimsical hack-n-slashery need just avoid the idols. Although the game gets harder over time even in its vanilla state, leveling up and weapon upgrades maintain one's interest. When leveling up and choosing a potion to make The Kid stronger, players have several choices to make. Do I want more mobility when holding up my shield, or do I want to have a slight increase to critical chance? Another shop allows players to purchase gods for the Shrine, potions for leveling up perks, and even special powers for the Arsenal. Other buildings include achievements and weapon upgrading with customization. Although Bastion egregiously offers pseudo-choices the way so many other games of its ilk do, the customization, challenges, and achievements are well thought out. Valve and Kongregate will tell you with firsthand experience that easy, medium, and hard difficulty achievements are necessary if goal-setting is going to motivate players even a bit; Bastion has this covered. I completed certain auxiliary objectives without even knowing about them, while others took conscious effort and practice. Thankfully, customization makes challenges easier. In this way, some of the side missions can be thought of more as puzzles with an element of skill, but others will require finesse, alacrity, and accuracy to conquer. However, I didn't find any Excalibur equivalents, and even if I thought I did, my brother glanced over at my screen and asked me how the heck I was using that weapon combination and special power; the sentiments were reciprocated. And isn't this the goal of any designer who includes gameplay options? As alluded to in the beginning of the review, Bastion is more than just gameplay and a novel plot: it's an experience. For those who've read my King's Bounty reviews, you're probably well-aware of my love of color. Modern gaming can be so monochrome and drab that when a game as vibrant as Bastion comes along, the appeal is two-fold; not only is color in itself enticing, but we're so starved for it that our love for it is accentuated. Additionally, not only has Bastion been graced by daubs of the palette, it's extremely busy. While clutter can certainly reach a threshold, Bastion never oversteps its bounds. The developers made sure to keep the minds and eyes of its consumers occupied while not getting in their way. Another marvel of the layout is just how intuitive foreground breakables are. Many other games leave questions as to what can be examined and destroyed, and what is meant to be left alone in the background. Some may complain that foreground pillars and structures can get in the way, but this reviewer perceives that as a necessary evil given how beautiful the game is. But what would a game be without music to match the visuals? Although most of the music is forgettable, some of the tunes have lasting power. Keeping with the atmosphere of a western, the occasional acoustic guitar and harmonica make for some innovative RPG music. However, the aural highlights of Bastion lie in its vocal numbers. Simple instrumentation matched with truly melodious voices grants us serene, wistful songs. Couple this with intelligent lyrics, and Bastion leaves an imprint on anyone with a love of music or beating heart. Typically, voice acting hurts or helps in a humble way. To my knowledge, never has a game been recommended purely because of the voice acting, but Bastion might be the first. Sure, we play games to enjoy deep, fun gameplay and funny or immersive storytelling. However, what if the defining feature was its narrator, and how that story was told? Take away Bastion's voice, and that leaves a pretty good game with fun combat in a slightly unique take on a post-apocalyptic world. With the voice, Bastion isn't just a great game, it's a work of art. Never before had I anticipated a person's name in the credits of a game, just so I could seek them out online and see what they've done and what they will do. I would be absolutely astonished and floored if this is the last we hear of Logan Cunningham. Finally, the controls are what you would expect of a game of this caliber. Nigh-perfect in its intuitive rolling and hit detection, the only complaints I can make are in its auto-targeting mechanism. Due to Bastion's archaic take on defending, players may steer clear of the shield due to its unreliability. When defending, The Kid automatically faces the nearest target, which makes sense. When I close a good, long book, I always feel a little sad, as if I had just said good bye to an old friend. I want to know what happens to the characters that I grew to love, but I have to accept the end and move on. Bastion is a short game, which will run most people around five or six hours. Nevertheless, I feel that same kind of loss. Although I truly believe that Bastion could have doubled its length in terms of gameplay, I'm glad that the story didn't risk imploding on itself. Don't let anyone tell you this is a Diablo clone–that would cheapen Bastion; it needs to be heard to be believed.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Once again, close friends and strangers of the internet, I'm back to review a game. I rarely feel the need to instantly write a review for a game; I generally like to replay the game so that I can see it from multiple angles (with the exception of FarCry 3-Blood Dragon. I've suffered enough. However, this game is still making my hands tremble from excitement some 12 seconds after I finished it. Without any further build-up, I give you... The Review Developed by Supergiant Games, Bastion sets place is a post apocalyptic world (Man, this steam sale I really went all out in Post-apocalyptic games) I don't really want to give too much away about the story (That's a lie, I really do want to, but for you, loyal or disloyal reader, I won't), the whole experience really is a journey more that a game. The excellent storytelling by voice actor Logan Cunningham was exceptional. This guy has the sexiest voice since Morgan Freeman. Seriously, his voice is like velvet. I loved the story all the way through. I did feel like it was balancing on the edge of getting repetitive like some kind of tight rope walker of dullness, but it never crossed that line, creating a rich game with plenty of replay value (Blood Dragon, Take note)Okay, now to something I can never seem to appreciate outside of the video gaming world.  ART!!!  This game was beautiful. It removed all need for me to go outside or even leave my chair. The way the world generated itself around you did a great many things including1. Add to the uniqueness of the game2. Create a need for completionist to search every single edge with the hope it might create a secondary pathand, subsequently3. Make REPLAY VALUE (*Cough Cough Blood Dragon)The art design of the characters, enemies, scenery and weapons was truly something to be admired. Hats off to Jen Zee, the god in human form who made this exist.The music of this game was a delicacy. I know I say this a lot with my reviews but I'm seriously considering putting the soundtrack on my phone. It always perfectly supported the art style, the story at that point and Logan Cunningham's sexy voice (Call me!)The combat was smooth and also commendable. Players had the choice of 13 different weapons (Excluding the battering ram) and were required to choose a melee and a range as well as a special move. The special moves were never over powered but they certainly did aid combat and contrasted against what was never dull combat. The combat in itself was great. There was a countering system which, though difficult to perform, were occasionally the only way to do serious damage to an enemy (This often depended on the weapons you chose.) The weapons you chose definitely affected the game. Weapons varied in range, speed and some required reloading and cooldowns. I choose to use the hammer and the duel pistols, however I'm sure everyone who's played this game will have less then positive opinions on my loadout. It really does depend on the individual play styles. The weapons could be upgraded, which was both significant and necessary to the game.Along with the main story line, there were also trials that you could do on the side for each specific weapon. Receiving a high score would earn you either third, second, or first prize depending on how quickly you completed the trial, how well you completed the trial or how many shots it took you to complete the trial. The rewards ranged from an upgrade for a specific weapon, the games currency or even a special move if you took first place. I was discouraged to say the least when I couldn't unlock the special move for my duel pistols and could have easily spent another half an hour if my fingers weren't about to start bleeding. This was a great way to add extra content and add to the depth of the game (This is the last reference I'm making to Blood Dragon)One great addition to the game was basically a wave based combat system in which you fought off waves of enemies whilst receiving back-story for one specific character. This was a great way to add depth and extra content to your game. I hope whoever came up with this idea was given a raise. (The back-story for the characters was well written and well voiced by the very sexily voiced Logan Cunningham.Finally, Something I never really explored in the game was the ability to use the shrine. This basically granted bonus XP or currency, but made huge effects onto the game (enemies respawing after you killed them, more enemies, more health and powerful enemies ect. Some shrines even did the reverse, making the game easier.Alright, if I haven't convinced you yet, go visit a doctor. This game deserves your money. Go get it now.Seriously, I'll wait.What are you waiting for?If you haven't got it yet, I'm very disappointed in you. Let's recap.Everything about this game is perfect, except that I'm not playing it right now.Anyway, needless to say, this game receives a 10/10Thanks for reading, see you next time.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
This game deserved an overwhelmingly positive reviewEven if Bastion is short (just a few hours <11hrs' mine>, depending on how many challenges you're keen on passing with a gold medal rating) it's one of the few games in which the New Game+ (rewinding the whole adventure but keeping the endgame resources) was just as much fun as the first playthrough. The content might be identical, but you've probably missed out on a few platforms the first time around, so you'll have the opportunity of discovering them and testing out your untapped weapons as well.The storytelling is unique and relaxing. While you do work fighting off enemies, the narrator gives you the lowdown. The world you explore is fragmented and broken, but the visual element of the game is gorgeous. Most importantly, Bastion's music ties everything together. I can still hear the bluesy guitar line and the hurt voice of a character you meet early in the game.A game you should buy 10/10 !

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												This game is the bastion of a well-designed RPG, and game (heh). Now that we've got that one pun out of the way, I truly do think that Bastion is one of the best RPG games out there, especially because it focuses on untraditional aspects of a game, and focuses on making a game a piece of art.Obviously, Bastion does the RPG-part of an RPG well. The plot is pretty well-crafted (no big holes), and I truly do buy into the story of the game. The characters are well-made, and while they lack a bit of depth (the game is a bit short compared to, let's say, Skyrim), they're still pretty cool. The in-game mechanics also are pretty good, and fit into the RPG-ish genre: you run around on an isometric platform, using your weapons to defeat the many nefarious enemies you'll encounter. You upgrade (and sidegrade) your character, weapon choice, and even game difficulty as the game goes on. All things normal for an RPG, and all things done well.I think where the game excels is the concept of art, and art in the game. First of all, the game is very visually appealing. According to the creators, Supergiant Games, the entire game is hand-painted; I've got to give kudos to their painting. The landscape is breathtaking, enemies really do look and feel like enemies, and each part of the map has its own special graphical feel (e.g. forests, swamps, cities). From an audio standpoint, there's also this narrator that accompanies you around the game, and he's one of the best serious narrators I've encountered. In addition, the soundtrack is absoutely amazing. Whoever they hired to do their sound really puts you into the game: common RPG tropes like "boss-fight music" are done very well, and the atmosphere is set during troughs of playtime. I've even added some of the songs on Spotify, and that's something I rarely see from video games.The game is also replayable (there's a new game + mode), and has a mechanism called "shrines" that can make the game harder, for better rewards. Plus, as you level up and gain access to more weapons, different playstyles are available.Overall, Bastion is one of the best RPGs I've played in a long time, and I definitely think it's worth its selling price. It functions well as an RPG game, but also has the added bonus of being a well-developed piece of art. If you're someone who likes games that are both fun to play and fun to just watch and listen, Bastion's definitely the game for you.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Bastion is beautiful in every way.  It feels more like a work of art then anything else Iv'e played before.  The gameplay is pretty simple and straight forward, venture into different areas to find shards that will help repair "The Bastion."  While doing this you destroy varying types of enemies with weapons you find along the way, wether it be a giant hammer, a katana, a rifle, or the many other weapons that you find.  Every shard that you find allows you to upgrade the bastion in some way that unlocks other aspects of the game. Sounds pretty straightforward but what makes Bastion great is it's approach to this style of gameplay.  The beautiful hand painted environments spring up around you as you venture through the lands, while a narrator reacts to your every move.  Supplement this with a wonderful bluesy-folk soundtrack, and you have a game that is really appealing to your emotions.  I would recommend that anyone pick this game up given the chance.

												Bastion is a game that involves anyone that plays it. It's art, narration and music combined creates an unforgettable experience for the player.The game has a nice story, somewhat predictable, but it still manages to touch the mind to a certain degree.The learning curve is smooth, adding features as you progress, with little ramification.The action can be really fast paced and require skill for those who want the chanllenge, but there's also a mode for those who want to see the story and "skip" combatA game that deserves to be in the library of every true gamer out there.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Bastion is by far one of the greatest games that I've played. Although the game is linear, it's easy to forget that as you slowly uncover the details of what caused the Calamity. In addition, there is a large amount of customizability with what weapons you use, and they allow for many different playstyles. In addition, instead of picking an arbitrary difficulty at the beginning (For example, if you pick between easy and hard, what makes hard more difficult than easy?), the game allows you to create your own challenge - while also rewarding you with more EXP if you choose to do so. The storytelling in the game is also phenomenal, and makes replaying the game so much more fun - because you can't catch every detail in your first play through. I've beaten the game many times and still notice something new each time. Overall, this is a great game and shows that Supergiant Games will definitely continue to be a great video game company.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Bastion is beautiful in every way.  It feels more like a work of art then anything else Iv'e played before.  The gameplay is pretty simple and straight forward, venture into different areas to find shards that will help repair "The Bastion."  While doing this you destroy varying types of enemies with weapons you find along the way, wether it be a giant hammer, a katana, a rifle, or the many other weapons that you find.  Every shard that you find allows you to upgrade the bastion in some way that unlocks other aspects of the game. Sounds pretty straightforward but what makes Bastion great is it's approach to this style of gameplay.  The beautiful hand painted environments spring up around you as you venture through the lands, while a narrator reacts to your every move.  Supplement this with a wonderful bluesy-folk soundtrack, and you have a game that is really appealing to your emotions.  I would recommend that anyone pick this game up given the chance.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												The reason why I bought Bastion was because of the immense praise and positive reviews it recieved on release. That might have been a mistake on my part, since I expected it to be a lot more than what it turned out to be. I didn't get the indie gem I thought I was getting, but instead a mediocre hack n slash with some underwhelming RPG elements slapped on top. It does have one thing going for it admittedly, and that's the presentation. The isometric graphics are beautiful, they were clearly shown a lot of love, and the narration is enjoyable, even though it gets kind of irritating after a while.The gameplay on the other hand is dreadful. It may be responsive and functional, but it is incredibly dull and repetitive and offers little challenge or variation. The levels are essentially all the same, there are no puzzles or interesting gameplay elements to differentiate them, only a slight difference in color hue and tileset. There isn't much enemy variation and it just feels like you're powering through mob after mob to get a little bit of story to keep you going(and the story is only decent at best).My advice is to try the demo and see how you like it, since it will give a pretty good idea what you will do for the rest of the game. Don't believe the hype.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												"A really great example of what a game should be. Original, interesting, and fun!"  (Dec 27, 2011)I still really enjoy this game. There's no sugarcoating it. This is one of my favorite games of all time and it probably had an influence in my life choices. Looking at the game closer, everything about it appeals to me. I love the character design, the music is above fantastic, and the scripting is amazing. The game mechanics are pretty smooth too, but that wasn't the thing that made this game one of my favorites of all time. The characters became a part of my life while I was playing this game, and not to sound like a crazy person here, but I connected with them all on an emotional level. Every single protagonist made me wonder about my life choices. I'm including Zulf in the pool cause I believe that he is in fact a protagonist, but that's an argument for another day. The Kid is the character that really makes this game. You befriend him as the player. The Kid isn't some faceless hero that you can imprint your own desires on to. The Kid, is The Kid, and everyone in the game recognizes that. The Kid has a personality, yet he's quiet the entire game. Again, I could rant about the similarities and differences that The Kid has to Link from LoZ, but that's an argument for another day. The kid, different from Link, existed before you started to control him. He had a mother and a life of his own. The Kid had feelings and dreams that the player can experience through dream snippets that make a separation possible between character and player. Rucks' narration also helps separate The Kid from the player, but when it comes down to it, this game is beautifully written and I can't stress it enough that this game is worth your money and time.Have a good one,CoffeeGoat

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												An amazing game. Great story, good gameplay, terrific music and the best narrator ever.The storyline is quite cool, with a little element of choose your own adventure at the end. I just wish they expanded on the world of Bastion a little more, maybe with a sequel, it's a very fascinating world.The way the game progresses through the story is sort of simple compared to the extensive background of the Bastion. Most of the game is "Collect the core to build the Bastion. Oh no, Bastion broken, collect shards to rebuild. Not again, more shards please." The storyline is very linear and I feel that some other plot device could be used instead of cores and shards. The story was too formulaic because of this.The soundtrack, the art, and the narrator are fantastic. Every level felt awe inspiring, each environment looked incredible and well designed. I really loved that Rucks was used to narrate everything, it was a neat twist to story-centric games, and with Logan Cunningham's voice I didn't mind at all.The weapon system is very awesome and most of the weapons are mechanically very different, but there are some obviously underpowered and overpowered weapons (UP=Fang Repeater, OP=Galleon Mortar). Generally the weapons are mostly balanced sidegrades.The passive upgrades via Spirits is quite unique. There is also a faulty power balance among spirits too: eg. Leechade should always be equipped regardless of build. There aren't enough spirits to make different builds viable except for a tanky build and a high risk high reward build, which are both outclassed by the all around build. In all fairness the game isn't deep enough to warrant more builds than those.I really enjoyed the difficulty of the game. It's a very easy game until the idols are all turned on, now the squirt mobs instakill you when they die with the dropped explosives on death, the spinning gasfellas permaslow to a quick death, and the Ura move at godlike speeds; the fundamentals of the enemies change quite a bit. Regen god + Damage block god + Invulnerability god challenges on vs a really tanky and high damage enemy such as Pyth is really stupid though, it almost forces you to use the Galleon Mortar or other high burst damage.Don't take my review the wrong way though, the criticisms I've made with this game are very minor, the game as a whole is amazing and worth every penny.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												What do you say to someone who’s played it all?“Buy this game. Please.”	Bastion is one of the “big names” of the Indie scene. Although its reach has gone farther than most games made by small companies thanks to a partnership between Supergiant Games and Warner Brothers, Bastion still has the charm that only a small-time game can. From the graphics to the gameplay, the music to the narration, you know you’ve found something special from the moment the game begins.	The game follows the story of a boy known only as “the Kid” following a catastrophic event called the Calamity. With the world falling to pieces, it’s up to the Kid to collect cores to rebuild the bastion and restore life. An old man known as Rucks narrates the story as it plays out. Along the way, the Kid must fight off monsters, enemies, and even nature itself to retrieve the cores and save the bastion, with a few surprises along the way.	Artistically, Bastion is a gem. Jen Zee’s artwork gives the world an organic, colorful feeling that constantly evolves around the player’s actions. The soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is as beautiful as it is fitting for the game’s story. With a very down-to-earth feel and haunting lyrics on a number of tracks, the soundtrack makes for good listening both in and out of the game. Better yet, it’s also available for purchase on the Steam marketplace.	In respects to gameplay, Bastion is a generally easy game. I had little difficulty making my way through on my first play-through, and never encountered a game over. That being said, the “Shrine” portion of the game allows players to raise the difficulty in exchange for more fragments (currency used for upgrades and purchases) and XP. With that in mind, the game can be made as easy or as difficult as the player would like, with the best benefits reserved for those who play the hardest.	What Bastion is known for most of all is its narrator, Rucks, who narrates the game’s events as they play out. The old, weathered voice of the man gives a dimension to the game that few others can hold a flame to. His voice guides players through the plot at several key points, but is also free-flowing at other instances. Rucks might comment on the weapons the Kid uses, offer hints when needed, and even comment on little things such as falling off the stage. The story is framed as Zucks telling the story--to whom? That comes in time.	Bastion is a gem, and for good reasons. Its fascinating story is told through every medium--art, music, and plot--and culminates in one fantastic experience. If you have the opportunity to experience Bastion, do so.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
The GoodThe main reason to play this game is for the story, most particularly the interesting way that story is presented.  Everything is narrated, and the narration serves both to guide the player through various parts of the game, it's also informed and appropriately altered by the player's actions.The gameplay is very solid in most aspects, and works very well in its isometric framework.  The graphics are excellent, and it's endlessly fascinating to watch the stages gradually take form as you move around, and just as fascinating to run around destroying as much of it as you can.  The real star of the background is the music, however, which is just chock full of beautiful and catchy sounds.  Shelling out $9.99 for the soundtrack is a bargain as far as I'm concerned.The BadThe mechanics of the game have surprisingly little variation given how many different weapons, abilities, and the like that are available.  Many of the enemies can be taken out in a lot different ways, meaning there's very little reason to bother switching away from whatever weapon you've picked as your favorite since odds are it'll still do the trick.  I do like the combat, but I also think it could have benefited a great deal from just a little more depth.OverallA very fun game with a damn fine soundtrack and a good, thought-provoking story presented in a unique way.  I would definitely recommend giving it a try, and I personally look forward to seeing and playing SuperGiant Games' future endeavors.

												I became interested in 'Bastion' when I first saw its beautiful illustrations. The artwork was so stunning that I intended to play the game purely for its art direction. content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Let's begin with a disclaimer: Bastion if really freaking hard to describe.At its core, it's a top down action game with RPG elements, and at that, it does its job. The game plays like a charm, and most of the weapons are fun to use (even if I found myself liking the ranged options more). The whole game feels extremely tight and polished.Where Bastion really shines, however, is its story AND the way it is presented. Every action you take, even some really meaningless ones (being hit by an enemy in the first level, breaking crates) are commented by the ever present Narrator - if you ever played Portal and liked how GladOs reacted to your actions, you'll like this, too. The story is very good, too, and among a plethora of brown and bleak post-apocalyptic scenarios, I feel the colorful fragmented world of post-calamity Bastion is a refreshing spin on an over-abused genre.With how little it costs, seriously, you just owe this game to yourself. And your friends, possibly.

												Bastion is an amazing indie title about world after apocalypse. You control silent protagonist which is narrated by someone who has replaced his vocal cords with  chocolate candy and that voice guides the protagonist through levels. Throughout progression you find 2 human survivors and 4 pets that will accompany you in Bastion when you return from your quest. I liked the part where you picked up Zia, the  singer. Gameplay is quite fun, you run around and smash various creatures with your weapon of choice (mine was Brushers Pike and Mortar) and retrieve Cores and Crystal shards to make Bastion functional again. You get quite big weapon arsenal and passive abilities (which comes in the shape of alcohol) to chose from. If you wondering whenever you should buy it the answer is yes, definately fun, aestheticly pleasing and good quality product. 8/10

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Bastion is a fine action-adventure game set in a fantastic world after a near apocalyptic event. The scenery is superb, beautiful places that show some of this world's former glory. The gameplay is quite varied, as there is a wide variety of weapons, each with their respective upgrades and secret skills, that you can combine in every way you want. You can also customize the difficulty by invoking different gods that will make foes stronger in a variety of ways, while providing you with greater rewards.The soundtrack is another strong point for this game. Each song seems fitting to the situation you're currently in, and there's plenty of them.Finally, the story is very well crafted. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.All in all, a highly recommendable game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												"Abstract" "Indie" games is where all the (K)ool Kids are. Just about recently, gamers are regularly met with a surfeit of these indie games that have a history of HYPE. Too bad most of them turn out to be vaporware or pretentious garbage. But there is that minute gleam of light that promises quality. Supergiant Games, thankfully, ends up being one of the few that actually develop decent games. Bastion, the game in question, is not one that should be adjudged "decent", but rather, astounding. Far from flawless, as this game is locked at 30 frames (Just, why?), but an overall stellar game that is worth every penny, or whatever crap currency you wield.Meet the Kid. One of the handful of survivors that has endured the Calamity. This catastrophic event brought the whole world to ruin. He sets off to the Bastion, where he is greeted by Rucks, the Stranger, with words claiming that the recent disaster can be undone. By constructing the Bastion back to health with monument cores and shards there are odds of restoring Caelondia and its neighbor lands to a time before hell unleashed, hence the title of this game. Throughout the Kid's travels to seek out the materials needed, players will learn more about the world and its people and you get to learn the backstories of the few survivors you come across as the game progresses. It might seem engrossing, but the story is where Bastion falls shortest. The journey with the Kid was complete in every angle it is viewed in, but it was also rushed from start to end, and had inadequate time to develop. Build-up starts to occur profusely around the last third of the game, only to conclude in some half-baked ending that proved to be unfufilling. Despite the mediocre narrative, Bastion is a feast for the eyes and ears due to it's gorgeous presentation.It is not an overstatement when it is said that this game has the potential to be sold solely on it's presentation. Hell, some have avowed that they bought the soundtrack before the damn game. It's just that damn delicious. Bastion's visuals is where that abstract tag comes into play, because it is most certainly what most reckon to be unconventional. The playing stage constructs itself as you tread along the path and the camera is complimented by a shiny filter, and other things I won't bother typing as it's better experienced than read. The soundtrack, done by composer Darren Korb, is brimful with impressive songs that seemlessly attach to the rest of the presentation. I'm not one that gushes over video game OSTs, but this one is pretty damn good, and I'm convinced everyone that isn't a moron agrees.If only it wasn't locked at thirty frames...that idea bothers me way to f****** much.Even with such wondrous superficial values, a game is crap if it isn't fun, and it is relieving to know that Bastion succeeds in this fundamental aspect too. Not much can be said about it however, it's just the average action-adventure game with a few tweaks that enable it to distinguish itself from the rest. The Kid can be equipped with 2 weapons at once and he has a "secret" move, and by, of course, playing the game (no way), the Kid is met with unlocks in his arsenal and attributes that gradually form him to an impetus of destruction by the end of the game. Sounds a little, unamusing, but this is without the mention of the copious ways one can up their game. The game played vanilla is laughably easy, but there are shrine idols that can unexpectedly rise its difficulty, which is recommended. There are also Vigils to complete for moneys, and wave-based side missions to earn more moneys and achievements, and a New Game Plus option that actually bears fruit! All of this will keep many entertained for a appreciable amount of time, around 20 hours or so maximum.There's more to be said, but I'm done. Bastion is a worthwhile game that I'm sure many have already invested their time in, and I hope people continue to pick this up. Supergiant Games is a talented developer, and they only demonstrate so with this installation. Where it fails in storytelling makes up in well-done game-structure and incredible graphics and sound. I'm looking foward to playing more entries from this group.Still haven't played Transistor at the time of this review, so I need to get to that quick.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												    Wow. Where should I start? Well, this game is probably my new all-time favorite. It has secured a place in my heart and I look forward to playing other games from Supergiant Games in the near future.    This game has an absolutely beautiful story that engulfs the player in the environment in such a way that I have never before experienced. The set-up for the narration is incredible and makes you feel like you are sitting on the Bastion listening to Rucks tell the story of the Kid.     The music is amazing and captures the environment of the game in a way that I've only seen two other games do before in my life (MGS4, and Borderlands). I will admit, I am a bit biased on the music because I love indie music in general and I love a very acoustic sound, so this was already appealing, but then as the game progresses the music takes a diverse turn that is very rare in any mainstream media. Darren Korb's instrumentation is great and includes a wide variety of instruments, and the vocals are absolutely beautiful (Ashley Barrett, I'm looking at you!).    The art is breathtaking to say the least. The game almost looks like the player is playing in a stained glass mosaic piece and the animation is smooth and natural feeling. The modeling is also superb and does not at all feel clunky.     Lastly, the gameplay is just 100% phenomenal. As mentioned above, the game plays very smoothly and everything feels very natural. The difficulty is at a very good level, giving the player the option to "invoke the gods" which provides a more difficult challenge, and gives the player more "fragments" and experience to build their character. Bastion's wide variety of customization options makes the game perfectly tailored to the player and ensures that people of all ages and skill levels can enjoy it.    Do I recommend this game? Absolutely. And not just to people who like Action Role-Playing games, but to everyone who wants to play a game that is, in the most modest of terms, perfect. Bastion is everything a player could ever want in a game, and is a must-have for anybody who has the ability to play it. "Now The Kid sees somethin' stranger still; his mind races. Did anyone else survive? Sure enough, he finds another. He finds me." - Rucks, The Stranger

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
The GoodThe main reason to play this game is for the story, most particularly the interesting way that story is presented.  Everything is narrated, and the narration serves both to guide the player through various parts of the game, it's also informed and appropriately altered by the player's actions.The gameplay is very solid in most aspects, and works very well in its isometric framework.  The graphics are excellent, and it's endlessly fascinating to watch the stages gradually take form as you move around, and just as fascinating to run around destroying as much of it as you can.  The real star of the background is the music, however, which is just chock full of beautiful and catchy sounds.  Shelling out $9.99 for the soundtrack is a bargain as far as I'm concerned.The BadThe mechanics of the game have surprisingly little variation given how many different weapons, abilities, and the like that are available.  Many of the enemies can be taken out in a lot different ways, meaning there's very little reason to bother switching away from whatever weapon you've picked as your favorite since odds are it'll still do the trick.  I do like the combat, but I also think it could have benefited a great deal from just a little more depth.OverallA very fun game with a damn fine soundtrack and a good, thought-provoking story presented in a unique way.  I would definitely recommend giving it a try, and I personally look forward to seeing and playing SuperGiant Games' future endeavors.
