content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												What do you say to someone who’s played it all?“Buy this game. Please.”	Bastion is one of the “big names” of the Indie scene. Although its reach has gone farther than most games made by small companies thanks to a partnership between Supergiant Games and Warner Brothers, Bastion still has the charm that only a small-time game can. From the graphics to the gameplay, the music to the narration, you know you’ve found something special from the moment the game begins.	The game follows the story of a boy known only as “the Kid” following a catastrophic event called the Calamity. With the world falling to pieces, it’s up to the Kid to collect cores to rebuild the bastion and restore life. An old man known as Rucks narrates the story as it plays out. Along the way, the Kid must fight off monsters, enemies, and even nature itself to retrieve the cores and save the bastion, with a few surprises along the way.	Artistically, Bastion is a gem. Jen Zee’s artwork gives the world an organic, colorful feeling that constantly evolves around the player’s actions. The soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is as beautiful as it is fitting for the game’s story. With a very down-to-earth feel and haunting lyrics on a number of tracks, the soundtrack makes for good listening both in and out of the game. Better yet, it’s also available for purchase on the Steam marketplace.	In respects to gameplay, Bastion is a generally easy game. I had little difficulty making my way through on my first play-through, and never encountered a game over. That being said, the “Shrine” portion of the game allows players to raise the difficulty in exchange for more fragments (currency used for upgrades and purchases) and XP. With that in mind, the game can be made as easy or as difficult as the player would like, with the best benefits reserved for those who play the hardest.	What Bastion is known for most of all is its narrator, Rucks, who narrates the game’s events as they play out. The old, weathered voice of the man gives a dimension to the game that few others can hold a flame to. His voice guides players through the plot at several key points, but is also free-flowing at other instances. Rucks might comment on the weapons the Kid uses, offer hints when needed, and even comment on little things such as falling off the stage. The story is framed as Zucks telling the story--to whom? That comes in time.	Bastion is a gem, and for good reasons. Its fascinating story is told through every medium--art, music, and plot--and culminates in one fantastic experience. If you have the opportunity to experience Bastion, do so.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												For those of you who haven't heard of it already, Bastion is an isometric action RPG, and the first game released by American game development studio Supergiant Games. Set in a colourful hand-painted post-apocalyptic world, you play as the Kid, a silent protagonist who wakes up to find himself and not much else floating on a piece of what was once Caelondia. Setting off for the Bastion, the civilization's refuge in times of calamity, you create, find and fight your way towards an unknown future.Bastion is unique in that you discover the story and the backstory behind the characters by playing through levels and having the narrator speak to you. The narrator reacts to your actions in the game with contextually-appropriate comments. There is very little reading to slow you down in-game, as Bastion plays like a narrated storybook. Its musical score (described as "acoustic frontier trip hop"), art direction and narration have been universally praised, and I find the story to be compelling. Other people may disagree on whether or not the story draws you in but I think it's interesting to explore the after-effects of surviving an apocalypse. There is a great deal of customization in the form of weapon and alcohol combinations, and the combat is responsive.Unfortunately, the levels tend to blend so well with the background that you have difficulty telling where the ground ends. Falling off edges is not penalized excessively, though; you only lose a bit of health. And while combat is responsive, it can become repetitive since the only way to scale the difficulty of the game is through invoking gods, which goes from easy to brutally hard. Bastion is also a really short game, clocking in at about 8-10 hours for a single playthrough. However, there is a new game+ mode, where you get to keep everything you collected in previous saves. The story also supports there being a new game+ mode so there is added replay value.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I usually avoid Hack & Slash games, but Bastion is special. Instead of drowning you in endless grind, the designers kept it short & sweet. This allows story to actively drive the game all the way through, rather than merely serving as punctuation. The smooth, standout narration deserves your careful ear, as its backstory adds so much depth to the overall experience. Bastion is one of the few games which enticed me to seek out other's analysis on its themes and philosophy afterwards.The cartoonish, hand painted world blends together to defy the sterile, methodical aesthetic many isometric games suffer. It's cute how these gorgeous tiles and assets fancifully fall into place just a few steps ahead of you, all in theme with the recollective nature of the story. The only jarring result of Bastion's isometry is you can only move in 8 directions; not granularly. However, the important thing is weapon aiming is granular.I won't lie, there were times I found the combat frustrating, but it did improve as I levelled (and equipped) up, and by the end, I was even enjoyed it. I also appreciated the fact that you have a good old fashioned hunk o' metal shield. As in, one you have to actively face the enemy and raise to counter with. The combat is definitely more interesting for that decision.Besides, Bastion is worth it for the music alone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2012
												Original review by 17 year-old Luke: "A narrator who compares with even Morgan Freeman, challenging gameplay and a deep story - with a unique storytelling style. If you have working hands: play this game."While 19 year-old Luke agrees, I feel as though there's more to say, since looking back at Bastion: it still feels like one of my most significant gaming experiences of ever.That viewpoint is perhaps somewhat nostalgic; this was one of the first real PC games I played back when I was still primarily a console gamer. So I will look back on it with that same sense of importance as Assassin's Creed 2 or Uncharted 2, the first two PlayStation 3 games I played.Nevertheless, there are elements of this game that make it recommendable to anyone, despite its personal significance to myself and the close friends who played and discussed it with me back then.Firstly, the narration is exquisite - and yes, past-luke, it does compare to Morgan Freeman. The narration really draws you into the world quite quickly, and although I don't have a vivid memory of the world that the game was set in, I do have a vivid memory of the (protagonist) kid's adventure through that world. The narration is your first contact with that world, right into the game's ending moments - which I won't spoil, but I will say that they are very well crafted from a storytelling perspective.Secondly, I said the game had challenging gameplay. I'm not sure why I said that really. I did die a few times, but that was just because I wasn't used to playing with a keyboard and mouse more than anything. As James (M!dD3) points out in his comment, the gameplay is straightforward and simple, with a wide array of weapons to choose from and experiment with. And for those who want more out of a game's challenge - there are indeed way to buff your enemies in the name of bragging rights.For me though, the gameplay wasn't a prominent factor. More important was the music, the soundtrack is amazing and undefinable by common genres. I've heard it described as "acoustic frontier trip-hop", so....yeah. Lovely. I still listen to that soundtrack today, and everyone I've encouraged to listen to it has loved the sounds: from friends my age, to adults, to grandparents.However, a game's soundtrack isn't rated by the quality of the sounds alone; in-game that is an irrelevant quality. But the music fits the game perfectly. I can still recall the chilling hammer-on-stone clangs of "mine, windbag, mine' as I entered an eerie stage and began to learn more of the truth of the strange world. And don't even get me started on "build that wall" and "mother, I'm here" - or better yet, their lovechild: "setting sail, coming home", to this day one of my favourite songs.The artstyle is equally captivating while in game, there's a certain childish element to the designs that mix with the seriousness of the plot - summing up the kid's overburdened mindset perfectly. There's a reason that kid looks so melancholy on the game's cover art.And I suppose that brings me to the final element that I mentioned, the game's "deep plot". Yes, well, that's one way to put it. Let me just say the decisions I made in that game hold true to the way I intend to continue to view my failures and embrace the future for the rest of my life. That is by no means an overstatement, or some pretentious interpretation of the game's plot. This game is simple and important, that's all there is to it. So, as past-luke rightfully said: "if you have working hands: play this game."Storytelling: 1/1Plot: 1/1Gameplay: [who even cares, just play it]/10Visuals: 9/10 (impressively beautiful, but not the recommendation-point on this one)Soundtrack: 11/10 (the music itself is 100% recommendable, even if you don't play the game - check it out right now if you're reading this)Do I get a boner just thinking about this game?: Yes/Yes

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Bastion combines a wonderful mix of story, art, music, and gameplay all in a way that feels unique to itself.  The game starts you off with little direction but the narrator's voice as you get used to the controls, combat system, level flow, and most importantly the signature level design.  Every environment is Bastion "builds" itself from the ground up around you creating a very unique take on the "fog of war" style exploration you commonly see in strategy games.  Story-wise all of this is the result of some far-flung calamity that literally destroyed a good chunk of the world.  This puts the story's focus half on keeping up the progress of the Bastion's buildings and exploration of what's left around you.The graphics are wonderfully rendered and everything looks like a mix of semi-realistic 3D and hand-drawn sprites similar to a sort of top-down version of Braid.  Despite the bleak undertones, the colors are vibrant even in the darker levels and every place feels both desolate yet full of life as you see what's become of the world around you.  All of these are explored via your home base- the titular Bastion which acts both as a hub for missions, power ups, weapons, and side-quests, but also serves to both tell and fill in the holes of the story you missed through the narration that goes on throughout the levels.There are only four named characters in the game counting the protagonist, but all of them are surprisingly well-developed for how little any of them actually speak.  All of them have special reactions to pretty much everything you bring back with you on each trip and each has a backstory to explore through special bonus levels.  While interaction with them is minimalistic at best, you really grow to know who they are and care about their well being just as much as in games where you spend most of the story talking to them, which is quite the accomplishment on part of the frankly stellar narration.For how much of the game you're going to spend in combat, it sometimes feels like it takes a back seat to everything going on around you.  However, you'll never get distracted from it and each of the game's unique weapons has its own bonuses and downsides making no combination (you can take two with you, plus one special move of your choice) a bad call.  It really calls to create your own fighting style and do what suits you best.  Due to how you can upgrade any weapons in a variety of ways, there's really no wrong way to go into battle and it's always fun.  What makes things more interesting is that depending on what weapons you pick, how you choose to go about a level, and even how well you're doing or whether you decide to simply derp about, the narrator has a response to pretty much EVERYTHING you do, which adds a bit of flavor and life to the game that feels a lot more like you're actually being watched and having your story told.The soundtrack of the game is just as varied as everything else in it and always manages to hit the perfect mood, particularly with the wonderfully done vocal songs.  Many levels or situations have their own music and no two songs really feel the same or reused whenever they appear.Overall Bastion is a wonderful experience that takes roughly seven to ten hours to complete in one playthrough.  It's not a long game, but at the same time it's not any longer or shorter than it needs to be.  But you'll be thankful for that because it means you can easily play it again.  If you ever see it appear in sales or the Humble Bundle as it's often wont to, I highly suggest picking it up if it even sounds remotely interesting to you.

												Bastion: The first game made by Supergiant Games. Also the first amazing game they created.Bastion's a hack and slash action-adventure game, and a great one at that. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.All in all, a highly recommendable game.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												One of my all time favorite games.  Bastion tells the tale of "The Kid", (possibly) a young man waking up in the aftermath of what's deemed "The Calamity," a disaster that overtook the entirety of Caelondia.  From there, you're on a journey to restore the Bastion, a place of sanctuary for when the situation arose.The story creates a perfect world where details are up to the player's interpretation, being quite scarce and vague overall on the land itself, and the landmarks which litter it.  Throughout the game, you're given a beautifully executed narrative by Logan Cunningham, who - with every step of the way - informs you of your progress as you roll along, and provides interesting pieces that could tell a thing or two about the land's past, or your own. The game is played from an Isometric perspective, with that being the camera being held at around an seventy-five degree angle.  Gameplay can often be mixed up to however your choosing with two weapon slots for you to make use of. Two melee weapons or two devastating range weapons?  Sure, why not. The game can provide wider mix of playstyles as well, having access to a special skill to make use of between your two weapons, it can turn the tide of battle in your favor.  Furthermore, the game can give you special "tonics" that you can equip within the game's Distillery that can give you a boost to help your survive longer in battle, or to compliment your playstyle of being at a distance or up close.With it's hand drawn art, intricate story, fairly diverse gameplay, deep narrative, and great soundtrack, I'd say this game is well worth the money you put into it.

I would have never guessed Bastion was an indie game made by a group of 7 people on my own. The game art and world work flawlessly, the innovitave and dynamic narration system makes the whole tale all the more engrossing, and the soundtrack is exquisite. I won't go into details about the game elements, for half of the pleasure is discovering what next the game throws at you. This game is an achievement of human ingenuity, a must play for everyone!

												Four hours into this game and it's definitely worth saying a few things. I'll start with the graphics only because the style in which this world is built is breathtaking. The art direction is watercolours, and do they ever add a fluidity to the movements of The Kid, the silent protagonist of whom you are controlling in this adventure. The colours themselves either have an undeniable shine to them that gently turn into black and white as your health decreases. So does your vision, which I found to be a great mechanic to have.The story is unique in where a narrator occassionally comments on your actions, while giving the player a sense of direction of where they are going and why. Honestly it's the only sense of direction you are likely to receive, given as to how each level is "summoned" step by step.A final word would be on the soundtrack. It goes with the game perfectly. What else is there to say?Get yourself this game if you're a fan of Adventure games!

												This game was a breath of fresh of fresh air for me, Purely because of the games i played beforehand. Before this, i played several games, ALL of them Story-based. All Story, no gameplay.This game is singificant in that the Soundtrack is beautiful, which is no surprise, but the star is an addictive gameplay AND a gripping story. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Figured i'd write a little something since this game is on sale.First of all, as far as indie games go, this is one of the best, let's go over what it has to offer.+ Top quality soundtrack.+ Beautiful, and mostly hand drawn art style.+ Narrator is a nice touch, with a very fitting voice, wich means fantastic storytelling.+ An excellent system to increase difficulty (wich comes with rewards of course).+ A total of 11 weapons (that come with upgrades) and a distillery building that provides you passive bonuses.There are some arguable negatives.- Game is quite short.- Not much replayability (offers a New game+ option and a "survival wave" mode where you get to discover each of the character's story).I had have to edit the review a bit. I'm just not satisfied with what i said, take the above as a short version so to speak.First of all a critical thing i forgot to mention in my short review is that you use two weapons at once. That means you can kind of build your playstyle based on two weapons. Other then that: the storytelling that is backed up by the narrator has a good attention to detail, he'll say certain things if you fall in a certain area, he'll say something if you kill all enemies in a certain section of the game etc.To make a spoiler example: You can "adomesticate" certain creatures and keep them in the bastion. At some point in the game you get invaded by the Ura's, one of my pets that was fighting the ura died. The narrator promptly said "Our woodpecker friend, he don't make it.Apart from the attention to detail part, the game narrator has his own charm, his own way of speaking so to say wich i found deserved mentioning. The writing also was very well executed, one area stuck to my head in particular. Jawson Bog (light spoiler follows)Jawson bog is the area where the kid (protagonist) loses hope, he goes trough some hallucinations, basically playing small segments of previous areas again with an altered dialogue that was spokem previously by the narrator. For example at the start of the game you find a shield in an old distillery, then you learn to use it against some turret like things. The first time the narrator comments about you using the shield to your advantage to "counter" the turrets, in the hallucination however he says "He has the nerve to flash the shield he just stole, he's a petty thief. The owner of the distillery is also there, just turned to... some sort of stone i think it was, anyway he's dead, that's the point. In the "original" segment you can hit him and the narrator comments about you putting him out of his misery, in the hallucination he says "Would you look to what he did to poor Rondy"I Think that's about it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2012
												Original review by 17 year-old Luke: "A narrator who compares with even Morgan Freeman, challenging gameplay and a deep story - with a unique storytelling style. If you have working hands: play this game."While 19 year-old Luke agrees, I feel as though there's more to say, since looking back at Bastion: it still feels like one of my most significant gaming experiences of ever.That viewpoint is perhaps somewhat nostalgic; this was one of the first real PC games I played back when I was still primarily a console gamer. So I will look back on it with that same sense of importance as Assassin's Creed 2 or Uncharted 2, the first two PlayStation 3 games I played.Nevertheless, there are elements of this game that make it recommendable to anyone, despite its personal significance to myself and the close friends who played and discussed it with me back then.Firstly, the narration is exquisite - and yes, past-luke, it does compare to Morgan Freeman. The narration really draws you into the world quite quickly, and although I don't have a vivid memory of the world that the game was set in, I do have a vivid memory of the (protagonist) kid's adventure through that world. The narration is your first contact with that world, right into the game's ending moments - which I won't spoil, but I will say that they are very well crafted from a storytelling perspective.Secondly, I said the game had challenging gameplay. I'm not sure why I said that really. I did die a few times, but that was just because I wasn't used to playing with a keyboard and mouse more than anything. As James (M!dD3) points out in his comment, the gameplay is straightforward and simple, with a wide array of weapons to choose from and experiment with. And for those who want more out of a game's challenge - there are indeed way to buff your enemies in the name of bragging rights.For me though, the gameplay wasn't a prominent factor. More important was the music, the soundtrack is amazing and undefinable by common genres. I've heard it described as "acoustic frontier trip-hop", so....yeah. Lovely. I still listen to that soundtrack today, and everyone I've encouraged to listen to it has loved the sounds: from friends my age, to adults, to grandparents.However, a game's soundtrack isn't rated by the quality of the sounds alone; in-game that is an irrelevant quality. But the music fits the game perfectly. I can still recall the chilling hammer-on-stone clangs of "mine, windbag, mine' as I entered an eerie stage and began to learn more of the truth of the strange world. And don't even get me started on "build that wall" and "mother, I'm here" - or better yet, their lovechild: "setting sail, coming home", to this day one of my favourite songs.The artstyle is equally captivating while in game, there's a certain childish element to the designs that mix with the seriousness of the plot - summing up the kid's overburdened mindset perfectly. There's a reason that kid looks so melancholy on the game's cover art.And I suppose that brings me to the final element that I mentioned, the game's "deep plot". Yes, well, that's one way to put it. Let me just say the decisions I made in that game hold true to the way I intend to continue to view my failures and embrace the future for the rest of my life. That is by no means an overstatement, or some pretentious interpretation of the game's plot. This game is simple and important, that's all there is to it. So, as past-luke rightfully said: "if you have working hands: play this game."Storytelling: 1/1Plot: 1/1Gameplay: [who even cares, just play it]/10Visuals: 9/10 (impressively beautiful, but not the recommendation-point on this one)Soundtrack: 11/10 (the music itself is 100% recommendable, even if you don't play the game - check it out right now if you're reading this)Do I get a boner just thinking about this game?: Yes/Yes

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Beatifully made indie game which is very rare these games. Has a very well fitted and nice soundtrack, the music always seems to kick in at the perfect times. Story is very nicely done and worth the sale price you can pick it up for. Combat flows very well as a whole with the rolling mechanic being very smooth with its transition in combat. The only real fault i could put against it would be minor nitpicks like the lack of sprint, or the lack of replayability. All in all it is a nicely made game that can be picked up for a good price. TL;DR: Good game, nice story, smooth flowing gameplay, fun fighting, beautiful graphics, Nice narrator  = Yay.No Sprint, Slow at times, lack of replayability = Nay

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I picked up Bastion when it was on sale with the Humble Bundle. I really just wanted to get my hands on trine, and the game soon fell into dark corners of my game library. A few days ago, for some mysterious reason, i installed it and played it, expected yet another indie game. Don't get me wrong, I love indie games, however with their independent label, we kind of lower our expectations and judge them on their own scale, seeing that a "small team made it against all odds in their own garage". I would have never guessed Bastion was an indie game made by a group of 7 people on my own. The game art and world work flawlessly, the innovitave and dynamic narration system makes the whole tale all the more engrossing, and the soundtrack is exquisite. I won't go into details about the game elements, for half of the pleasure is discovering what next the game throws at you. This game is an achievement of human ingenuity, a must play for everyone!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												"A really great example of what a game should be. Original, interesting, and fun!"  (Dec 27, 2011)I still really enjoy this game. There's no sugarcoating it. This is one of my favorite games of all time and it probably had an influence in my life choices. Looking at the game closer, everything about it appeals to me. I love the character design, the music is above fantastic, and the scripting is amazing. The game mechanics are pretty smooth too, but that wasn't the thing that made this game one of my favorites of all time. The characters became a part of my life while I was playing this game, and not to sound like a crazy person here, but I connected with them all on an emotional level. Every single protagonist made me wonder about my life choices. I'm including Zulf in the pool cause I believe that he is in fact a protagonist, but that's an argument for another day. The Kid is the character that really makes this game. You befriend him as the player. The Kid isn't some faceless hero that you can imprint your own desires on to. The Kid, is The Kid, and everyone in the game recognizes that. The Kid has a personality, yet he's quiet the entire game. Again, I could rant about the similarities and differences that The Kid has to Link from LoZ, but that's an argument for another day. The kid, different from Link, existed before you started to control him. He had a mother and a life of his own. The Kid had feelings and dreams that the player can experience through dream snippets that make a separation possible between character and player. Rucks' narration also helps separate The Kid from the player, but when it comes down to it, this game is beautifully written and I can't stress it enough that this game is worth your money and time.Have a good one,CoffeeGoat

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Is your world falling apart? Bastion can relate.       Maybe not in the mental state but taking place in a world that begins to crumble into pieces, Bastion manages to capture a beautiful unique scenery that has a quite amuzing arcade like gameplay. Positive    The story follows to be short but powerful, the game follows a young boy on the curiosity and discovery on what's happening to his world, and how can you stop it.   Captivating dialouge, you will enjoy this classical hit if you love the enrichment of emotions this story can and does indeed bring.      If you have enough money for the soundtrack i also highly reccomend you download that too. I'm not much on soundtracks, however Bastion does have an extremely rich and cultivating music producer. However the beauty if music is there is aways gonna be a song out there to enjoy....just not for everybody. Thus,https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLA6BDC6AA59483A76      I give you a quick link to hear some of the music so you can see for yourself if you would rather buy the game with or without it's soundtrack. Im kinda repeating mysef here but again, im not much of a fan for the soundtracks, thats why i recommend this one, because i just absolutely love it.(I'm listening to the ending credits song as i write this review!!!)Con      The game doesn't have much of a replaybility, I mean Bastion contains extra modes after the intial completion of the game isn't the type of game you can have 500 hours on....unless you enjoy the game that much but in hinde sight, it is a short game. Additional Info     The game contains multiple endings. Basion contains about as many choices as the size of one grain of rice, but very powerful in game choices you, the player, have to make.  It is not a choice making game like Mass Effect, but I just needed to add that because I still to this day regret all the decisions this game forced me to make. It's a balance of depression and joy that the presence of the choices were involved.In short, for any fan of an enticing, rich storyline with captivating scenery and ear endulging music, this game is a must have. Bastion is a definatly an 11/10 in my book and the music is a must have in your itunes library.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
The GoodThe main reason to play this game is for the story, most particularly the interesting way that story is presented.  Everything is narrated, and the narration serves both to guide the player through various parts of the game, it's also informed and appropriately altered by the player's actions.The gameplay is very solid in most aspects, and works very well in its isometric framework.  The graphics are excellent, and it's endlessly fascinating to watch the stages gradually take form as you move around, and just as fascinating to run around destroying as much of it as you can.  The real star of the background is the music, however, which is just chock full of beautiful and catchy sounds.  Shelling out $9.99 for the soundtrack is a bargain as far as I'm concerned.The BadThe mechanics of the game have surprisingly little variation given how many different weapons, abilities, and the like that are available.  Many of the enemies can be taken out in a lot different ways, meaning there's very little reason to bother switching away from whatever weapon you've picked as your favorite since odds are it'll still do the trick.  I do like the combat, but I also think it could have benefited a great deal from just a little more depth.OverallA very fun game with a damn fine soundtrack and a good, thought-provoking story presented in a unique way.  I would definitely recommend giving it a try, and I personally look forward to seeing and playing SuperGiant Games' future endeavors.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Let's begin with a disclaimer: Bastion if really freaking hard to describe.At its core, it's a top down action game with RPG elements, and at that, it does its job. The game plays like a charm, and most of the weapons are fun to use (even if I found myself liking the ranged options more). The whole game feels extremely tight and polished.Where Bastion really shines, however, is its story AND the way it is presented. Every action you take, even some really meaningless ones (being hit by an enemy in the first level, breaking crates) are commented by the ever present Narrator - if you ever played Portal and liked how GladOs reacted to your actions, you'll like this, too. The story is very good, too, and among a plethora of brown and bleak post-apocalyptic scenarios, I feel the colorful fragmented world of post-calamity Bastion is a refreshing spin on an over-abused genre.With how little it costs, seriously, you just owe this game to yourself. And your friends, possibly.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Must Play not only for Indie FansBastion is a top-down action adventure and the first title by Supergiant Games. It takes place in a dystopian, destroyed fantasy world that is nevertheless colorfully painted. You play as The Kid, a mysterious young man with white hair, and are aided by an omnipresent narrator that dynamically narrates your actions and is also used to deliver the game's lore to you in a very natural way.The gameplay focuses on a combat system based on dodging and rolling. It features an arsenal of melee- and long range weapons that all work and control differently, including a warhammer, dual pistols, a flamethrower and a machete that can also shoot blades. You can customize your experience using a variety of light RPG elements like weapon upgrades, an active ability(like a spin for the hammer or an AoE attack for the flamethrower)and passive boni that you receive by drinking different kinds of liquor you can unlock with experience. There is also an option to make your game harder and receiving more XP in return and a New Game+ Mode.Bastion is an interactive piece of art. The handdrawn art is gorgeous, the soundtrack is among the best ever heard in videogames, and the gameplay synchronises really well with it.

Finally, as you come closer and closer to the end of the line, you slowly uncover the pieces of a heartbreaking tale between two peoples that leads to the calamity.4 years later, this game still has high replay value and I constantly listen to the soundtrack outside of the game.Awesome story. Awesome narration. Awesome music. Awesome gameplay. Awesome game. One of the best games I've ever played.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												"Abstract" "Indie" games is where all the (K)ool Kids are. Just about recently, gamers are regularly met with a surfeit of these indie games that have a history of HYPE. Too bad most of them turn out to be vaporware or pretentious garbage. But there is that minute gleam of light that promises quality. Supergiant Games, thankfully, ends up being one of the few that actually develop decent games. Bastion, the game in question, is not one that should be adjudged "decent", but rather, astounding. Far from flawless, as this game is locked at 30 frames (Just, why?), but an overall stellar game that is worth every penny, or whatever crap currency you wield.Meet the Kid. One of the handful of survivors that has endured the Calamity. This catastrophic event brought the whole world to ruin. He sets off to the Bastion, where he is greeted by Rucks, the Stranger, with words claiming that the recent disaster can be undone. By constructing the Bastion back to health with monument cores and shards there are odds of restoring Caelondia and its neighbor lands to a time before hell unleashed, hence the title of this game. Throughout the Kid's travels to seek out the materials needed, players will learn more about the world and its people and you get to learn the backstories of the few survivors you come across as the game progresses. It might seem engrossing, but the story is where Bastion falls shortest. The journey with the Kid was complete in every angle it is viewed in, but it was also rushed from start to end, and had inadequate time to develop. Build-up starts to occur profusely around the last third of the game, only to conclude in some half-baked ending that proved to be unfufilling. Despite the mediocre narrative, Bastion is a feast for the eyes and ears due to it's gorgeous presentation.It is not an overstatement when it is said that this game has the potential to be sold solely on it's presentation. Hell, some have avowed that they bought the soundtrack before the damn game. It's just that damn delicious. Bastion's visuals is where that abstract tag comes into play, because it is most certainly what most reckon to be unconventional. The playing stage constructs itself as you tread along the path and the camera is complimented by a shiny filter, and other things I won't bother typing as it's better experienced than read. The soundtrack, done by composer Darren Korb, is brimful with impressive songs that seemlessly attach to the rest of the presentation. I'm not one that gushes over video game OSTs, but this one is pretty damn good, and I'm convinced everyone that isn't a moron agrees.If only it wasn't locked at thirty frames...that idea bothers me way to f****** much.Even with such wondrous superficial values, a game is crap if it isn't fun, and it is relieving to know that Bastion succeeds in this fundamental aspect too. Not much can be said about it however, it's just the average action-adventure game with a few tweaks that enable it to distinguish itself from the rest. The Kid can be equipped with 2 weapons at once and he has a "secret" move, and by, of course, playing the game (no way), the Kid is met with unlocks in his arsenal and attributes that gradually form him to an impetus of destruction by the end of the game. Sounds a little, unamusing, but this is without the mention of the copious ways one can up their game. The game played vanilla is laughably easy, but there are shrine idols that can unexpectedly rise its difficulty, which is recommended. There are also Vigils to complete for moneys, and wave-based side missions to earn more moneys and achievements, and a New Game Plus option that actually bears fruit! All of this will keep many entertained for a appreciable amount of time, around 20 hours or so maximum.There's more to be said, but I'm done. Bastion is a worthwhile game that I'm sure many have already invested their time in, and I hope people continue to pick this up. Supergiant Games is a talented developer, and they only demonstrate so with this installation. Where it fails in storytelling makes up in well-done game-structure and incredible graphics and sound. I'm looking foward to playing more entries from this group.Still haven't played Transistor at the time of this review, so I need to get to that quick.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												I cannot sing the praises of this game enough. I went into this knowing next to nothing, not even knowing how well praised it is. This has become my favorite game. The story is interesting and quite grim. There are no cutscenes or excessive text. It doesn't try to be a movie, it's a very subtle and gameplay driven story. The Narrator's voice gives Morgan Freeman a run for his money. The gameplay is fun and stays fresh for the most part. Interesting enemies and lore. The art style is beautiful, I adore how the land forms at your feet.And the soundtrack? Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. It is PHENOMENAL. I could listen to it nonstop. There is not a single song that is any less than the others. There are a few songs that have singers, which is usually a no-no in video games, but it suits the situation perfectly.The one thing that really bothers me only applies to you if you want to complete every little thing in the game like I do. It's no problem if you're a "finish the story then I'm out" kind of person. But the grinding. To buy every upgrade for every weapon, you have to beat Who Knows Where many times, or replay New Game+ multiple times. It gets stale, but I need to beat the Calamity Cannon training grounds, dammit!Bottom line, buy it. I'd wait for a Steam Sale (then again, I do for everything), but it's worth every cent. Supergiant Games deserves it so they can hopefully make more awesomeness. I can't wait to try Transistor.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
Proper review supposed to start at the beginning... Ain't so simple with this one	Get Bastion. Really. A discount means it's a steal for youI'm just foolingBastion is an adventure beat-em-up game with unique artstyle, superb storytelling, hypnotizing music, and a meta-ish thingy in the plotline.Bastion graphical representation used a lot of handpainted scenery, resulting in a beautiful and easy-in-the-eye kind of graphics, you won't find many game that uses this kind (well, aside from other game from Supergiant, Transistor). It'll be a different 'graphics' experience for you with BastionThe story in this game are told with a narrator as the player progresses through the Bastion world. The character player control is silent (and looks like the main character communicate with other using handwriting, as hinted by all the dialogue choices when interacting with others), and all element about Bastion are told by the narrator. The narrator did a really excellent job at delivering the world of Bastion to the player. His voice feels friendly, like someone you've known for so long, yet only meet again after a long separation. You won't feel tired listening to the narrator thoughout the game, and it is also a good thing because the way of the storytelling is unique, leaving you with a feeling of wanting to be told more.Music at the bastion is a little different with other games that usually use orchestra of violin, drum, piano or everything else. It sound like 1 or 2 instrument that playing along with a storyteller, and perfectly captures the predicament of the story being told. This fits a lot with the storytelling style of Bastion.Not much of gameplay selling point can be told here. Some people might feels the combat is repetitive, and old as there's no differentiation to other game with same type of combat. That might be true, but I find Bastion combat is at good value. The many Arsenal you'll find coupled with passive boost from Distillery and difficulty tweaker from the Shrine will kinda force you to seek new way to combat the enemy and it's good enough for me.The meta things of Bastion plot is *SPOILER AHEAD  you're supposed to choose a peculiar ending in order for your first playthrough to match with the new game +, the Restoration Protocol. Because the narrator will have some kind of deja vu telling throughout the whole new game + narration, it fits the ending. Also it can be interpreted that as the player, you are the Kid's will that never forget even after time reset itself, the Kid at first want to restore the world before the Calamity happen, but as the player see that restoring the world doesn't prevent the Calamity, on the second playthrough, you know that the correct choice is Evacuation Protocol, thus setting sail for a new home is kinda the right /good ending of Bastion. Bastion is game where a second playthrough is needed to close a loophole that might be caused by 1 ending. And it's spectacular for a game this small to have this kind of meta story.The whole narration or the story is actually Ruck telling the story to Zia about how they all come together, while waiting for the Kid to return from the Tazal Terminal at the last level, so you are playing a memory of Ruck, and the only real time moment Ruck's narrating is when we save/leave Zulf and afterward.Also, dramatic moment when you decide to rescue Zulf. The music is plain tearjerker, the tension of the situation feels heroic and out of respect, you'll struck in awe playing that part.It's finished... No matter what you decide to buy Bastion or not, you done good...The Bastion's gonna take us to a better gametimeSo long kid, Maybe I'll see you in the next one*cue Setting Sail, Coming Home music (youtube it!)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												You wake up.  Stuff's falling apart.  An old guy starts narrating as you run around trying to figure out what the dink is going on.  This is the Kid's story about the Calamity.StoryWhile the actual storyline in itself has been done before, the presentation of it feels fresh and new as you discover what exactly is happening and everyone's lives beforehand and so on.  If I must make one qualm is the story is completely narrated to you during play.  That means while you're trying not to die fighting a boss or something, there is actual story being presented and it can be difficult for those who can't multitask to be able to pay attention and lose details.  It's also incredibly short, and you'll be able to do just the story in around 3 hours (not including sidequests) though the game has a New Game+ encouraging you to play a second time through with all your assets still in check.GraphicsSprites are sharp looking, environments lush.  I think the Kid's ingame proportions look a bit off from his artwork design but eventually you get used to it.  The enemy variety was a bit lackluster, which is a fault of the game being rather on the short side unfortunetly.  Sometimes it could also be difficult to figure out what you could and couldn't walk on leading to a fall, but I could've just needed my eyes checked I have no idea since it happened to me three times.ControlsThis game was meant more for a gamepad I feel, as the keyboard just feels rather awkward overall.  You can get used to it but never feels nearly as fluid as the controller with it's precise movement.GameplayI have to admit, blowing something up with a mortar or whatnot brings a shimmer to my eye.  Everything in the game feels organic, leveling your character, using materials to upgrade your (very large) cache of weapons and equipping tonics to your character instead of armor to grant special quirks.  Again as stated earlier, due to the game being so short it's necessity you need to play through the New Game+ just to be able to upgrade everything and even unlock the rest of the achievements since you can't play through any areas except Proving Grounds or character related arenas.  The Proving Grounds force you to complete a task using the specific weapon for each area.  My main issue is the difficulty ratios for each of them are wildly different, and sometimes you cannot complete a proving ground until you fully upgrade said weapon which is a tad irritating.  God help the Machete Proving Ground and it's stupidity.  If the game ever feels too easy, you can also add in Deities or Gods onto your person which grants you an experience bonus but adds difficulty and let me tell you, the game can be impossibly ruthless with those settings on.  The main flaw I feel of the combat system is the targeting, as you automatically target the enemy closest to you, but if you wish to switch to another target, any enemy between it and them will have to be manually cycled through leading to massive headaches due to the frequency of tons of enemies being dumped on you.  This also coincides with your shield use as you have to be facing the target to be able to use it and is just best left to dodge and roll then to block.SoundAt first I wasn't too enthusiastic about the music, but it has grown on me over time and I enjoy it.  Is it the best soundtrack ever? No particularly though there are some choice tracks in there that are worth listening too.  The voice acting is also done really well with the Narrator narrating everything from what weapons you equip to if you slip off a ledge and fall on your face.ConclusionA highly enjoyable game that is unfortunately really short, New Game+ or no.  Some small tweaks here or there and it could benefit greatly.  It also has some sort of 3rd mode of play which I never attempted involving some kinda scoreboard, which indeed this game does have leaderboards that surprises me but hey, why not right?

content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Bastion is what every indie game hopes to be. The excellent fast-paced action/adventure combat pales only in comparison to the visual vibrancy and storytelling immersion. Far from a gimmick, the narration fits so seamlessly with the rest of the game it will leave you wondering why it hasn't been done more. This game will draw you in with its addictive combat mechanics, and keep you enthralled with its emotionally-charged storyline. If you haven't played Bastion, you're missing out on one of the greatest works of gaming art ever made.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Bastion is a 2D isometric hack and slash that (unlike every other game I’ve ever played) works well with both controller and keyboard & mouse.  The first title released by indie studio, Supergiant Games, Bastion is a colorful, fast action platformer that is great for kids and adults alike.The Good:  Everything!  This game is %&@$ing amazing in every way!  The color, the way the story is told, the story itself, the music, the upgrades, the way the difficulty increases, the way new game plus is done, the artwork, the level design, the combat mechanics, the upgrades … you get the idea.  Literally everything is wonderful in this game!The Bad: The game is a little short and … Uhh … hmm, I am REALLY fishing for anything here.  OH! I got it! If you can find a way to make the hammer or machete work better than the pike I’d love to see how, the Brushers Pike/Spear is WAY better than the other two melee weapons.The Funky:  If you get it on Steam they give you a turret from the Portal games.  Talk to it and it will utter phrases such as, “sensory overload” and “location unknown.”The Verdict:  I really wish saying “10 out of 10” was not so over used because here it actually applies.  It is damn near impossible to get more entertainment for 15 bucks anywhere.  I realize this review is a bit short but the game has to be played to be understood and you’d be reading 2-3 more pages just for me to set the stage to talk about the experience that is Bastion.  Get it, play it, LOVE THE HELL OUT OF IT!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												After completing Bastion, I realized that the ending is actually really thoughtful, you have two ultimate choices; restore the world to a time before the calamity which is the apocalyptic catastrophe that caused an outbreak in plague, monsters, and fighting factions, or evacuate the Bastion, the mechanical floating island that the old man, Rucks, and you, the kid, live on. That's the central point of the game, to get the Bastion back in working order, gathering shards and minerals to fix the Bastion.Along the journey, the old man, Rucks, narrates every move you make which might sound annoying but was actually intuitive because of all the context he is able to give. Later on in the game, you figure out that he's narrating to one of the Ura, a girl named Zia who comes to the Bastion after meeting the kid.I can't say much about the gameplay, as it's rather repetitive, shooting down enemies, blocking, and hacking, no depth to it. But the options you get in weaponry and special abilities and the leveling up make up for it. The game's design is isometric but also 2D, kind of cel shaded. And the floating islands which are part of the world was an interesting way to represent how society has turned out.Very good game though, with heavy depth in narrative.9.1/10

Posted: December 30, 2014
												this game is short, very short, short enough to finish the story in an afternoon/ evening. but it is very fun doing so, and the story and narration are amazing. it even got a wee bit emotional towards the end and the Narrator always kept the story and action moving along, in some ways it had some strong similarities to call of Juarez : gunslinger in the narration style, with it responding to players deaths and weapon usage as well as interaction with the surroundings.  it's a gorgeous looking game as well and frankly i think anyone who is looking for an easy to pick up isometric rpg should seriously consider this one :) all in all a cute, fun, humouress and well written little game

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Buy this. Now.Seriously, this game is possibly one of the greatest games I have ever played- the story is phenominal, the characters interesting and deep, the atmosphere hauntingly beautiful, and the most important to me, it NEVER felt like an indie title. The game stars a set of four characters after the 'Calamity', a mysterious force that next to destroyed the world. You play as 'The Kid', and head to Bastion to meet "The Stranger", who narrates your story to build the Bastion and give hope to the new world. Along the way you meet Zulf, a fabulous character and probably one of the best in any game ever, and Zia- a young Singer who brings a vision of innocence and childlike wonder to the otherwise bleak world.I've played through the game three times, and every time I notice something new- some piece of narration with a second meaning, or even a theory about the world I hadn't seen before. If you can't pay for this game now, buy it when it hits the sale shelf.Overall, this is one of the most flawless games I've ever played. 10/10.

												A landmark in innovative interactive storytelling and art. perfectly crafted, from the sound and the effects and quality (the muffled sound when shot or pause), the paintings and graphics (which are artworks by themselves), the music, the interactive narrator that enthralls you and describes quite fluidly and naturally your movements and decitions besides intriguing you to keep finding what he wants to say, the variety of choice in the game and the poetic aspect of its story. its all beautiful, trully an artistic masterpiece.it doesnt necesarilly have heavy gameplay features (although i found them quite entertaining and vast myself) but the main catch of the game is the narrative process, the exploration and feel of the environment and simply experiencing the game and what it is saying.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												A beautiful arcade game with hand painted graphics supported by an interesting and original story and an even more original storytelling. The world you are evoling in is building itself while you are moving, and nearly every of your step is accompagnied by a deep and grizzly narator voice.The game comes with a variety of enemies using different tactics to bother you and of course with bosses. You on the other hand have a big choice of weapons and perks allowing you to always be best prepared for the next world you enter. Weapons are upgradable with "fragments' of the world you collect during your adventures, and you can also gain fragments while completing challenges related to your weapons or to the story.Expect 20 hours of gaming at least on your first run, and 10 to 15 more if you want to complete the "New Game Plus" mode and/or all Steam achievements.I highgly recommend it for anyone wanting to play a "different" arcade game.One last thing: there is no way you could not enjoy the beautifully crafted soundtrack.

												A landmark in innovative interactive storytelling and art. perfectly crafted, from the sound and the effects and quality (the muffled sound when shot or pause), the paintings and graphics (which are artworks by themselves), the music, the interactive narrator that enthralls you and describes quite fluidly and naturally your movements and decitions besides intriguing you to keep finding what he wants to say, the variety of choice in the game and the poetic aspect of its story. its all beautiful, trully an artistic masterpiece.it doesnt necesarilly have heavy gameplay features (although i found them quite entertaining and vast myself) but the main catch of the game is the narrative process, the exploration and feel of the environment and simply experiencing the game and what it is saying.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Bastion is a 2D isometric hack and slash that (unlike every other game I’ve ever played) works well with both controller and keyboard & mouse.  The first title released by indie studio, Supergiant Games, Bastion is a colorful, fast action platformer that is great for kids and adults alike.The Good:  Everything!  This game is %&@$ing amazing in every way!  The color, the way the story is told, the story itself, the music, the upgrades, the way the difficulty increases, the way new game plus is done, the artwork, the level design, the combat mechanics, the upgrades … you get the idea.  Literally everything is wonderful in this game!The Bad: The game is a little short and … Uhh … hmm, I am REALLY fishing for anything here.  OH! I got it! If you can find a way to make the hammer or machete work better than the pike I’d love to see how, the Brushers Pike/Spear is WAY better than the other two melee weapons.The Funky:  If you get it on Steam they give you a turret from the Portal games.  Talk to it and it will utter phrases such as, “sensory overload” and “location unknown.”The Verdict:  I really wish saying “10 out of 10” was not so over used because here it actually applies.  It is damn near impossible to get more entertainment for 15 bucks anywhere.  I realize this review is a bit short but the game has to be played to be understood and you’d be reading 2-3 more pages just for me to set the stage to talk about the experience that is Bastion.  Get it, play it, LOVE THE HELL OUT OF IT!

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Bastion is an amazing game, with amazing gameplay, a great narrator, beautiful visuals, and a soundtrack so good your ears will ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's upgrade system is good, it has very fun weapons, and overall the gameplay just feels like it's exactly how it should be. The story is very good. It is simple but creative. How is the story told? Well, as you're playing the game, it is narrated from a future point of view. This not only answers questions you have while playing the game, but it leaves you unanswered with the biggest question; To whom is the story being told? Anyways, what is the story about? You wake up, with the world around you shattered and abandoned. As you move on, it soon just seems like you're trying to just fix everything after an apocalypse. Though while you dig deeper into the game, you find out what it's really about. It's about war, and the affect it has on not just people, but on the world. The game lets you make some huge decisions, big enough to make you think "Am I doing the right thing?". It's so well put together it made me question who I was and if I knew enough to make decisions that big in real life.The game is one of the most original titles I have ever seen. Supergiant did everything right with it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												There's not much to say about Bastion...Amazing art direction, slick presentation, superb narration, and the soundtrack blends in perfectly with the gameplay. The game mechanics are excellent as well. Every weapons have a unique feeling to them and are fun to use, from light and heavy melee weapons, to bows and guns. Furthermore, weapons' abilities can be customized through a kind of crafting system which allows for different kind of play style with the same weapon. You can also increase the difficulty at any time by selecting up to 10 idols which grant unique boosts to your enemies, but earn you more experience points in return.Overall, the game's quite short and not very challenging, but that is only because they chose quality over quantity. A highly recommended game and experience.

content:
Posted: March 1
												Bastion is a 3D platforming game made by a small team of indie developers that stands above a lot of their competitors because of their style of narration, art style, and smooth mechanical brilliance.Bastion blends a very well told story with a very smooth narrative done in a almost storybook like fashion with a great voice actor that rivals the likes of Morgan Freeman, which also helps that none feels out of place or overdone. The platforming is very seamless and does a great job of incorporating a variety of unique weapons that you can choose to fit your play-style. Bastion does a great job of also helping you along the path to mastering said weapon with optional challenges that push your weapon potential to the limit. Above all, the game has an incredible original soundtrack that makes the whole experience that much more enjoyable.Pros:+ Great Narration and storytelling+ Phenominal music, I still sometimes hum the Build the Wall song+ Fast pace platform action game with variety of unique weapons to fit each players play style+ Great hand drawn art+ Fun gameplay+ Great use of different ways to change game difficulty and challenges to unlock upgradesCons:- Not much in replayabilityTL;DR:9/10Very enjoyable 3D platformer with great music, awesome mechanics, and good story.

Posted: January 14, 2016
												Why I play games is both for the challenge of the gameplay and the immersion of the story itself. On both counts Bastion is superb. The story itself can be hard to grasp while you're too busy learning the ropes and not trying to die, but this only serves to make replaying it all the more rewarding. You're in a post-apocalyptic world, and all you have is the voice of a Stranger guiding your steps, to build a Bastion where all can be safe, all can be rebuilt, though your enemies won't see it that way. If you take advantage of all the game has to offer, you'll find that your skills have been challenged to the utmost and you are the better for it; and tears may come to your eyes when you make your final choice.

												This review is brought to you by the wonderful Ponxha.Bastion is indeed one of the most captivating games I've played, gameplay-wise and story-wise.The art, the soundtrack, the narration. content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This is one of the indie classics. Shame NOT to play it. It's got great gameplay AND great writing, particularly considering how cool the constant narration of your actions is.If I had any complaint, it would be that Xbox 360 gamepad controls pretty much don't work for me, and the game seems to kind of be made for this style of controls. Keyboard+mouse is fine for gameplay but menus can be a little hard to navigate sometimes.Oh well. It's still an excellent game. Took me a little over 10 hours to do pretty much everything there was in one playthrough, by the way, so if you blitzed through it, the game would probably be like half of that, or even less. But there's New Game Plus (which unlocks some new stuff) and another special mode, not to mention many different challenges and "quests" to complete, so there's plenty to do.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												If you don't want to read you can watch the video review which basically says the same.


YouTube™ Video: James Elgo Reviews - Bastion 

			Views: 376		

			Game time as of this review: 5.5h Hope you enjoyed, if you want to buy this game here is the link: http://store.steampowered.com/app/107100/ Thanks for watching, join my steam group page for more...		

Bastion is a hack n' slash role playing game, however this game has some really interesting aspects that contrast from other games inside the same genre.You play as "The Kid" someone that just woke up in the middle of a catastrophe that neither the player nor the character know anything about, however we can count on the strong presence of the Narrator to enlighten us during our adventure.I want my first point on this review to be exactly about the Narrator, something that really standed out from any game I've ever played. We are used to games which story develops over time with strong interactions between characters, or with the environment however in Bastion, every interaction is very  subtle, and that's where the Narrator comes in, as someone telling and unfolding a story and interacting as much with the main character as with the player himself which is awesome. And the developers really hit gold here, since first of all the voice fits perfectly on the western theme that surrounds the game, and at the same time the voice acting is also amazing, since you can feel every emotion which helps create a certain empathy with this being, and that's something fundamental in this story.Since we're talking about voices and sounds let's jump to the soundtrack, which after the Narrator is the best aspect of the game, since it manages to develop and transform according to the story which is phenomenal. You'll understand what i mean since it's quite rare to hear a soundtrack which contain tracks with lyrics, and even though I think that including something like that is risky since it could break the atmosphere of the game, it does exactly the opposite and traps you even more on this brilliant story.Now onto the gameplay, this is up to you to decide if it is a good thing or not according to your standards but to me it felt like the combat and exploration is something secondary. Don't get me wrong, the combat is fun and this aspect of the game is very well developed with a big array of weaponry, abilities and upgrades. The developers even managed to make this part of the game more interesting with the fact that all the way to the last part of the game you unlock a new mechanic, however it didn't feel as good as the plot, which was what really kept me going.The visuals are very interesting, the 2D visuals with the isometric camera really fitted into the style, nevertheless some models seemed quite odd, as an example the main character which on some drawings shows up as someone quite slim, when you look at the model you see someone quite bulky which doesn't make much sense. Same goes for Rucks which the model doesn't look that good either.Something that also bugged me was the fact that you're being told a story and all of a sudden the game gives you the option to make a couple decisions on the final stage and to me it felt out of place, I think you should be either given more choices to make or none at all. Although i think I'll play this game again someday I can't justify playing the main storyline for 5 hours again just to make a diferent decision at the end and see an alternate ending, but if I had more choices throughout the game I could justify a second playthrough immediately after the first one.Nonetheless I consider this game to be a master piece, the story is interesting, the length feels just right and the western/badass vibe throughout the game is an amazing experience.+ Great story;+ Fun mechanics;+ Amazing Atmosphere;- Some models are just ugly;- Lack of more decisions.92% cool game!Join my Steam Group page for more reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/jereviews

Posted: August 28, 2011
												An amazingly polished game with a great story, superb visuals, and very satisfying customization options. Great world and characters. The story is told through a narrator as you play. Easy to play with extra options to increase the difficulty for a higher reward. The combat feels a bit lacking, but the game is definitely not a chore to play. Has a new game plus mode with lots of goodies after you beat the game, so there's a high amount of replayability if you're into 100% completion. Took me about 7 hours to beat. Definitely a 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												'Tis a thing of beauty.Bastion is an RPG that harkens back to the days of games like Secret of Mana, choosing an action combat system rather than a turn-based one.  The mechanics of it are quite simple, but satisfying to utilize.  You have two weapon slots and an ability slot, and you can upgrade your weapons as time goes on and you find the materials for it.The story is an interesting one.  Bastion, unlike most modern RPG games, decides to go for minimalism in its storytelling.  Rather than have you sit through a forty minute cutscene that explains things, it tells it to you on the fly through a narrator (who is superbly voiced by the way).  It's an interesting touch that allows you to stay engaged, and the narrator will even make little comments based on your actions.The game starts after a world ending event known as The Calamity.  You play as The KId, a lone adventurer who seeks to restore the world through The Bastion, a place of immense power.  I won't say any more for the sake of spoilers, but I will say that there are a few twists and turns later on.  There are only two major choices you'll have to make in the story, but rest assured you will feel the weight of them.The game also has a fantastic art style, with bright vibrant colors that are pleasing to the eyes.  So if you want a fun, RPG romp with a unique story and fantastic aesthetics, I highly recommend Bastion.  It's a very atmospheric and memorable game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I just finished Bastion and really enjoyed it. Highly recommended!Gameplay: 8/10 -- Pretty standard stuff, i.e. everything you need from an isometric top-view style action-RPG. Not too complicated, not too simple.Visuals: 9/10 -- Really beautiful hand-drawn world, with a genuine "feeling" to it. Animation and cutscenes were also cool. I like how the world "came together" as you walked.Audio: 11/10 -- The music is fantastic and the "Narrator", accompanying you throught *all* the game, is just awesome. Easily the strongest aspect of the game.Story: 7/10 -- The story is OK, but there's too few characters (err, 4 of them!) and only a couple are really "explored". The world the game unveils is interesting, albeit tuned for "all ages" audiences.It took me about 12 hours to finish the game; the difficulty was quite OK, maybe a bit easy. I completed almost everything in the standard story-mode, and I didn't do any of "Game Plus", for the time being.Achievements (both in-game and steam ones) were quite finely tuned to my liking, keeping me reasonably motivated to play and earn more as I went.My sole problems were: (1) my no-name PS3-like USB gamepad wasn't recognised; typical... (2) Isometric top-view has the NE-SW and NW-SE as the two principal axes, so playing with WASD keys [N-S and W-E axes] was a little weird at first; but I quickly adapted.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												One of the best Indie games I've ever played. That is the best example for can be done without being an AAA title.First, the story. The voice of the narrator was the first thing that baffled me. He describes everything (so no character voice), but it's in a unique, very fascinating way.The combat is balanced and well designed. There is no A click, there is more to discover and "learn". If you hit an enemy you really can "feel" it.The graphics are simple but awesome. The are is painted and differs from any other game I've played. There is no 3D super-hyper-cool-AAA-Shader-Textures-Bling-Bling (thank god). Even the graphics were well-thought-out and matches perfectly.The soundtrack was so good, that i just had to buy the soundtrack.With pure conscience I do recommend this game, if you like RPG style games of course :-)

content:
Posted: September 15, 2011
												Bastion is one of the best new games I've played in a long while. I guess technically it is an action-RPG, but not in the traditional sense (for example, it's very short and you only gain 10 levels maximum). But it's not even really the gameplay that is the main attraction anyways (at least not for me) - rather, it's the unique world you get to visit during those few hours. The world is visually beautiful and the soundtrack is amazing, but the main draw that keeps you engaged is the smooth-voiced narrator that tells the story of everything you do as you do it. It's hard to explain the concept properly since it is unprecedented in gaming, so all I can really say is check it out and see for yourself. The game itself is not very hard, so pretty much anyone should be able to finish it (there are also various options more experienced players can enable if they wish to make the game harder). I can't say enough good things about Bastion - it is practically a clinic in game design. Get it!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Bastion is an amazing game, with entertaining gameplay, a unique and beautiful artstyle, and most importantly an intricate, thorough, and moving story. The gameplay and combat is fairly straightforward, but the combinations of two weapons and a single skill can allow for many styles of play, and the lack of straight upgrades adds to this dynamic as well. Additionally, the system of leveling up was unique and further added to the styles of play, and the difficulty of the game scales well, with additional options to offer a greater challenge. Regardless of the engaging gameplay, Bastion excelled in its storytelling. Told through amazing narration, you experience the story of the world of the Bastion. The environment is defined by the artstyle and the soundtrack (which is definitely worth a listen). What stood out most to me concerning the story, however, was its ability to invoke an emotional response from me. As someone who usually plays games for just their gameplay, the whole story (and particularly the conclusion) I was surprised at how much I actually cared about the kid and the characters he meets. Overall, Bastion is definitely worth a purchase. Decent gameplay in an amazing environment with an engaging story made for a great game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												It would be remiss of me to begin this review without divulging that if the devs ever resolve to produce a Bastion: Revisited or likewise, I would jump for joy in my pajamas (and probably even pee a little) before insta-buying the game. My love for the game isn't even as strong as my love for procrastination, but it helped me reminisce about an older strategy game I played with similar mechanics.The plot itself is light and uncomplicated - with two choices towards the end. You play as a squat yet resilient Kid, who can wield weapons taller than himself, and dodge attacks with the agility of a jaguar. Tasked with restoring a brittle, post-apocalyptic world, you help him traverse various picturesque floating isles in search of resources while trying not to fall off ledges at every corner. Only a cockroach would survive a fall like that, not your protagonist.Pros : UI - Being able to move around via mouse while battling via keyboard was more satisfying for my hardwired brain than I can account for. You can also choose between complete keyboard control and gamepad. Besides that, the in-game screen itself isn't cluttered with unnecessary icons, which makes for cleaner gameplay.  Weapons - The assortment of murder tools at your disposal will be enough to make you squee. Moreover, they're colorful and have cool names. My personal favorites were the Spear, the Musket and (later on) the Galleon Mortar. The latter is akin to a pocket cannon, but looks and feels much cooler. The weapon upgrade system is unique too. Every time you unlock an upgrade, you can choose between two characteristics. For example, one upgrade for the Army Cabine (a long range, destructive rifle) offers a choice between activating either Faster Aim Speed or Bonus Damage.  Music - I often say this for other games, but it can be quite a challenge to create a good ambience with music. I wouldn't want hardcore metal blaring in my ears during a battle lest I get squashed by a giant hammer. Thankfully, the BGMs in this game keep you perfectly at ease, and are well paced . There are moments when you can hear Zia (the game's Nightingale) singing; it's the kind of voice I can fall asleep to. Mobs - Some are stationary and can be killed with ease. Some have armored heads, will collide into you with all their might, can only be poked if you stick a spear into their♥♥♥♥♥ and ARE FROGS. *internal zombielike laugh* Some can only be killed if you poke them in the eye enough times. (i.e.) They're pesky but they won't bore you. Cons : Bonus Stages - Each time you discover a new weapon, you can test it out in it's exclusive battle grounds to challenge yourself. The difficulty lies in the fact that most of the challenges require you to do something humanely impossible. Like aiming and shooting a random popping scarecrow in 2 seconds, or clearing a minefield of pin-spitting cushions in (what was it?) 1 minute? Since these add to the very charismatic Achievement system in game, which in turn provides resources for upgrades, I'd like to actually be able to complete them. Instead of having to hire a robot. Shrine - This may be appealing to masochists, but invoking ten or so idols to immortalize the already pestilent mobs is not something I can enjoy. Moreover, there's 8 steam achievements for accomplishing these. I don't mind the Shrine system itself, but be more realistic please... Duration - The game ended too quick.Scores Art - 10/10Music - 8/10Narration - 11/10Plot - 8/10Overall Score - 7/10 (would've given a 9 if I wasn't such an achievement hoe)
