number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												"Bastion" - if it wasn't for my friend, who knows I love good stories and good soundtracks I might have never tried this game. He got me a copy, and I got addicted.In the game, you play as the Kid, who wakes up, and finds his world is literally falling to pieces. The ground shatters beneath him, it's like something is devouring the land like a disease. And that something is called the Calamity. The Kid has to find his way to the Bastion, a place created to gather any survivors in case of a catastrophy. A place that is supposed to save to world. But through his travels the Kid meets other people, finds their stories, and then discovers the horrible truth about the Calamity, and the Bastion itself.It's an action RPG set in a two-dimensional world with an isometric camera. Sounds simple, and boring enough, right? Wrong! The world is beautifully painted, colourful and vivid. There is a vast number of different enemies and environments. You also have a large group of weapons to choose from, and create your own style of fighting. For me, I always prefered the war machete as a melee, scrap musket as ranged, and squirt lure as a special ability. But there is a number of combinations, and everyone will find something fitting. The gameplay is mostly hack&slash, not gonna lie. But the story is just gripping. You do get involved, you do get attached, and at some point, you will be forced to make a decision. And it is not an easy one, it squeezed a tear out of my eye.The soundtrack deserves its own review... From blues bar sounding "Slinger's song", through the sweet notes of "Build that wall", exciting and fun "Terminal march", and the beautiful, heartbreaking "Mother, I'm here", this soundtrack provides about an hour of eargasms... I listened to it for two weeks non stop, after I completed the game, it's that good.Oh, and I forgot the best bit. The whole game is narrated by a deep, warm voice. With a hint of sense of humour, a lot of sarcasm, and plenty of emotions, the narrator, also known as Rucks, creates an atmosphere of a campfire story, being told to anyone who dares to listen.Will you dare?

												Beautiful game, both visually and aurally. The soundtrack is utterly phenomenal, the design is gorgeous, and Logan Cunningham's narration is like something out of a storybook.It's brief, but not too much so. Long enough for me to become rather fond of it, but not so long that it ever felt like it wasn't in motion. None of it felt like a grind. The combat took a bit of getting used to, but the fact that the world you're waltzing about in is so stunning tended to stifle any momentary irritation.

												what a game! i hate to rave about the soundtrack, since so many often do, but it really is something special. one of the first game soundtracks i've ever purchased, and felt good about purchasing. the gameplay catches a lot of crap, and i can see why, but i think that if you experiment with your loadout enough, the game stays fresh. a lot of people just stick with the hammer/repeater, which is good, but can get really boring really fast. only two characters have any real voice work, and it's done absolutely beautifully. the characters and their stories are compelling, and you'll do the same god damn level over and over to learn more about them. the story started off confusing and difficult to get into, but the more you learn, the more interested you become. highly recommend even at full price. get the soundtrack, too.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Bastion is an amazing game, filled with colorful art and a sexy narration that tells the story as you play as oppose to ripping the camera and controls from you so you can watch a 5 minute cut scene. I would love to play another game with this guy as a lead voice. Music for the game is also very good and fitting for this kind of game, somewhat somber at times.The game play is pretty fast pace and excellent, though has it's short falls. One of them is that you are given too many weapons, Unless you plan on experimenting with the weapon load-out, You will usually stick with what works for you. Same with secret skills, which I hardly ever used while playing. Overall, an amazing game that opens up for you the more you play.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Well ladies and gents, it took me almost 5 years but I finally Beat the game with 8 hours on record. With that said I took this game pretty slowly and I still beat it in 8 hours, Just keep that in mind. Let me just start off by saying this game is a work of Art, A Masterpiece. This game honestly shocked me, Before I knew who supergiant was, I went into this game thinking it was just some average indie game with little story. I thought that  you would just be  going from zone to zone grabbing these crystal shards until you finish the crystal. But slowly you start to realize it is not just that, you start to notice it is more complicated than that and encounter new characters and Items. As you get further and further into the game,the story starts getting thicker and thicker. The narrator (Who is absolutely fantastic by the way) Is pretty much telling someone the story of what you are doing in that moment and this mechanic is what helps guide you through some parts that you may not have figured out.As you progress you get these items which you use at the Bastion to upgrade the weapons which adds some variation is play styles.  My only complaint is that the OPTIONAL dream levels took so long and there was no checkpoints so if you died on the last wave you would have to restart and redo the last 20 minutes over again.9/10, excited to move on and play transistor finally!!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Bastion is a super fun, yet challenging game with a pretty art style and a good soundtrack!As to be expected from a Super Giant game, it is very story rich, with a fixed narrative. There is however, some agency you keep, since the narrator is only an NPC and his view can be challenged. But the gameplay isn't just follwoing the plotline-levels, there are the seperate weapon-levels as well where you can gather prizes based on your performance. To me, those were a welcome change and a fun challenge! I also liked that there is the possibilty to manually upgrade and put together your own weapon set. It encourages you to experiment with differnt fighting techniques and combos, which is always nice.All in all, I enjoyed playing Bastion and look forward to replaying it!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Bastion is a truly incredible game.  While not a particularly long one, the depth of it lies in its beauty and story.  It stands out because of the artwork and the narration primarily, but many other aspects hold gamers captivated.  The music is wonderful and the various weapons are highly entertaining.  The narration was one of my personal favorite features.  Many games force you to sit through cut scenes or read massive amounts of text.  But the narration allows you to play without disturbances, and as it is sometimes subject to what you do in the game, it adds a level of humor.  It’s a beautiful game that I’ve played through multiple times (different account) and have yet to grow tired of.  The richness of the world created and the storyline lurking around every corner brings out the unique magic that Bastion holds.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												One of the better soundtracks I've heard in a very long time, along with the Uncharted Series, Ori and the Blind Forest, and Skyrim. Combat is fluid, the levels are well designed, and let us not forget that guy narrating your every move. He's awesome.I will also mention that this is one of the more beautiful games I've played in a long time, reminding me a lot of said Ori and the Blind Forest. It's bright, it's dynamic, and the colors always go with the levels flawlessly.And this is all coming from less than an hour of gameplay.I'll probably re-write this review later on, when I have more time in the game, but I have an inkling this will end up being one of the better games I've played in recent days, if not my life.So, far, my first impression is %100 positive. Can't wait to see more of it.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												+ Beautiful soundtrack+ Great atmosphere+ Unique and fitting narrative+ Customizable weapon/skillset allows for individual playstyle+ Satisfying gameplay"Bastion" distinguishes itself with its unique and immersive narrative. The soundtrack is powerfull and helps building the atmosphere; creating excitement and suspense for its fun, action-packed gameplay - and hits you right in the feels when the story asks for it. Posted: June 2, 2014
												A truly great game, unlike anything I've played before. An original and beautiful art style, captivating storyline with a stunning backstory, and satisfying the whole way through. Progressing through the game, you find yourself being able to customize your character's unlockables to fit your playstyle and what you do best with, and the choice to upgrade what you want, when you want is great. If you pay attention to the lore that the amazing narration fills in for you, you'll be wholly immersed. I just finished my first playthrough, and I know for a fact I'll enjoy replaying it with special rules and boundaries, finding new things I didn't catch the first time.TL,DR: Buy this game! You won't regret it. (I swear on me nan!)

Posted: June 11, 2014
												This game is great. I was immediately surprised by how easy it is to play with multiple combinations of weapons and skills, especially since each weapon is rather well balanced, and it is both possible and feasible to use any combination you can imagine, except perhaps in the case of weapon-specific skills. Also, the dynamic narration and music (also dynamic!) really help with the atmosphere, and the decisions you make actually have consequences. This is a fine example of a game where YOU get to choose how you will play. Will you bring a pair of ranged weapons? Or will you go full melee? Maybe you prefer a ranged weapon and a melee weapon. This game lets you play with any combination! The roll ability especially adds to the gameplay, allowing you to gain distance for a ranged strike, or move in for a quick melee attack. It has been a while since I played a game this dynamic and fluid, and I happily recommend it to anyone reading this.

												I would totally recommend this game!It has become one of my favorite games. It's very addictive and has fun bonus levels (pretty much a horde mode with 10 waves, that are pretty hard). You have different choices of weapons that you unlock throughout the game, everyone will have their own weapon that they like to play with. If you like adventure games, I would recommend it.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Surprisingly good and lovely game. It has a nice and intriguing story and cowboy-like songs and narrative that mixes very well with the intended atmosphere. I love the narrator's voiceover, btw. The game itself is easy and fast paced. You have to clear levels and, one after one, the story advances in the "city" (Bastion), revealling more details of future and past. You gain abilities and new weapons and customizations each level aswell. You can carry two weapons and one power at the same time, but can shift between all your unlocked weapons anytime at the arsenal buildings.On the last part, you have to make a choice (no spoilers) which leads you to one of the two avaiable endings. I recommend this game for pretty much everyone, specially those looking for a light story with soft gameplay elements and not so time/commitment requiring. I also recommend this game to children of 7+ yo; not because this game is silly or childish, but because there is no gore or explicit violence and kids could find the colorful themes and animations quite entertaining. At last, there's something on the moral of the story that parents could find inspiring and teaching aswell.

Posted: June 3, 2012
												Oh my god. What a great game! The game's mechanics work really well, kinda plays like an Actionzelda (Perspective, controls, weapons). The grafics are well suited and very diverse.And in regards to music...just perfect! The adaptive narrator is something I'd like to have in every game. This is the best way of storytelling I have ever experienced.The story is also very neat and often touching. The final choice one has to make was the toughest of my gaming career I think...especially since it doesn't have this right-wrong, good-evil feel to it, but I'm not gonna spoil any more here!I finished the game the first time half an hour ago and I'm still emotionally involved.Now not much more to say, except: Play this game!Together with World of Goo, Limbo and Super Meat Boy this is the most epic piece of Indiegaming!

Posted: May 3, 2014
												This is a difficult game for me to recommend. I'd heard wonderful things about it, and when I finally tried it I was immediately pulled in by the narrator's voice. The story is very engaging, the characters are intriguing with interesting backstories and figuring out the (beautiful!) world is a pleasure. All the things that I love in a RPG.But boy, is this game hard. Ignore the "action" part of "action RPG" at your own peril. Thankfully there's a wimpy mode that lets you come back to life as many times as necessary, but I struggled nearly every step of the way. I could barely comprehend it when I found a building that lets you _increase_ the difficulty in all sorts of insane ways. Learning about a character's background is done by cutting off the story into little pieces intersected by really tough fights.If you love playing games mainly for their story, brace yourself and make sure you understand what you're getting yourself into!

Posted: July 7, 2014
												General Overview: A short but very captivating game with addictive game play, unique setting and wonderful story telling. The game is deceptively simple yet captivating with a great balance of narration and action, very well paced and simply a joy to play and strong reasons to experience the game again.TL;DNR: 9: Great original concept and wonderful execution and although short is rewarding and addictive to play with substantial replay value to experience the "other" side of the story. My only complaint is the length of the story but is also great as an arcade style game in the side area proving grounds.Technology/engine: 7: Very simple, clean and functional. The unfolding of the environment keeps it light weight but also provides and element of exploration value despite linear story telling.AI: 8: a bit repetitive but challenging with frequent pace changes of actions and many new situations and variety of enemies to encounter.Graphics: 9: Simple, attractive and unique art style that is endearing and captivating and creates a unique immersion into the unique setting.Sound: 9: Very unique sound and good distance to source recognition that creates ambiance without being overwhelming and only plays into the soundtrack.Soundtrack: 10: Excellent music selection that is very fitting for the title.Voice acting: 10: The narration is fantastic and the simple device of a single talented story teller really works well here.Crafting: N/A - more customization than crafting.Customization: 10: You can customize the weapons to your preferred play style and it really makes a difference.Game play systems: 10: Great action game play with lots of movement and simple controls that keep it fun and fast paced. Its hard to describe how such a simple combination of mechanics can make a game so fun and addictive.Controls: 8: Very simple and streamlined with full reprogramming.Story: 10: The story is what really shined for me. The narrative is well paced, well delivered and enhances what you do throughout the game with a satisfying but difficult choice at the end.Multiplayer: N/A

Posted: November 22, 2015
												Where to begin...?Never an easy task. As the cryptic narrator with a badass voice that slightly resemblesJames Coburn's gruff bass performance cooked with Tommy Lee Jones' dry wit and with a pinch of Eastwoodness likes to say, "Proper story's supposed to start at the beginning. Ain't so simple with this one." Sounds cryptic enough? So anyway, the name of the game is Bastion, and it is one of the best indie action RPG games to date. The script, the vocal performance(s), the action, the graphics and artistic direction, the beautiful acoustic soundtrack...I could go on and on and on.The story is surprisingly good; it is mysterious, very well told, gripping and emotional. You are a young man, lovingly nicknamed only "The Kid" by the narrator - a tough, laconic and capablewhite haired builder in service of Caelondia, the flying city in a fantastic world. The Calamity (in other words, catastrophe of epic proportions) has struck, leaving only shreds of the entire civilizationthat was once your home. Your friends, neighbours - all gone. Turned to ash statues.You go in search for survivors. Sooner or later, you find some. Some are friendly. Some are not.And then, figure out what happened to the world that was your home, and even more importantly, as abuilder, how do you rebuild it?Your actions are narrated to you; The Kid remains silent throghout the game. There arenot many examples of silent protagonists being a positive thing in video games; let's face it,main reasons for it are usually budget savings on $$$ voice actors and easier scriptwriting. Or lack of creativity. Or all together. Not in this case. You get to be immersed in the role of the Kid, and your actions (even your blunders)are narrated to you by the mentioned narrator. It makes sense through time that the Kid is silent.His Cael hammer does the talking for him. Western trope? You betcha.Gaming is based mostly around hack 'n' slash, your relfexes will be tested. There are numerous weaponsavailable to you, remnants of the old world. Your arsenal includes firerams, too.However, there are numerous special abilites, upgrades for weapons (numerous, you are free to choose), and a huge numberof magical potions that are truly important. You will need a maximum balance to get through some challenges,especially near the end.Soundtrack is mostly acoustic, although intense beyond belief in some parts. My favorite instrumental track is probably "Spike in a Rail". Pure eargasm. There is some banjo, some acoustic guitar, and a little bit of synth tracks.Some tracks resemble FInal Fantasy, while most of them are Western influenced.Graphics are truly gorgeous. Not so many details (again, budget of an indie game $$$), although thisreinstates what I always like to say - one fine day, completely photorealistic Unreal #456tnt engine will be here. And no, it STILL won't be able to replace the softness and attractiveness of hand-painted backgrounds in games. It really serves it's purpose, conisdering you play from isometric (basically top-down 2D) perspective. Every similarty with Final Fantasy Japanese style games is purely coincidential. NOT.The nitpickers would say that because of that, the main character models are not that detailed (with suspiciously large eyes, I might add),but the beautiful background of the world dominates anyway.Some minor snags that I would like to point out are, for example,  difficulty - it gets difficult near the end, and there are some real challanges that await you - although for the first 50% of the game, it is really easy. The lack of difficulty levels to choose from (save for the super easy kids oriented difficulty) is a minus.There are difficulty upgrades available later in the game, in the form of "gods" of the world of Caelondia,but they do not change the overall impression significantly.Also, some levels really do get repetitive after a while - there's only so much you can do with isometric 2D after all.Still, there is a great replay value, because there are several endings to this fine game, and you willdefinitely be intrigued with "what if I had done that at the end...?"Artistically, the game has sooo many influences - ranging from Western movies, up to Japanese visual arts and Greekmythology. Story is in no way simple - not only is it the story about choices, you get acquainted with the whole world of Caleondia that was once here. And it might not have been such a wonderful place all the time...Did I mention the badass narrator? An example of great storytelling and rock solid gaming on an indie budget.Go get it!

Posted: December 7, 2015
Bastion is the debut game from independent developer Supergiant Games, and what a debut.  Bastion is an Action Role-Playing Game with beautiful art-style and music. It has an intriguing and different story narrated to you by a Stranger, which is one of the most recognizable features of the game. The gameplay and character's skills are solid, flexible and fun to mess around with. The game lends itself to at least 2 play-through’s with 2 different endings, but such is not mandatory to understand the story. One run should take you around 11 hours with the extra challenges. It has a Metacritic score of 86 (critics) and a 8.6 (users) . Overall, I really liked and had fun with the game, if you like action games and RPG’s I would recommend this game. I also think this could appeal to bullet hell shooter fans, because it has some elements of it although in a smaller scale.My Score: 9/10

Posted: January 14, 2014
												Bastion is a good game, make no mistake, but it's considerable style outweighs its substance. It's certainly a beautiful game, the hand-drawn art style graphics are very pretty and distinctive, fitting well with the general tone, although they can sometimes get a little busy. There were also times where the isometric viewpoint combined with some strange shapes made the safe pathway a little less than obvious. Visually, it's a treat from beginning to end.The soundtrack, in my opinion, is the Bastion's strongest asset. The score is wonderful, taking old-western guitar twang and mixing it beautifully with other velvety tones that make the soundtrack bundle worth the extra dough. The narration is also great, adding a new and interesting way of framing the story and directing the player with a voice that sounds like molten caramel. The story it frames is also fairly good, if a little bewildering to start with.On the downside, the actual gameplay is fairly homogenous. Most of the game consists of "go to a place, hack and slash until everything is dead, grab a magical something-or-other and flee before the ground disappears from under you" on a repeating cycle.  The variety of weapons and special attacks and the challenges offered by the Shrines (difficulty-boosting optional extras) and other challenges offer a little bit of variety, but I can't see myself making use of the New Game Plus feature. Despite there being two possible endings, I just didn't enjoy the 5 hours I spent with it enough to want to go back any time soon.Overall though, considering I paid quite a lot less than the list price for Bastion, I still got my money's worth and would recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind beauty being mostly skin deep.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Você vê este jogo em promoção, barato, talvez deva comprar. Vê a expressão pensativa do Kid e gosta das letras de "Bastion", e o nome também não lhe parece nada mal. Você olha os reviews, a maioria positivos, vê as imagens e pensa "ahhhhh, é mais um daqueles joguinhos".Minha situação é a do homem que está diante de uma obra de arte coberta, enquanto todos ao redor dele vêem apenas o pano vazio. Como explicar Bastion? Ele difere de vários outros jogos pelo simples fato de ser inteiramente narrado por um homem, mas não é "somente um narrador não-personagem". Ele não só está na história, como faz tudo parecer muito mais profundo sob a voz dele."Now here's a kid whole whole world got all twisted, leaving him stranding on a rock in the sky."Ele acorda, descobre-se sozinho numa ilhota de chão, no meio do céu. Como se tivesse dormido e tudo tivesse desaparecido, menos o chãozinho e o colchão. Mas quando ele anda, as pedras surgem e formam um caminho! Bom, você nada pode fazer senão seguir. O garoto encontra seu fiel martelo, e também alguns seres que antes trabalhavam como operário, mas por algum motivo resolvem te atacar.Para onde ele irá? Para o Bastion. Onde todos devem ir em caso de emergência. Mas ao chegar lá, esperando encontrar as pessoas, ele encontra primeiro um homem. "He finds me", diz o narrador. E então a verdadeira história começa.Bom, tudo parece estar suspenso no céu, então tem claramente alguma coisa errada. Você precisa então juntar Cores espalhados pelos... bom, pelos lugares restantes de Caelondia, porque os Cores têm poder e os mantém no lugar. Ao mesmo tempo você encontra alguns fragmentos, que, primitivamente falando, seriam como a "moeda" do jogo.A jogabilidade é bastante simples. Teclas para se mover, botão esquerdo do mouse pra usar uma arma, botão direito para usar a outra. Barra de espaço para rolar, shift para bloquear, botão do meio do mouse ou Q pra usar habilidade especial. A Calamidade aconteceu, mas você não sabe a causa, e ficará, durante o jogo inteiro, perguntando-se o que é isso. A cada Core reunido, você pode recriar um novo edifício em Bastion. E vamos dizer que reunir os Cores é... Bom, não quero estragar a surpresa.Você tem algumas armas que vai ganhando ao longo do jogo, e pode escolher duas delas pra usar. Cada arma possui cinco upgrades, e cada upgrade possui dois melhoramentos. Você escolhe um melhoramento de cada upgrade, podendo alterar quando desejar. Há poções que conferem efeitos passivos, um Achados-e-Perdidos, um Memorial com missões... E criaturinhas que você encontra, lembrando-se de que nem todos são seus inimigos.É um jogo fácil, pelo menos até você libertar os deuses do Santuário, que conferem mais dificuldade ao mesmo tempo que aumentam o ganho de Experiência. Há também os Proving Grounds, que são desafios específicos para cada arma(e um para o escudo). Alguns chegam a ser moleza, mas a maioria são mesmo desafios, e Bastion é um jogo completo, desafiador, profundo. Há também os "Who Knows Where", que são "desafios" onde o Kid dorme, e o narrador conta uma parte especial sobre determinada personagem.E no final, tudo terminará com uma grande decisão sua.Feito para ser completado duas vezes. Não digo isso porque "O jogo é tão bom que te dá vontade de completar de novo", de jeito nenhum - quando você completá-lo pela primeira vez, entenderá.Usei muitas palavras para meu jogo inde favorito, mas se eu só pudesse usar poucas, elas seriam "Esse jogo possui uma alma".

Posted: March 22, 2014
												First off, this game is amazing, and a must buy.Let me tell you why this is so. This game has a very unique artstyle, and not in a bad way. It's probably one of the best looking games I've had the pleasure to play. The art really gives an atmosphere to the game, which is lacking in most games (In my oppinion). Another thing done to almost perfection, is the music. The music in this game blew me away, it's action-packed when needed and it's a bit.. "toned down" and emotional, when it's needed. This contributes alot to the atomphere of the game aswell.The main focus of the game, and the thing you'll be doing the most, is using various weapons to kill creatures, critters and other living things. The game ALSO does great in this part. The combat is responsive, and does not feel like a "mash-to-win" thing. It also requires an amount of skill to master. This is empathised by the game it self, as it has "Training Grounds" where you can unlock 3 tiers of rewards, depending on how good you do a task, where the third tier is perfecting the task (Which is very difficult). This combat system if what I'd call an "easy to learn, hard to master" kind of thing. The game has around 10 weapons, where around half of them are ranged and the other half melee. You also get a "secret skill" which is like a special move, but you can't use it all the time, it has a resource attached to it which you can hold 3 of. You can upgrade your weapons aswell, It's almost impossible to upgrade them all. That's all I'm going to say on that.Now I think it's time to talk about the story. It's great. I'm not a "story guy" as I apreciate good mechanics instead of a great story. But since this has great mechanics, I started to focus on the story aswell. I'm scared to say anything about it, I'd recomend you to go experience it for yourself. The levels them self don't get boring either. They are kind of being built, as you go along the path. That's the way this game does secrets aswell, which there are a few of. This makes the levels feel very dynamic, as they're kind of built on the spot. So now I'm going to repeat my self... Go buy this game. It's worth the price.

Posted: May 13, 2014
												Bastion is one of my favorite games in recent years. It also might be my #1 Indie game. Although there may not be anything completely original in this title, the way the game is presented feels different from the majority of games I've played. They keep a lot of tried and true mechanics (e.g. upgradable weapons and character, multiple levels categorized by zones, home base where you will upgrade and customize your character, and unlockable arena battles to test your skills) but they've added plenty of charm and character to this title that keep it fresh. The narrator is one of the most memorable parts of the game and you will learn most of the world's lore and story progression via his soothing voice. The controls are very tight and almost perfect. The way you can alter your difficulty with the idols you unlock is also a nice feature that forces you to adjust your fighting technique if you want to face these self-imposed challenges. I finished the game several months ago for the 5th time, but keep reminiscing about the music, weapon loadout and the final, tough-as-nails dream challenge.9.5/10

Posted: June 9, 2014
												I @#$%ING LOVE THIS GAME!!!!! I finally bought it when it was on sale for $2.24, which was a STEAL! That's less than a Starbucks frappucino, guys.Summary: Beautiful music and art but can't zoom in; story not extremely original but well done; floating maps are interesting but easy to fall off of; customizable controls, gameplay styles, and loadouts; minigames and side missions for loot and money; using idols changes play difficulty. ------1) Art. Basically what first drew me into the game. Even though the drawing style is "kiddish" with brightly colored maps and big-headed characters (I think it's easier to animate and stay visible on the map), the art is digitally painted SO beautifully. In fact, I wishlisted this game immediately upon browsing the selection of profile wallpapers available from crafting the steam badge. The isometric map design imposes permanent bird's eye view which cannot be rotated. It's a real shame that the you cannot zoom the camera in and out of maps besides the Bastion, but you get used to it. 2) Music. Amazing soundtrack which greatly enhances the atmosphere of the game and your immersion into its world. When Zia's theme first played, I was taken aback by how perfect the moment was that I stopped walking around and simply listened. 3) Story. Looking back at the concept of the "Calamity," you realized that it's not particularly innovative or original, but it is successful in the way that the backstory is slowly revealed and keeps you wondering for more information. That also opens itself to fitting with the fantasy steampunk theme. At the end, there are choices that you make based on opposing moral values. That said, there are also serious themes in the story which contrast with the bright colors and cute art style. There's death and the loss of loved ones, but the biggest overarching question is whether the ends justify the means: How comfortable are you, The Kid, with sacrificing the lives of others in order to secure your own survival? 3a) Rucks narrates the game while you play as The Kid in a deep voice that's as smooth as BUTTER. He provides much of the backstory to the game and its characters. It's actually helpful sometimes because he alerts you to incoming enemies or a part in the map that will kill you. 3b) So many little quirky details made me smile. Most notably, The Kid always soars through the air and invariably lands on his face. Rucks also says the darndest things. The first time I died, he said something like, "And then The Kid falls to his death. Nah I'm just foolin'." You hear "Kid just rages for a while" if you destroy objects in the beginning. When Rucks tells you about The Kid's tutor: She "taught Kid some good manners. “Never used 'em though."4) Gameplay. You travel between your home, the Bastion, and other areas of the globe via Skyway. Your goal is to collect items to restore the Bastion, but exploration of the map is encouraged in order to get loot, fulfill a particular side mission, collect upgrades for weapons, and domesticate pets for an achievement. On each map, the pathway is built out as you walk near the end of it. Maps are designed to float in the air, which is a blessing and a curse: It's easy to fall off, but you can push enemies into the abyss. 4a) Controls are simple and easily reconfigurable. There is an option to move using keyboard (WASD), mouse (kind of like playing League of Legends), or controller. Controller support is xbox only, but using a 3rd party program on PC to get my PS3 controller recognized as such did the trick. Playing with the analog stick felt more intuitive for me.4b) Fighting style is hack and slash.  You can rambo, defend, camp, hide in a corner and snipe; whatever your play style is. Countering is rewarding in reflecting damage, but not necessary.4d) Various weapons, skills, and alcohols, which give passive bonuses, make for a myriad of loadout combinations. Upgrading weapons is easy if you loot alot, and it also allows for customization because there are two choices on the left and right per tier unlocked.4c) There are different types of side missions. You can go to Proving Grounds, where you use a specific weapon to complete a goal under certain conditions and are rewarded with upgrade materials. Other challenges, which you earn money from completing, are like mini-achievements. Battling waves of enemies in the 3 "Who Knows Where" maps, also known as The Kid's Dream, The Singer's Dream, and The Survivor's Dream, nets you money. (P.S.: I found the context for getting to these Dreams hilarious--The Kid basically gets high in the first one and food comas for the second. P.P.S This is where you learn character backstories.) 4d) Idols can be invoked in order to increase the difficulty of the game since they buff enemies. Each idol invoked adds +5% to experience and money earned.

												This game is kind of like a diablo-style hack and slash, but the game isn't an RPG like diablo is, it's more like an adventure game with some customization elements. Posted: June 29, 2014
												A simple yet deep action game that plays well depending on your choice of controlsUpon first look into this top-down action game I was compelled to report that this was a simple game with simple mechanics, simple game play and a simple story.  Not soon after I completed the first area did I come to the understanding just how much depth was contained within this game despite the simplicity of the mechanics.  Bastion truly is an experience to be had despite its unorthodox art-style, soundtrack and narrative.  Like many games of the indie genre, it is a refreshing break away from the mainstream but still contains the clean and somewhat polished look of many mainstream action titles that holds a place for both casual and competitive gamers.  This title is not without its quirks but contains a wholly unique experience that drives players from area to area.The story of Bastion is one of hope and survival.  Though not being terribly deep, the story is able to propel players from each area to the next.  It is not one given to gamers in a mainstream way.  It comes to players as if they are hearing a story given from the perspective of a  soothing-voiced supporting character.  Though the narrative was told in a story-like fashion, I never felt like it forgot about what was happening on the screen.  It was interactive and reacted to what my character was doing in the various areas. The story tells of the Calamity, a single apocalyptic even that lays waste the land and has released many monsters to impede your progress.  Few people remain and those that you find on your journey join you at the Bastion, a safe haven and the future of your people.  You begin your journey as a boy that has just awoken to find the effects of the Calamity and is being lead by the narrative to the Bastion.  You begin to rebuild the Bastion that will save the world and must traverse many hostile areas to find crystal shards that give the Bastion core power to rebuild.  On your journey you meet just a few characters that add depth to the story.  They merely give information and are not intended to physically aid you in your journey.  They story unfolds into one of treachery and deceit and has you make a few very difficult decisions as you approach the end of the game.  Though initially surface level, the story become one that some players may become emotionally engaged in.  Overall, the story is great and the experience is solid.When it comes to game play in Bastion simplicity is the name of the game.  Everything from the controls to the mechanics scream simplicity.  This is not to be confused with the game being simple however.  There were many instances where I began slapping keys out of frustration on a particularly difficult segment of the game.  The top down action genre has generally been associated with games like old school Grand Theft Auto and Diablo, but Bastion brings a more hack n' slash element to the genre with its various weapons and real time action.  Initially there are just the basic moves such as the primary and secondary weapon actions.  There are simple dodge and defend mechanics as well.  However not far down the path you begin to realize that there are many seemingly trivial elements introduced during the opening area that are absolutely crucial to be successful in the following areas.  I was pleasantly surprised to come to an area where I was to only surpass by timing counter attacks perfectly or practice efficiency with a weapon by only being allowed a certain amount of shots.   Bastion is not without its quirks however.  Having the PC title allowed me to choose whether I wanted to use the keyboard and mouse or a game pad.  I was able to try both as I had an old Xbox360 controller lying around.  After some time and a sideways expression, I came to find that depending on the weapons you chose to utilize on your journey, your choice of input greatly decided the difficulty or simplicity of the game.  I found that using a mouse an keyboard was more difficult because you had to manually aim shots whereas the game pad had a lock-on feature.  I also found that navigating the world of Bastion was much more intuitive with a game pad.  However, the keyboard and mouse offered much greater ease when it came to using weapons that had area of affect damage because I could aim at a group as opposed to an individual enemy.  Overall, the game pad was easier to use on a far greater range of weapons.  In the end, I ended up using both my keyboard and mouse and the game pad.  This I felt was a quirk that could have been resolved by implementing an auto-aim feature on either input device that could be turned on or off on the fly.  The would have prevented the need to sometimes constantly switch input devices.  If a player has the Xbox360 version of the game, they are most definitely limited to using just a game pad as the Xbox360 does not support mouse input.I feel that Bastion is a very unique experience that anyone can enjoy.  It allows users to merely play a decently designed game or get engaged into the story.  It does so many things well that its easy to overlook its input quirks.  It allows for gamers of all skills and gives an engaging 4-6 hour experience.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Ah yes, Bastion. Probably one of the more famous indie games from recent years.Since I don't normally play these type of games often, a good friend of mine always told me to get it whenever it was on sale here on Steam.But I never really thought about buying it really, but a Humble Bundle took care of that.However since then it laid in my Steam library as the kind of game that I would play maybe someday. Which was May this year.And I sincerely enjoyed my playthrough of it.Bastion is a isometric action-game where you play as a boy, titled as the Kid, trying to survive through the Calamity, a catastrophic event that destroyed the City of Caelondia and  most of its surrounding lands.The whole game is narrated by a man named Rucks, who helps the Kid throughout his adventure. Also he knows how to fix the Bastion, that was supposed to save as many citizens of Caelondia as possible.Most of the time in the game you'll be fighting all sorts of wildlife of the world of Bastion with a range of weapons. You start out with a hammer, but along the way you'll find many  more, ranging from repeaters to a machete to a mortar. You can always carry one melee and one ranged weapon and there balanced really well, though you'll may find yourself using only a few depending on your play style.I really enjoyed the game play as enemies are varied and all of them require a certain tactic, making combat against several enemy types really fun and challenging.The game can be quite difficult at times, but manageable. Though there are ways to ramp up the difficulty much higher if you want to.There are also a few role-playing elements in the game, where you can craft upgrades for your weapons or get bonus perks to help you along your way.The hand-painted art-style of Bastion also is quite different to most other games in the genre and it looks quite stunning. Because it doesn't depend on real 3D polygons or geometry, it also means that even years in the future, the game will still look great. And it's colorful, too.When it comes to the soundtrack I can surely recommend the music that was composed for Bastion. All songs that you'll here during the game really add to the ambience of the world and some of them stood really out to me.The only thing I did not like were some performance problems that made the game ran in half-slow-motion most of the time, though only from the game play. It wasn't that annoying as I still enjoyed the game throughout, but it would have been nice to a fully smooth experience. I couldn't find a fix for it online sadly.So TL;DR Bastion is a fun game. If you're looking for a game that looks nice, plays great and provides a solid story then I would say Bastion is what you're looking for. If you're not sure, there's a demo right here on Steam where you'll be able to play a few minutes of the game.I thoroughly enjoyed my play through of Bastion and while I won't be jumping right back into New Game+, I'll be playing it again sometime and I'm sure I'll be enjoying it.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												My first experience of the Kid waking up in Bastion instantly told me that this was going to be one of those games that you don’t forget, something truly special. So let me preface this by saying I will try and make my review as spoiler-free as possible.You wake alone amidst serene chaos, on an island of beautifully painted pieces suspended over a seemingly infinite void. The only accompaniment is the deep, gravelly, and reassuring voice of the Narrator. Moving from your bed, the world begins to form at your feet. Tiles zip up to form a path before you, leading you onwards through a vibrant, colourful environment.At it's core, Bastion is a competent action RPG. You can carry two weapons (each with a unique role, ability and all upgradeable), as well as a shield (which when used at the correct time allows you to deflect) and a special ability. While there is nothing particularly genre-redefining here, it fulfils its function and allows you to dodge and roll through the world slashing and shooting at lot’s of enemies as well as collecting “shards”, fragments of the old world.Not being a huge fan of ARPG’s myself, the real draw of the game for me was the delivery of the story, the atmosphere and the whole mystery surrounding the world. You want to know what happened here. The primary way for you to find out is through the Narrator.The way Bastion utilises the Narrator works phenomenally well. He leads you through the levels, depositing slivers of story as well as beautifully crafted nuggets of feedback of your play style, all in a unique style of speech that you will associate with his long after the credits roll. Decide to smash everything in the room? Expect to hear something along the lines of “Kid just rages for a while”. Your character, the Kid, is a silent protagonist. But this is allows you to focus entirely on the Narrator, whose ability to drop subtle undertones of dismissal or hints at a haunted past is astonishing.Difficulty is handled in an ingenious way as well. Instead of just a straight Easy/Medium/Hard slider, you can choose to make the game more difficult in different ways through a building that I would rather not spoil. Not only does it allow the game to be more tailored to how much you want to be challenged, it does it through a totally natural system that doesn't take you out of the experience.It isn’t without complaints though. The isometric camera angle can cause some frustration when coupled with the inherent limited maneuverability of the WASD keys. If this is getting too much for you, a 360 pad can be used instead. A small complaint, but worth mentioning.The music for the game is also something else. Trust me when I say this, you should get a hold of the soundtrack. The melding of instruments from different cultures and technology creates a sound that fits the game’s theme like a glove. The way it is used in one particular song sent shivers through me.So in summary, while the core of the gameplay is not hugely inspired (though sufficiently refreshed to be enjoyable) and the isometric view and keyboard limitations can be stifling, the game is one that should be celebrated as an achievement in the medium. The story and its implementation through the Narrator, the world in all its desolate beauty and the extraordinary soundtrack all come together. Each element melds to create an audio and visual treat which should not be missed.

Posted: March 10, 2013
												This is one of very few action RPGs with a compelling story and good characters. If compelling stories and good characters are what you're looking for, play it. It's good. It's really good.It's not a stereotypical action RPG either. You start with your character waking up in his bed with all the world except the 10-foot radius around him just gone. When you walk, the world floats up and pieces itself back together in front of you. It's not only a cool visual effect. It's also part of the story's worldbuilding and a metaphor for the main character trying to piece his life back together after a catastrophic event that evidently left the world wiped out.Gameplay-wise, the action is skillful and fast -- much more skillful and much faster than I could handle at higher difficulties (note: difficulty levels are built into the game's lore, so that's pretty cool too). It's also fun and responsive, though the isometric perspective combined with the colorful levels and masses of objects and enemies alike moving around the screen at once, it can get confusing. It's never so confusing that it becomes unplayable, though. It just starts to feel a little like a bullet-hell shooter at times, and it's not even a shooter.The music's not getting out of here without a mention. I got the soundtrack in one of the Humble Bundles, and I've listened to it far more than any other video game soundtrack (except perhaps Metal Gear). It has an electro-western feel to it that's a bit difficult to describe. The lead acoustic guitar is tuned down to something odd that I tried out on my own guitar (note: just a simple open strum sounds cool in the tuning Bastion's music uses). There are vocals in a few of the songs, and they all come in at exactly the right time for the meaning of the song and the context in which they're played to punch you right in the feels. Sometimes, the music fits so well (mostly the instrumental stuff) that I didn't even realize it was there. It's incredibly unique for a game in the fantasy genre, and the same could be said of all the game's design, from art to writing to music and even to gameplay to an extent.Each weapon feels different and serves a different playstyle, which is more than can be said for nearly any other game in Bastion's genre. The Cael hammer, the default weapon and the one I used throughout nearly the whole game, feels like it has weight and power packed in every swing. The sword is quick and slicey, the guns are suitably punchy, and the bow is precise enough to feel great.If you thought Diablo was the king of the action RPG genre (any of the three), I request you try Bastion. At least in my opinion, it completely demolishes all three Diablo games in every area on which it contends (Bastion has no loot system, so there's no contest there): story, characters, art style, music, worldbuilding, combat, and probably a few I missed.Play Bastion. You'll be doing yourself a favor.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												You are greeted by the gruff voice of a stranger. A voice that will be your guide, your mind and your comfort for the next six hours. You play the character of an unnamed Kid, who's job is to protect himself and other survivors from the aftermath of a calamity, and make ends meet on The Bastion: your safe haven. To do this you have to collect cores from the various locations around The Bastion and return them.During gameplay you look down upon The Kid and fend off enemies' attacks. You can improve your weapons back at The Bastion and the narrator will comment on your progress.The voice of the narrator and the soundtrack are the two things that bring the game from fun to brilliant. “Windbags ain’t much different than normal folks,” the narrator says as you crush one of the game’s enemies with your hammer. “All they want is a place to stay and a decent meal.” This makes smashing them that much harder. As for the soundtrack, it suits the mood perfectly; the whole experience drips with passionate artistry. If you are thinking of buying this game, you have no idea what you are getting into. You will come to know of the beauty of Bastion, but you shall never understand it.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												I absolutely cannot recommend this game enough.From the simple-on-the-surface gameplay that is ultimately packed with variety, to the beautiful, oil painting-like landscape that materializes before you as you play.From the stellar and emotional voice acting performance by Logan Cunningham and company, to the incredible fusion of fantasy and frontier that is Darren Korb's soundtrack.From the incredible story that reveals itself to you as you play, to the equally fantastic presentation thereof.There are just not enough words for this game. It is a true indie gem that I cannot convey my appretiation for to a satisfactory degree. All I can say is, I wholeheartedly recommend this, and hope that you will enjoy the outstanding journey Supergiant Games created.

Posted: August 11, 2012
												Bastion is an action adventure game with a few RPG elements. The gameplay is dynamic, and very entertaining; art style is cartoonish, colorful, haflfway anime but not overdone. OST is one of the best I've heard and it's perfectly used through the game fitting each moment's pace completely. These things would already make the game outstand, yet it's major strenght is story and narrative. You can easily immerse into the story by hearing the narrator as you advance through the game, story unfolds with each step you take. It has only a few or no drawbacks, the only I can think of is it's relatively short duration (6-7 hrs) and that the ending didn't wrap everything up as I would like.Final veredict: Brillant 9,3/10. Totally recommended.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Bastion is a Fantastic game and i enjoyed every single second of it! The game has great music and graphics. An interesting narrator that comments on your actions / decisions. And it also has a "Campaign+" Mode, Where you play the game over again with all of the stuff you got on your first playthrough. Its however a fairly short game that is not very challenging. However you can up the challenge by adding "Idols" Which makes the monsters harder to defeat, such as they attack faster, Take more damage on you, drop grenades once killed, Can't be shot with guns etc. This makes the game much harder.It's a fun little title which you'll beat in a few hours. I've read that some people have played it for more than 60Hours. I myself haven't come back to it yet but now im thinking about playing it once more as it was so fantastic!  The music and narrator of the game makes it a memorable experience that you most likely won't forget too easily :)

Posted: January 15, 2015
												A beautifuly crafted game, Bastion is one of the few games that can boast a colorful post-apocalypse enviroment, a relatable silent protagonist, and a rich lore that doesn't place too much detail on the uninteresting aspects of it. With gameplay that can be scaled up or down with an array of "idols", and enough-but-not-too-much weapon choice. The overall gameplay is solid and enjoyable with fights changing from one area to another without any clunkiness.Story-wise: the game gives itself enough room to create a universe without said universe creating plotholes. The Whole game is told from the perspective of the game's narrator who adds context to the kid's (your) actions without taking anything away. TL;DR: The game is all about story combined with balanced gameplay.

Posted: November 6, 2011
												The Kid did good. First he heard rumors about just how awesome Bastion was during its Xbox live run. Then it came to steam and he played the Demo. Wielding two weapons at once, he plowed his way though the first level of an entertaining hack-n-slash game where he heard me, the narrator, narrate his every action for sometimes humorous effect as the plot unfolds. Purchasing it during a Steam Sale, he continued onward past the demo level where he found the world map filled with challenge levels and missions as he collected the cores and shards to rebuild Bastion. He just couldn't get enough of it.The Kid was impressed, and so was I. Even after he completed the story, I was pleasantly surprised at how even NewGame+ was worked into the game even if I found the act of making choices near the end rather arbitrary. A shame that the Kid didn't know how to strongly recommend the game. On a part that he's that strong silent type. But that's okay. As I can do it for him.Strongly Recommended!

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Cool levels, and there's good variation in their artwork themes, but they are very linear. I liked the enemies a lot, there are a load of different enemies with unique and funny designs, and cool and varied attacks. A con about the combat is that you have no choice in how to engage an enemy by choosing different paths to different situations, but there is in the weapon choice. There's a big amount of weapons, and they are varied, but I feel like they just got stronger the further in the game, so that there's really not much reason to pick a bow over carbine. Lastly, the sound-effects were varied and the voice-acting and the soundtrack was absolutely stunning. The creative story-telling with an omniscient narrator and the sounds and voices truly elevate this game above mediocrity.8/10

Posted: November 10, 2014
												I just completed this game and other than that familiar sense of accomplishment I'm delighted with the experience.The game caught me since the first 2 minutes with a narrative that makes you look around wherever you are playing and ask "are they talking to me?"The visuals are outstanding, fluent and vibrant. I fell a few times at the beginning (and accross the game I must confess) because I was distracted with all the details. Eventhou you can get used to the fight mechanics, the game puts a few surprises specially with the very last weapon.This is not a game to be creative regarding decisions and follow your own path but is flexible regarding how you walk that path now and then.After completing it I will give it a second try since lets you decide the way that you want to make the game more difficult (enemies with more endurance or speed, resources limitation, etc) and I can just imagine the pain that will be with all the challenges enabled.I give it a 9/10

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Bastion is one of those indy titles that took the dedicated gaming community by storm, but it deserved to be so much more. Thinking back on the more than 30 hours I sunk into the campaign and challenges of this game, I can't come up with a single fault. The art style is beautiful, the combat is simple but robust and at the more difficult stages becomes shockingly deep. The story is very well written and concieved; but dear god the narration. The narration in this game is a thing of absolute beauty. And if for no other reason, everyone should play through this game just to see how powerful well designed narration can be.Buy this game and play it all the way through, you won't be disappointed.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												While on it’s surface the game looks like a pretty simple beat-em up game the gameplay is actually a lot funner than that. There’s tons of customization that allows a lot of different play styles and the ability to easily switch between them makes sure that the combat never gets boring. But where this game really shines is in it’s narration and storytelling. The narrator of this game is really ♥♥♥♥ing good and the nonlinear narration adds a really cool element of personability to the game. But out of all of that I think that story is really the best part of the game. It’s mature but not in an edgy way and really speaks a lot about everyday life and learning to move on rather than live in the past. The only bad thing I can say about this game is that it’s a little short. I was able to beat it in one sitting, ~5 hours for a full playthrough, and for some people that might not be worth $15 but the game does seem replayable.

Posted: July 14, 2016
												Really fun adventure game that follows a boy through a devastated land where he needs to explore and fight while trying to save what's left.+ Cool isometric perspective gameplay.+ Responsive and accurate controls (I personally would recommend using a gamepad).+ Wide variety of weapons, perks and upgrades that totally change the way you play and fight.+ Excellent voice acting that helps driving a pretty good storyline.+ Beautiful environments, characters and enemies.+ Really nice replay value, since you can keep your upgraded weapons and face the story and new challenges with them.+ Godlike soundtrack (like, seriously, buy it if you can).

Posted: January 18, 2016
												Bastion is a charming little game that easily captures your heart as you battle your way through the ravaged world of Caelondia in order to rebuild the Bastion.  As you find shards that restore pieces of the Bastion you will be able to build various buildings that assist you in customizing your character and the way you play the game.  And it's this customization that makes Bastion a novelty to play, offering a unique experience many other isometric action RPG's fail to deliver.The first thing you'll notice about Bastion is it's stylized hand drawn environments which piece themselves together as you move through the level giving it a personality uniquely its own.  This is further reinforced by the marvellous voice acting of the 'Stranger' as he narrates your progress through the game world making it feel as if you were sitting by a warm camp fire as your Grandpa tells a story of dreams and fantasy.Without much delay though you’re smashing your way through environments and enemies alike.  The combat in Bastion is smooth and intuitive enabling you to smash, block and shoot your way around waves of diverse enemies achieving some pretty giddy feats of accomplishment narrowly avoiding that gasbags sliding strike.  The only annoying instance I occasionally had was with blocking the wrong targets even though I was aiming elsewhere, but this generally only happened in 'Dream' dungeons.  After clearing an area a shard can be placed in the Bastion enabling a building or upgrade to be built.  These building's really make Bastion a great experience as they provide weapon upgrades to suit different playstyles, shrines which allow the player to tailor their own difficulty curve and in-game achievements to earn more creds to upgrade those weapons faster.  There are other buildings but they provide bonuses we're typically used to seeing in games like a 'buffs' building for example.  Depending on what shrines you use and how far you delve into the 'Dream' and 'Proving Ground' areas will generate approximately 5-7 hours’ worth of game time on a single run.  But with various other weapon combo's to try and new shrines unlocked this game can easily retain you for a further 2-3 run throughs especially with the fantastic narration this game has.  So in summary, Bastion is a wonderful story set in a beautifully unique world that offers immersive gameplay that can be tailored to suit your desired skill level as you play.  With a minimum 5 hours of content you won't be disappointed by buying this game.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Just know, I have out time into this offline, on my X-Box, and PS3! I have alot more experiance then the time it says I have put in.     Bastion is a game of story. The game is a almost 3D-isometric-ish hack and slash. There are alot of wepons, abilities, sidequests, options, and so much more. The controls are sweet too!   You wake up as a character called "The Kid"( as most characters are only referred to as The ????). After making your way throught the first level you learn a little about the story through The Narrarator. The world is expanded upon much more the there are a even a few tear jerking moments in there You can find several relics to give to people you will start pooling to the hub to learn more about the lore of The KId and the mythical world of his.   There are many wepons and abilities, as I have said. All wepons are found throughout the story along with some abilites. No wepons are missable. Stores in the hub(we'll get to that) can sell permant equipments(Spirits) and upgrades for your kicking wepons(assuming you have obtained the ingredients).   The game is traversed through the hub, the Bastion. The skyways(teleporters) can shoot you to missions or extra stages. Most of the time the game gives you several levels to choose from, although you have to complete them all, just in any order.  In the earlier mentioned extra stages you can play challenges based on one wepon. You can win money, a upgrade ingredient and a specilzed ability for that wepon.  Completing the story will allow you to upgrade the hub with stores. These range from the shrine for sidequests, to the Lost and Found to buy missed ingrediants and relics(even though you can backtrack), along with some uniqe spirits and abilites.  The story (and action) is complimented by  the awesome soundtrack, it can pump you up, get you down,♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, anything!If you didn't get the message, buy this game!

Posted: February 17, 2014
												At first glance, Bastion boasts amazing art style. The gameplay looks somewhat interesting, and you might consider this game for your Steam Wishlist.     But then, once you have the game, Bastion assults your ears with an unforgettable soundtrack! Upon playing the first 5 minuets of the game, you hear a narrator giving a story monolouge to every action you take! Not only that, but the narrator has a voice in league with the Great Morgan Freeman!     The game's audio and video quality match those of many indie greats such as Braid or the Borderlands series. The storyline to back this game reveals itself like the ground coming up around you; the more you explore, the more you discover!  By the time I Reached the end credits of this game, I was crying tears of sheer amazment and awe at the beauty of the world in which these events take place. And if that were not enough to draw you in, When you finish the game, you can relive every moment you loved with the New Game+ feature.     All around, Bastion is part interactive storybook, part RPG action adventure with dozens of Steam achievments and challenge areas that will have you playing this game over and over again. 10 out of 10 In my humble opinion. Adventure, beauty, action, costumizable weapons, secret skills, and a soundtrack that leaves you speachless. Not to mention a golden-voiced narrator, all of these await you in Bastion.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Should you play Bastion if you haven't done it yet? In one word : YES. Gameplay-wise the game is very well done. You collect weapons, spirits, level up, upgrade you weapons, etc. The difficulty level is adjustable by use of idols : you practically invoke the gods who in return make your life harder :) . To be honest, i played the game 3 times using the idols just to get more achievements. It's a blast! To make it short, the gameplay is engaging and challenging at times. Now the best part of Bastion : it's music and graphics. About the music there is nothing to say except that it's gorgeous. You'll definetly download the soundtrack and integrate it in your playlist. The narrator does a fantastic job at depicting the story and describing your every action. The narrator is no more that person who talks only between mission. If you break a vase, he tells you that, if you defeat a boss, he's certainly got something up his sleeve to say. And all this happenes without becoming too annoying.The graphics are astounding despite the fact they are 2d (or at least the background is). In fact, this has an even more powerful impact on your perception than a game who has 3d graphics. Every detail in the game is finely drawn and you'll feel the urge to explore every nook and cranny just to see the vistas.So, what are you doing here reading ? Go buy the game!9/10

Posted: December 24, 2012
												Bastion is what I consider the ultimate example of pacing in a videogame. The game hits you hard with major challenges early on, and steadily ramps up the difficulty while also providing a lot of new weapons and concepts to the player steadily. What's more, the game never keeps you pinned down in one spot for too long. There's always some new interesting weapon combo to try out, and new challenges to try them out on. The narrator and story presentation tie into this perfectly, keeping the storyline moving at a good stint along with the rest of the game. Bastion isn't a very long game, but it's a very dense experience - there's a lot to take in during that short time period, on all levels.

Posted: February 24
												7/10 - Charming game, fun combat, rewarding upgrade system, an interesting story and setting, and of course the narration really makes it shine. Not much to say that hasn't already been said. Goes on maybe a bit longer than I'd have liked, and there were a few points here and there that felt either unfairly difficult (some of the challenge arenas basically requiring absolute perfect economy of movement/action) or far easier than the plot would have suggested (most of the major encounters towards the end of the game felt rather inconsequential despite the increasing significance). Still, a great game nonetheless.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Ah yes, Bastion. Probably one of the more famous indie games from recent years.Since I don't normally play these type of games often, a good friend of mine always told me to get it whenever it was on sale here on Steam.But I never really thought about buying it really, but a Humble Bundle took care of that.However since then it laid in my Steam library as the kind of game that I would play maybe someday. Which was May this year.And I sincerely enjoyed my playthrough of it.Bastion is a isometric action-game where you play as a boy, titled as the Kid, trying to survive through the Calamity, a catastrophic event that destroyed the City of Caelondia and  most of its surrounding lands.The whole game is narrated by a man named Rucks, who helps the Kid throughout his adventure. Also he knows how to fix the Bastion, that was supposed to save as many citizens of Caelondia as possible.Most of the time in the game you'll be fighting all sorts of wildlife of the world of Bastion with a range of weapons. You start out with a hammer, but along the way you'll find many  more, ranging from repeaters to a machete to a mortar. You can always carry one melee and one ranged weapon and there balanced really well, though you'll may find yourself using only a few depending on your play style.I really enjoyed the game play as enemies are varied and all of them require a certain tactic, making combat against several enemy types really fun and challenging.The game can be quite difficult at times, but manageable. Though there are ways to ramp up the difficulty much higher if you want to.There are also a few role-playing elements in the game, where you can craft upgrades for your weapons or get bonus perks to help you along your way.The hand-painted art-style of Bastion also is quite different to most other games in the genre and it looks quite stunning. Because it doesn't depend on real 3D polygons or geometry, it also means that even years in the future, the game will still look great. And it's colorful, too.When it comes to the soundtrack I can surely recommend the music that was composed for Bastion. All songs that you'll here during the game really add to the ambience of the world and some of them stood really out to me.The only thing I did not like were some performance problems that made the game ran in half-slow-motion most of the time, though only from the game play. It wasn't that annoying as I still enjoyed the game throughout, but it would have been nice to a fully smooth experience. I couldn't find a fix for it online sadly.So TL;DR Bastion is a fun game. If you're looking for a game that looks nice, plays great and provides a solid story then I would say Bastion is what you're looking for. If you're not sure, there's a demo right here on Steam where you'll be able to play a few minutes of the game.I thoroughly enjoyed my play through of Bastion and while I won't be jumping right back into New Game+, I'll be playing it again sometime and I'm sure I'll be enjoying it.

												*whistles a catchy tune from Bastion*It could be any one of the beautiful songs from the soundtrack. ONE of them will stick in your head when you play this. If you're unlucky, more than one song will stick AND YOU WILL LOVE EVERY MINUTE OF IT....and if you thought the music was catchy, the gameplay and graphics will leave you wanting more. And if you play for the stories... well, you're going to love it. The combat can be adjusted so anybody can play it happily.You want to play for the story? Normal mode with all shrines invoked will cause your character to die every few minutes unless you're a pro. (Don't say I didn't warn you!)The graphics are cute, but never overly so. STORY, GRAPHICS, SOUNDTRACK, GAMEPLAY, OR THE WHOLE THING. YOU WILL LOVE IT FOR SOMETHING.

Posted: March 1, 2013
												Bastion's art-style looks really great and adds a lot to the feel of the game. The story is mostly shown to the player through the gameplay and environment rather than told in dialogue or text. This makes the story seem more interesting than it perhaps actually is. My favourite feature of Bastion is that as you make your way through the world, the story and landscape are described by a man who has the voice of an old, western heavy smoker. This constant commentary, whilst mostly ineffectual, really adds a lot to the game and makes discovering each new area and enemy that much more enjoyable. The combat is fairly basic and very similar to other isometric hack & slashers and the game can be finished in just a few hours but I think that if it were longer it might out-stay it's welcome. Bastion is a great game and often appears in the steam sales so it is definitely worth picking up.

You wake up as a character called "The Kid"( as most characters are only referred to as The ????). After making your way throught the first level you learn a little about the story through The Narrarator. The world is expanded upon much more the there are a even a few tear jerking moments in there You can find several relics to give to people you will start pooling to the hub to learn more about the lore of The KId and the mythical world of his.   There are many wepons and abilities, as I have said. All wepons are found throughout the story along with some abilites. No wepons are missable. Stores in the hub(we'll get to that) can sell permant equipments(Spirits) and upgrades for your kicking wepons(assuming you have obtained the ingredients).   The game is traversed through the hub, the Bastion. The skyways(teleporters) can shoot you to missions or extra stages. Most of the time the game gives you several levels to choose from, although you have to complete them all, just in any order.  In the earlier mentioned extra stages you can play challenges based on one wepon. You can win money, a upgrade ingredient and a specilzed ability for that wepon.  Completing the story will allow you to upgrade the hub with stores. These range from the shrine for sidequests, to the Lost and Found to buy missed ingrediants and relics(even though you can backtrack), along with some uniqe spirits and abilites.  The story (and action) is complimented by  the awesome soundtrack, it can pump you up, get you down,♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, anything!If you didn't get the message, buy this game!

Posted: July 6, 2015
												Bastion is simply one of the top 3 games I have ever played. Everything about it - aesthetics, soundtrack, storyline, gameplay... everything Bastion offered, I loved.As an adventure/beat'em up game, with RPG elements, I think Bastion poses itself in a comfortable spot where there isn't that much mechanical complexity so character creation/enhancement becomes dull nor the core game becomes so simple that things get repetitive quickly. Instead, gameplay is always evolving (mostly due to enemies and weapons), and from time to time you start to re-evaluate your combat strategies. This is particularly true if the player follows a completionist route, in which this kind of strategic evaluation applies even on the proving grounds.Story is really emotional and satisfying - the Stranger's narration does a great job (along with the soundtrack) at bringing a great immersive experience, in which I often pictured myself as an avid listener to a story that I was actually helping to write. These feelings, among with soundtrack fluctuations and the ongoing plot, amplified most of the experience for me, to a point where all the themes the game approaches - loneliness, hope, fear of uncertainty, etc - were instantly relatable to my personal life experiences.(MAJOR SPOILER)To the point that, upon completing the game for the first time and choosing Restoration, realizing that the "bad ending" was what I've always been inclined to do - unable to overcome my fears and regrets, and always willing to get back in time to correct my wrongdoings. The powerful message that the game brings is that - no matter what - there's always hope in moving forward, and the fear of the unknown and regrets often sets true progress back. As someone who constantly regrets most of my decisions in life, this message struck me in such a powerful way that I can't help but consider this game as a much more powerful life lesson than all the self-help crap I've ever read, or all the good advice I've received through these years to no use.(/SPOILER)Ahem.So, either way, this game is a masterpiece. There's absolutely nothing I'd ever change or improve in it, as each part of it enhances the experience of playing it, and reaches for the player in meaningful ways.
