Posted: March 2, 2015
												I couldn’t have been happier to kick off the new series of reviews with Bastion which is one of my most favorite games and has one of the best stories in the industry. Let’s have at it.I – Story [10/10]Bastion is an action RPG from the amazingly talented Supergiant Games. The player assumes the role of the Kid. The story begins in the aftermath of the Calamity, a cataclysmic event that almost entirely destroyed the city of Caelondia as well as much of the surrounding world, leaving it in fractured, floating pieces. The Kid makes his way to the Bastion, a location the Caels were supposed to meet at in case of an emergency. However, the only survivor the Kid meets is Rucks, a mysterious old man and the narrator of the game’s events. Rucks informs the Kid that he needs to collect Cores (large crystals that used to power the city) from around Caelondia and that the Bastion has the ability to use the Cores to rebuild.During his journey, the Kid meets two other survivors; Zulf and Zia. Zulf was an ambassador from the Ura people, a one time enemy of the Caels. Zia is an Ura girl who was born and raised in Caelondia. The Kid leads them both to the Bastion and, upon discovering a research notebook written in the native tongue of the Ura, the Kid enlists their help in translating it. Rucks and Zia are unable to read it, so the Kid falls back on Zulf to do the translating. In the meantime, the Kid goes in search of the final Core that they need.Upon his return however, the Kid finds Zulf gone. Rucks explains that when Zulf had finished translating the notebook, he snapped and wreaked significant damage upon the Bastion. Apparently the notebook (which had belonged to Zia’s father, Venn) detailed the Mancer’s (a group of Cael scientists) efforts to create a weapon with which they could destroy the Ura and prevent any further wars. However, Venn had rigged the weapon to backfire, so, when the Mancers finally made him pull the trigger, the weapon destroyed Caelondia as well.In order to repair the damage done to the Bastion by Zulf, the Kid takes to the Wilds in search of Shards (smaller versions of the Cores). As the Kid acquires one of the final shards, the Ura attack the Bastion, kidnapping Zia in the process. This event takes the Kid deep into Ura territory in search of both the final shard and Zia. When the Kid finally breaks through the Ura outpost, he finds Zia, but the Shard slips through his fingers.In the final missions of the game, the Kid sets off into the once-underground Ura homeland to confront Zulf and retrieve the final Shard. Inside the homeland, the Kid finds Zulf being attacked by his countrymen and he is faced with a choice: he can drop his weapon and carry Zulf back to the Bastion with him or he can leave Zulf to his fate and battles his way through the remaining Ura.Back at the Bastion, the Kid is presented with one final choice from Rucks. The Kid can choose to use the Bastion’s power to rewind time to before the Calamity and set things back to the way they were, but there is no guarantee that the Calamity won’t happen again. The Kid can also choose to use the Bastion’s power to initiate the evacuation protocol  and move on to someplace safe with Rucks and Zia (and Zulf if the player chose to save him).Multiple endings, an enchanting fantasy world, an incredible back story revealed through gameplay, and a hands-down amazing story throughout the entire game. Almost every game could stand to learn a thing or two from Bastion.II – UI [9/10]The user interface in Bastion is marvelous. You’ll never struggle to find any critical information, what weapons you have equipped, or what special attack you currently have. The only complaint that I have, at all about Bastion (though I’m somewhat torn about making it) is the lack of a minimap. While a minimap would have made navigation in game areas easier, it probably would have distracted from the overall game immersion.III – Gameplay [10/10]Gameplay in Bastion is fluid and fast-paced, with a fine-tuned combat system and intuitive controls. Attacking and defending are both omnidirectional. While there’s no jumping (at least, not for most of the game), you do have a very nice rolling maneuver at your disposal.IV – Content [10/10]With Bastion being the first ever game from Supergiant Games, I must say there was a very large amount of content. There are more than ten weapons with which you can fill your arsenal, all of which are fully upgradeable. There is a vast array of special attacks and character perks to unlock and discover throughout the course of the game. There are a good amount of missions and bonus missions to keep you occupied with and they are all filled with a wonderful plethora of enemies to slay.V – Visual [10/10]The art of Bastion is, simply put, phenomenal. Everything is hand-painted and unforgettable. It has an art style that is very unique when it comes to gaming and I sincerely hope that we all have the privilege of seeing it more often in future titles.VI – Audio [10/10]Not to be outdone by the artwork department, the soundtrack (and sounds) of Bastion were every bit as good as every other aspect of the game. Even if you don’t end up getting the game, you should do yourself a favor and pick up the soundtrack, because wow. Just wow.VII – Overall [9.8/10]Overall, Bastion is a truly great game and you shouldn’t hesitate to add it to your own library.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Bastion is a strange game best known for it's narrator which is more like a commentator but is done so well that you never get annoyed by him repeating itself.The art is amazing as the ground raises from the bottom of the screen so you can walk on which makes exploring and finding secrets very rewarding. The general appearance of the levels and characters is very well done and thought out. Though I diddnt like the isometric type of view I wasnt punished by falling off the edge with a loss of life, the isometric view gives you the gods eye view which obviously works well with the narrator.The combat got repetitive but it was challenging you are able to block and use melee and ranged weapons. There are multiple weapons and you are able to customize your character even to suit the style you want such as using an arrow and a blunderbuss or 2 different melee weapons, or the 1 melee weapon and 1 ranged weapon. But you will always have a shield in Bastion which does resemble an old shoot em up at times.Bastion has a lot of life with it's replayability, the god shrine is a great idea, letting the enemy get stronger and getting more experience is a great idea. I finished the game and was given the option to play through it again but with all the unlocks available so its a great game for the completionists out there.Though I do believe it is overrated just a bit it obviously gets a lot of attention because of the narrator. Posted: February 24, 2013
												Bastion is one of those games that catches you on the first two minutes of playing. Features lots of perks which, even if we are used to it, the game itself just gives you a well-rounded complete experience, be it you want a challenging game or just a good hearing at the beautiful story of the tribulations your character has to complete. Providing of beautiful, aesthetic and well-done stages where the action takes place, accompanied by astounding and fitting soundtracks for each of them, you will feel an unbelievable harmony throughout all the game. The story, on the other side will captivate you; every finding, every bit of information that will come to fill you in of what happened (and what is happening) on every minute will expand the picture of what you are doing, and the motivation of your character. The variety of weapons and powerups (in form of pretty clever liquor names), as well as techniques and characters, along the freedom of chosing whatever two weapons you desire, will make your gameplay a blast as whatever you feel like sporting any given second; ber it you want to feel like the sharpest bowman, the fastest gunslinger or even a badass guy with a full-automatic repeater, choices are vast. The icing on the cake is the perfect noir-like voice and style narrator that goes with you during the whole experience (If you ever liked Sin City [movie] narration style, you will fall in love with this one), will eliminate every bit of anything you could find repetitive or boring. Bastion, in a few words, is a game to remember.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Where to begin? This game is absolutley beautiful, from the soundtrack, to the different regions/"worlds", the art style, the very vibe it gives off; it is amazing. There is something so mystical and vibrant about the environment that I just can't put my finger on. The Narrator's voice also adds a lot to the game; he is the one who walks you through vivid memories and reflections of the characters in the game, and without hardly any clips or unskippable sequences to accompany it. No other speaking voice besides the Narrator's is used, and I honestly wouldn't have it any other way; his descriptions and story-telling is really all you need, and adds to the feel of the game in a very positive way.The story of the game itself feels fresh, and is very interesting if you can keep up with listening to the Narrator while trying to fight your way through intense enemy sequences, which is my only real gripe. Then again, its best to save time and works more fluidly for him to explain while you are fighting in the area he is explaining. If you want to know the fine details of the story, you really can't afford to zone out for too long, because he describes things in simple sentences (that do the job and do it fantastically), but make it all the more harder to refocus and understand what just happened.The gameplay is very smooth and just works. No complaints there. As you travel through each region, the ground literally places itself piece by piece out in front of you, adding to the beauty and mystical vibe of the game. I love all the different weapons and skills you can equip and upgrade to use in battle; it makes everything more diverse and suitable to your playing style, which is kind of a standard for an RPG, but the game has its unique twist all the same. A drawback is that if you die, you have to start that region/level all over instead of having a checkpoint to teleport to. The enemies are varied, but they seem to have the same themes depending on which part of the game you are in and/or what region/level you are playing. They are not too difficult to defeat, but you can make it more challenging by using Divine Idols which can make enemies more resistant to attacks, hit harder, etc.Overall, this game is simply gorgeous and all-around fantastic, involving some of the best art styles, music, and usage of a Narrator I've ever seen. I would definitley reccomend to anyone who wants a great adventure with a good story.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												Great little Action/Adventure game with some great sound and art direction. The gameplay, while not super inventive, was fun the whole way through. The game constantly gives you upgrades for equipment and new powers keeping the whole game fun and fresh. No two weapons act the same and you can choose what you want to have. The musical score is great, not much more to say about that, seeing as how the main attraction is the narration. The entire game is narated by a character with a voice as godly as Morgan Freeman. His voice doesn't get old. The art direction is stunning. The game just looks great, play it and you will see what an excellent job they have done with it. While the game is only around 4-6 hours long on a first playthrough, the game is designed that you will play it again and again. New Game +, tweaks to the existing gameplay and challenging modes give it solid replay value.I got this game in one of the Humble Indie Bundles, so it was only around $1 for it. Definitely worth that price. Give it a shot!

Posted: December 5, 2012
												Played the game before, never got around to actually finishing till now.  Because of this I must rewrite my review:Bastion is an RPG that stands out from many other RPGs out there.  The path lays themselves down as you walk on them and the game itself is an art.  Fighting system is also not too complex but still offers various options for loadout and passive skills.  If the game is too easy, you can add additional challenges by invoking one (or all) of the ten gods available.  The narrator is one of the game's unique feature as he narrates everything you do - including your dumb mistakes.  But the best part of the game is the story itself.  You start the game knowing nothing about yourself or the world or anyone.  But in time, the story will come together like a puzzle and the ending is definitely worth playing for.  In my opinion, it's one of the best endings I've seen.  It's not a long game - I finished it in 12 hours (and I took my sweet time).TL;DR: PLAY IT!Tip: if you have a controller, use it!  This game is so much better with a controller, in my opinion.

The soundtrack is powerfull and helps building the atmosphere; creating excitement and suspense for its fun, action-packed gameplay - and hits you right in the feels when the story asks for it. Said story is- although not necessarily the focus, as narrative and gameplay happen mostly simultaneously- gripping and delivers its message convincingly.If you haven't bought Bastion yet (which I assume, since you are reading this), you should do so now! Go grab it! It's worth its price and your time! :D

												Amazing. The 'Hack n Slash' tag doesnt suit a game with this much Depth. Most RPGs have different weapons, but more like an upgrade as you progress. But these weapons are purely on what your style is. Ive seen people ace with weapons i didnt even consider. And i feel it hard and unnatural to switch. Beauty in my opinion.Amazing music. Makes you want to buy the soundtrack. Art style was different, but Perfect.Narration is really cool. Never found it too distracting or corny, etc. Not something you see anywhere else.The story and the dynamics too were very complex and especially the ending makes you think. Alltogether, This was the best game i never expected anything from.I did feel this would be better with a controller just for the movement directions, doesnt come in the way of gameplay though.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Talking about the gameplay of this game is probably the easiest part:You have two weapons that you can choose from a pool of up to 12 (or something). New weapons get introduced regularly up to and including the final level. With the left and right mouse buttons you shoot, slash, smash, stab and/or pistol-sling things until they are dead. There are many different things to kill, which keeps up the variety nicely, and being able to dodge-roll like crazy keeps a steady and exciting pace.There are minor gripes (such as the lock-on being a bit imprecise at some points), but nothing even remotely gamebreaking.I may sound dismissive, but this is only because the hack'n'slash gameplay is merely good - compared to a narrative which is absolutely excellent.Bastion puts you into the shoes of The Kid, a tough lone survivor of an almost world-ending catastrophe called The Calamity. He quickly finds his way to a safe haven called The Bastion, but is disappointed to find only one survivor - Rucks, who is also the narrator of this game. Now you might have heard how this game has a "dynamic narrator" and the way it's been marketed is slightly less than truthful - the vast majority of the narrator's lines are scripted and occur at fixed points in the narrative. This doesn't matter one bit though, because there are many, many such lines and Logan Cunningham as Rucks manages to get every single one of them to work. This narrator is sometimes funny as hell, sometimes tough and cool, sometimes sad and wistful, sometimes something else entirely... but it works. It sucks you right into the world and doesn't let you go until you have heard the last of his incredibly well-written comments.To me, the narrator alone is a unique and overwhelming selling point, but that is not to say that this is the only way the narrative and the art of this game will charm you. Caelondia, the main setting of this game, is (as the above screenshots will verify) a colorful and beautiful and interesting and varied place. The range of levels (and related moods and tones and gameplay changes) is huge, though the way new locations keep getting introduced and then forgotten after a short visit may remind you of an overambitious sightseer with an overstuffed travel schedule.The music is excellent, moody and serene and exciting as the situation demands. Special mention should be reserved for two absolutely beautiful guitar-and-voice pieces that I won't spoil. Let me just say that they fit into the plot and have a lot more going for them than you would understand on a superficial hearing.Finally, I have to give the gameplay some more credit. That is, the way it merges at times with the plot to create... art.Sorry, that sounded horribly pretentious, but it really is the only word I can find for it. Supergiant Games have somehow managed to make the simplistic and violent mechanics of hack'n'slash appear meaningful in a story about loss and recovery, desperation and hope.... god damn it, there comes the pretension again.Let me just finish this paragraph by saying that one possible endgame scenario is the capital B Best synergy of engaging gameplay and poignant storytelling that I have ever seen or could ever imagine.In closing, Bastion remains one of my favorite games of all times. This is very much an "art" game in the sense that you get the feeling the people working on it wanted to make something beautiful and something that really resonates with people. And they succeeded. As a little extra, I'd like to note that the narrator has an unique comment for every possible combination of weapons. Sometimes it adds a little extra texture to the world, sometimes commenting on the style of fighting it implies. Wow. (All possible combinations of two weapons from a pool of 10 = 45, if my calculations are correct. Anyway, you get my point.)

												Bastion is a Fantastic game and i enjoyed every single second of it! The game has great music and graphics. An interesting narrator that comments on your actions / decisions. Posted: March 21, 2015
												By the end of this game I have to admit, I was getting a little tired of the gameplay. It wasn't necessarily boring because the game steadily throws new weapons and enemies at you which you have to work your head around. But by the end, I was mostly looking forward to not having to see another one of those green eyed thorn balls. I've never been a big fan of dungeon crawlers, so maybe it's a point in Bastion's favour that it was able to keep me interested for so long despite my mixed feelings towards the gameplay.The artwork is definitely the highlight of the game. The landscapes are bring and colourful, and it's a plearsure to meaner your way throught them. The sound is great, with parts of the landscape giving a satisfying "cruch" when they're destroyed. And the voice acting... oh man. Rucks is the narrator/guide through your adventure. He is well written, and his rusty voice gives the game a lot of character. Buy the Bastion announcer pack in Dota 2 if you want more.Overall, it's a good game. I won't be playing it over, but it was overall an enjoyable game while it lasted. I'll be looking forward to playing Transistor next.

Posted: April 16, 2015
												Bastion is a unique game in the sense that it focuses on narration. There is this dude telling you about the destruction of the old world caused by the Calamity, and you are set on a quest to obtain Shards, pieces of the old world so that you can rebuilt it.During this journey, you will discover:- A variety of weapons each with their unique special skill(s)- A variety of upgrades to each of these weapons- A unique challenge for each weapon to see how good you are with it, with the 1st prize usually requiring a number of tries- A few side quests where you fight waves of enemies to find out more about each character(May have a few more but these are the highlights for me.)The game play can be really easy or hard. This is because you can choose to invoke a number of Idols (up to 10) at the Shrine, each giving enemies a unique power-up. I played the last few levels with 6 Idols invoked, cos any more and I would fail and had to restart.At the very end, you have to make two choices that will directly affect the end screen. The second choice will also trigger two separate steam achievements, so achievement junkies like me will have to replay the game on new game +. While there isn't much replay value (enemies don't get tougher automatically), I guess you could invoke all 10 Idols for the maximum difficulty.Overall amazing art and great soundtrack with average game-play (gets old). I think the narrator did a great job, and he even has an announcer pack for Dota 2!8.5/10

Posted: March 2, 2015
												I couldn’t have been happier to kick off the new series of reviews with Bastion which is one of my most favorite games and has one of the best stories in the industry. Let’s have at it.I – Story [10/10]Bastion is an action RPG from the amazingly talented Supergiant Games. The player assumes the role of the Kid. The story begins in the aftermath of the Calamity, a cataclysmic event that almost entirely destroyed the city of Caelondia as well as much of the surrounding world, leaving it in fractured, floating pieces. The Kid makes his way to the Bastion, a location the Caels were supposed to meet at in case of an emergency. However, the only survivor the Kid meets is Rucks, a mysterious old man and the narrator of the game’s events. Rucks informs the Kid that he needs to collect Cores (large crystals that used to power the city) from around Caelondia and that the Bastion has the ability to use the Cores to rebuild.During his journey, the Kid meets two other survivors; Zulf and Zia. Zulf was an ambassador from the Ura people, a one time enemy of the Caels. Zia is an Ura girl who was born and raised in Caelondia. The Kid leads them both to the Bastion and, upon discovering a research notebook written in the native tongue of the Ura, the Kid enlists their help in translating it. Rucks and Zia are unable to read it, so the Kid falls back on Zulf to do the translating. In the meantime, the Kid goes in search of the final Core that they need.Upon his return however, the Kid finds Zulf gone. Rucks explains that when Zulf had finished translating the notebook, he snapped and wreaked significant damage upon the Bastion. Apparently the notebook (which had belonged to Zia’s father, Venn) detailed the Mancer’s (a group of Cael scientists) efforts to create a weapon with which they could destroy the Ura and prevent any further wars. However, Venn had rigged the weapon to backfire, so, when the Mancers finally made him pull the trigger, the weapon destroyed Caelondia as well.In order to repair the damage done to the Bastion by Zulf, the Kid takes to the Wilds in search of Shards (smaller versions of the Cores). As the Kid acquires one of the final shards, the Ura attack the Bastion, kidnapping Zia in the process. This event takes the Kid deep into Ura territory in search of both the final shard and Zia. When the Kid finally breaks through the Ura outpost, he finds Zia, but the Shard slips through his fingers.In the final missions of the game, the Kid sets off into the once-underground Ura homeland to confront Zulf and retrieve the final Shard. Inside the homeland, the Kid finds Zulf being attacked by his countrymen and he is faced with a choice: he can drop his weapon and carry Zulf back to the Bastion with him or he can leave Zulf to his fate and battles his way through the remaining Ura.Back at the Bastion, the Kid is presented with one final choice from Rucks. The Kid can choose to use the Bastion’s power to rewind time to before the Calamity and set things back to the way they were, but there is no guarantee that the Calamity won’t happen again. The Kid can also choose to use the Bastion’s power to initiate the evacuation protocol  and move on to someplace safe with Rucks and Zia (and Zulf if the player chose to save him).Multiple endings, an enchanting fantasy world, an incredible back story revealed through gameplay, and a hands-down amazing story throughout the entire game. Almost every game could stand to learn a thing or two from Bastion.II – UI [9/10]The user interface in Bastion is marvelous. You’ll never struggle to find any critical information, what weapons you have equipped, or what special attack you currently have. The only complaint that I have, at all about Bastion (though I’m somewhat torn about making it) is the lack of a minimap. While a minimap would have made navigation in game areas easier, it probably would have distracted from the overall game immersion.III – Gameplay [10/10]Gameplay in Bastion is fluid and fast-paced, with a fine-tuned combat system and intuitive controls. Attacking and defending are both omnidirectional. While there’s no jumping (at least, not for most of the game), you do have a very nice rolling maneuver at your disposal.IV – Content [10/10]With Bastion being the first ever game from Supergiant Games, I must say there was a very large amount of content. There are more than ten weapons with which you can fill your arsenal, all of which are fully upgradeable. There is a vast array of special attacks and character perks to unlock and discover throughout the course of the game. There are a good amount of missions and bonus missions to keep you occupied with and they are all filled with a wonderful plethora of enemies to slay.V – Visual [10/10]The art of Bastion is, simply put, phenomenal. Everything is hand-painted and unforgettable. It has an art style that is very unique when it comes to gaming and I sincerely hope that we all have the privilege of seeing it more often in future titles.VI – Audio [10/10]Not to be outdone by the artwork department, the soundtrack (and sounds) of Bastion were every bit as good as every other aspect of the game. Even if you don’t end up getting the game, you should do yourself a favor and pick up the soundtrack, because wow. Just wow.VII – Overall [9.8/10]Overall, Bastion is a truly great game and you shouldn’t hesitate to add it to your own library.

												The Kid did good. First he heard rumors about just how awesome Bastion was during its Xbox live run. Then it came to steam and he played the Demo. Wielding two weapons at once, he plowed his way though the first level of an entertaining hack-n-slash game where he heard me, the narrator, narrate his every action for sometimes humorous effect as the plot unfolds. Even after he completed the story, I was pleasantly surprised at how even NewGame+ was worked into the game even if I found the act of making choices near the end rather arbitrary. Posted: December 5, 2012
												Played the game before, never got around to actually finishing till now.  Because of this I must rewrite my review:Bastion is an RPG that stands out from many other RPGs out there.  The path lays themselves down as you walk on them and the game itself is an art.  Fighting system is also not too complex but still offers various options for loadout and passive skills.  If the game is too easy, you can add additional challenges by invoking one (or all) of the ten gods available.  The narrator is one of the game's unique feature as he narrates everything you do - including your dumb mistakes.  But the best part of the game is the story itself.  You start the game knowing nothing about yourself or the world or anyone.  But in time, the story will come together like a puzzle and the ending is definitely worth playing for.  In my opinion, it's one of the best endings I've seen.  It's not a long game - I finished it in 12 hours (and I took my sweet time).TL;DR: PLAY IT!Tip: if you have a controller, use it!  This game is so much better with a controller, in my opinion.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Talking about the gameplay of this game is probably the easiest part:You have two weapons that you can choose from a pool of up to 12 (or something). New weapons get introduced regularly up to and including the final level. With the left and right mouse buttons you shoot, slash, smash, stab and/or pistol-sling things until they are dead. There are many different things to kill, which keeps up the variety nicely, and being able to dodge-roll like crazy keeps a steady and exciting pace.There are minor gripes (such as the lock-on being a bit imprecise at some points), but nothing even remotely gamebreaking.I may sound dismissive, but this is only because the hack'n'slash gameplay is merely good - compared to a narrative which is absolutely excellent.Bastion puts you into the shoes of The Kid, a tough lone survivor of an almost world-ending catastrophe called The Calamity. He quickly finds his way to a safe haven called The Bastion, but is disappointed to find only one survivor - Rucks, who is also the narrator of this game. Now you might have heard how this game has a "dynamic narrator" and the way it's been marketed is slightly less than truthful - the vast majority of the narrator's lines are scripted and occur at fixed points in the narrative. This doesn't matter one bit though, because there are many, many such lines and Logan Cunningham as Rucks manages to get every single one of them to work. This narrator is sometimes funny as hell, sometimes tough and cool, sometimes sad and wistful, sometimes something else entirely... but it works. It sucks you right into the world and doesn't let you go until you have heard the last of his incredibly well-written comments.To me, the narrator alone is a unique and overwhelming selling point, but that is not to say that this is the only way the narrative and the art of this game will charm you. Caelondia, the main setting of this game, is (as the above screenshots will verify) a colorful and beautiful and interesting and varied place. The range of levels (and related moods and tones and gameplay changes) is huge, though the way new locations keep getting introduced and then forgotten after a short visit may remind you of an overambitious sightseer with an overstuffed travel schedule.The music is excellent, moody and serene and exciting as the situation demands. Special mention should be reserved for two absolutely beautiful guitar-and-voice pieces that I won't spoil. Let me just say that they fit into the plot and have a lot more going for them than you would understand on a superficial hearing.Finally, I have to give the gameplay some more credit. That is, the way it merges at times with the plot to create... art.Sorry, that sounded horribly pretentious, but it really is the only word I can find for it. Supergiant Games have somehow managed to make the simplistic and violent mechanics of hack'n'slash appear meaningful in a story about loss and recovery, desperation and hope.... god damn it, there comes the pretension again.Let me just finish this paragraph by saying that one possible endgame scenario is the capital B Best synergy of engaging gameplay and poignant storytelling that I have ever seen or could ever imagine.In closing, Bastion remains one of my favorite games of all times. This is very much an "art" game in the sense that you get the feeling the people working on it wanted to make something beautiful and something that really resonates with people. And they succeeded. As a little extra, I'd like to note that the narrator has an unique comment for every possible combination of weapons. Sometimes it adds a little extra texture to the world, sometimes commenting on the style of fighting it implies. Wow. (All possible combinations of two weapons from a pool of 10 = 45, if my calculations are correct. Anyway, you get my point.)

Posted: July 8, 2014
												The game is really awesome. Its simple controls and fast learning curve are appreciated. The graphics are rather beautiful and colorful.What I like about the game really are the levels. They are short, allowing for a lot of variety, which the game does use. City, ports, forests, etc.The weapons are nothing too original, yet each is used in a different way; allowing to fit anyone's playstyle. The upgrade system of the weapons is well balanced, making you wait some time before getting the really useful ones.When it comes to soundtrack, I got to say they are really awesome: joyful, calm, clear; it goes by itself and fits the area you're in.My two complaints about it would be that I found the game lacking some "real difficulty". Yes, there are shrines that increases it significantly by adding chances for ennemies to block, to become invincible for some time, etc. I would say, "real difficulty" to be ennemies with paterns, ways to behave, effective spots as real difficulty. Here, bosses are similar to their counterparts but with more HP and more damage. The good example of "real difficulty" would be The Binding of Isaac.My second complaint is that I find the game a bit too short (finished the story in 5 hours). I would have loved a longer story because I really loved it.Final verdict: the game is not perfect, but is certainly worth your time. 17/20

Posted: February 23, 2015
												+ Tons of atmosphere+ Great soundtrack+ Great voice work by the narrator+ Art and visual aesthetic- Not a lot of depth in combat or other gameplay features.I've played through Bastion twice now and it's still very enjoyable.  One can't really say enough about the great job Supergiant did with building an interesting and slightly mysterious world, and crammed it with atmosphere and character.  Everything from the music, the narration, the detailed and beautiful art, and interesting plot all add up to a world you like seeing and experiencing.  The music and voicework really deserve their own mention, winning many awards (not that those mean much nowadays) for both the composer and Logan Cunningham for his portrayal as the Narrator.  The best way I can describe the soundtrack is like...acoustic frontier western folk music mixed with electronica.  It's great and can easily be listened to on it's own.  The games combat mechanics are the one thing that doesn't shine quite as bright as the rest.  What is there is very solid and controls just fine, but it tends to be a bit dull and not very challenging, especially in the first half or so of the game.  It gets a bit button mashy.  Later on, more enemies and more varied weapons and projectiles pick up the pace and things feel much better.  I just wish I had the same level of enjoyment in combat throughout all of it.  There are some city building and weapon upgrade features, which are welcome, but don't have much substance.  With more time and money in the budget, I'd love to see what Supergiant can do with a more fleshed out sequel.It's the atmosphere and aesthetics that take this good game and elevate it to something special.

Beautiful graphics blend seamlessly into beautiful audio tied together with the silky smooth voice of the narraitor. Many of the achivements are easy, several unmissable. Others however are brutal, several involve beating the hardest levels in the game with all the difficulty modifiers activated.  Such achivements being: Calamity All Around, Ashes in the Sky, About the Author and Just Like That The game defanitly has re-playablity, if not for achivement-hunting then for everything else. You will miss a lot on your first play-through, playing with all the weapons, consumables and modifiers goes a lot deeper. Many questions will go un-answered. You will likely be forced into desicions you don't want to make, only to jump back in again to choose again.  Would you save a traitor? Would you go back, in the hope something will change. What about if it doesn't? The choice is yours, let me know if you find out the right one.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												If you like a good soundtrack, character customization, art style and narration then you’ll be loving every second Bastion has to offer. Bastion is an hack and slash action RPG that combines an amazing art style with an even more amazing soundtrack. The combat and movement feels smooth and unique. There is a variety of different weapons that allows you to fight enemies the way you want. One of the best things about Bastion is the freshness of the game, there aren't many games that are able to pull of an amazing art style, soundtrack, narration and combat all at the same time. The scenery never gets boring and is alway changing with lots of minor details. One of the ways they do this is by having the ground around you form as you walk near it. This can help keep people with low attention spans to keep engaged with the game.The constant improvements to your character and weapons gives a lot more replayability to the game. Leveling up allows you to quipt a buffing effect called a ‘spirit’ to your character. Weapons can be upgraded through finding materials when exploring the world. Idols make the game harder in certain aspects and are used to give the player more of a challenge, this helps give the game more replayability. The hack and slash gameplay is well made with lots of different ways to defeat your enemies. Upgrading weapons was very satisfying and fun to do. Bastion's soundtrack is very good and interesting and can be what keeps some people playing the game. The art style is also very unique and fitting with the soundtrack.One of the cons the game has (And it’s hard to come across cons in Bastion) is that the hack and slash gameplay at times can get a little repetitive. It’s also lacking in a filled in story, for example It doesn’t talk about what the world was like before the calamity, leaving the world feeling a bit empty at times. The story missions are basic and revolve around collecting one sort of object for almost every mission. But these don’t make Bastion a bad game, far from it. These are just little things I found when playing Bastion other people might and probably do disagree with.On average Bastion takes around six and a half hours to complete the story, while to complete the story and all extras takes around twenty hours. Bastion keeps the story nice and short for players looking for a short and sweet experience, while giving the game a good amount of completion hours for those wanting to spend a good extra fifteen or so hours on the game. With this and everything I’ve covered I’d recommend this game to anyone who loves good hack and slash mechanics, art and soundtrack in the games they play. I think It’s well worth the full price of fifteen dollars, but if you find it on sale it’s a must buy.

Posted: March 17, 2013
												Bastion is a fantastic and colorful game that tells a heartwarming story. The game revolves around the narrator, a likable figure that dictates your actions and voices the game's story. He is quite unique, and unlike other narrators in games like "Thomas Was Alone" or "The Stanley Parable". I honestly can't quite explain it, you would have to play the game for yourself to see it. The gameplay is fun -- and even though animation isn't top-notch, you barely notice it. You have the ability to level-up, gaining new weapons and powers -- there's also plenty of secrets about the world to discover. Bastion's combat is fairly enjoyable -- and although challenging, it was not frustrating.Bastion forms around the choices you make. This includes the narration. For instance, during the beginning of the game, (if you destroy enough items) you are told the classic line: "Kid just rages for a while." Some of the other choices are more influential, of course. I was proud and happy about some of my choices, but filled with dismay over others. (And such is life.)Overall, this is one of the best indie games of all time. It's worth all $15, but if you wait long enough you can pick it up on sale (or in an indie bundle).Bastion is great for everyone, no matter what you like in a game.

												At first glance, Bastion boasts amazing art style. The gameplay looks somewhat interesting, and you might consider this game for your Steam Wishlist.     But then, once you have the game, Bastion assults your ears with an unforgettable soundtrack! Upon playing the first 5 minuets of the game, you hear a narrator giving a story monolouge to every action you take! Not only that, but the narrator has a voice in league with the Great Morgan Freeman!     The game's audio and video quality match those of many indie greats such as Braid or the Borderlands series. The storyline to back this game reveals itself like the ground coming up around you; the more you explore, the more you discover!  By the time I Reached the end credits of this game, I was crying tears of sheer amazment and awe at the beauty of the world in which these events take place. And if that were not enough to draw you in, When you finish the game, you can relive every moment you loved with the New Game+ feature.     All around, Bastion is part interactive storybook, part RPG action adventure with dozens of Steam achievments and challenge areas that will have you playing this game over and over again. 10 out of 10 In my humble opinion. Adventure, beauty, action, costumizable weapons, secret skills, and a soundtrack that leaves you speachless. Not to mention a golden-voiced narrator, all of these await you in Bastion.

												Lovely game. The art style is amazing and one-of-a-kind. It flows out of a steampunk fantasy aesthetic that makes the game worls relatable and yet also distant. Posted: January 20, 2014
												Should you play Bastion if you haven't done it yet? In one word : YES. Gameplay-wise the game is very well done. You collect weapons, spirits, level up, upgrade you weapons, etc. The difficulty level is adjustable by use of idols : you practically invoke the gods who in return make your life harder :) . To be honest, i played the game 3 times using the idols just to get more achievements. It's a blast! To make it short, the gameplay is engaging and challenging at times. Now the best part of Bastion : it's music and graphics. About the music there is nothing to say except that it's gorgeous. You'll definetly download the soundtrack and integrate it in your playlist. The narrator does a fantastic job at depicting the story and describing your every action. The narrator is no more that person who talks only between mission. If you break a vase, he tells you that, if you defeat a boss, he's certainly got something up his sleeve to say. And all this happenes without becoming too annoying.The graphics are astounding despite the fact they are 2d (or at least the background is). In fact, this has an even more powerful impact on your perception than a game who has 3d graphics. Every detail in the game is finely drawn and you'll feel the urge to explore every nook and cranny just to see the vistas.So, what are you doing here reading ? Go buy the game!9/10

Posted: May 3, 2015
												This game was a game I bought on sale without expecting much. I tought the design looked pretty enough and randomly decided to give it a try. I did not regret it. I can safely say that this game is well worth its full price.It is, for one, absolutely beautiful. The details and colors are awfully pleasing to look at, the voice acting never gets old & does an amazing job of getting you into the story and, most of all, the soundtrack is breathtaking. It has been a long while since the last time I wanted to buy a soundtrack so badly. The story is well paced and makes the most of small cast of endearing characters. The twists, although mostly easy to predict, are paced in a way that keeps the story compelling and interesting. I could not help but get attached. There is also some replayability to the game as it has multiple endings. Finishing the game once means that you have the option to start over and keep all the weapons etc. that you got the first time around.The game in itself is not too hard and offers you a nice system to up the challenge should you desire it. As you play the first time around, you collect various idols, each bearing its own difficulty, that you can activate to pepper things up. The achievements are also quite fun to get. Anyway, this game is a gem. Getitgetitgetit. You won't regret it. ❤

Posted: December 12, 2016
												I've heard of Bastion prior to owning it, but never really bothered to look into it. One of my friends was like "Hey, you should play Bastion" and I decided to try the demo. Figuring the demo was alright, I went an' bought the game on sale for very cheap.What I got was arguably one of the greatest games I've ever played.To start, I'll begin with the gameplay itself. I tried the demo with a keyboard and mouse, but played through the full game from start to finish with an Xbox360 Afterglow controller. For both schemes, the controls are fluid and intuitive, and there are many different weapon combinations and upgrades to suit your preferred playstyle. There are options to remap the controls to however you desire in case the default controls don't quite work for you. The game's pacing and difficulty scaling are next to perfection; throughout the game, I felt challenged but it wasn't overwhelmingly difficult nor was it a cakewalk. The only times I had serious trouble were when I activated the optional Shrines that explicitly make the game harder to gain better rewards and exp. The combat focuses far more on player skill than in-game stats, as said stats are virtually nonexistent; your combat prowess is determined purely by how adept you are at attacking, blocking and evading. Sure, the weapons can be upgraded to make them a bit better, but not a single one of them ever feels overpowered until the very end where you're forced to use a blatantly overpowered weapon.As for the story, the narrative provides a nice touch to the way the plot develops; the story is far from straightforward, but it's paced such that new developments always bring something to the table. At first I was confused about the plot as you're thrown right into the middle of it (as lampshaded by the narrator), but as the story progressed I began to really get immersed.Overall, this game is very well designed. There wasn't any point in the game where I felt hopelessly stuck, nor did I ever feel like I was punished for choosing to unlock/use one thing instead of another. It felt like I was in control of my own progression and skill level as I experimented with which weapons worked best, as well as developing my own combat playstyle. The story took me on a very enjoyable ride as the narrator pieces together the big picture the more I progressed.

												Got recommended to buy this game by a friend and since it was in the sale at the time, I got the game. At first it seemed like another typical animated game with a simple story line. That was until I dwelled deeper into the game and the story line progressed making the game much more interesting. As in most games, the player can choose to play on "No-Sweat Mode", a mode allowing the player to get to grips with the games controls and learn how the game works and then a normal mode. I have to admit, the normal mode seemed easy until I unlocked some more islands and the fun began. After much rage quitting I finally completed the game, or so I thought. When returning to the title screen, deciding to play the game again, I found two new modes had been added. "New Game Plus" and "Score Attack Mode". I won't dwell into the details of the modes as it is for you to find out when you get to it, but Bastion is a rewarding game with characters you can't help but love. If you are thinking of getting this game I recommend you do so as it is well worth the price and will provide hours of entertainment and has an incredible soundtrack.Overall : 9/10NOTE: If you're wondering why my playtime is only 4.6 hours on record at the time of writing yet I said that I have spent a lot of time on it, this is because I originally played this game on a different account. Do not let this stop you thinking about buying the game, there is plenty of content to enjoy!

Posted: August 14, 2014
												Before I actaully go into any sort of depth, for anyone that uses the Steam reviews of a game in the same way that I do, the game functions!  Some people have complained about the keyboard & mouse controls, but the controls were perfectly fine on a 360 controller.  Now, onto the review proper.Bastion is a game where a mysterious calamity (simply called "The Calamity" by survivors) has wiped out most of the world's population and shot most of the land into the air.  You play as a boy (simply called "The Kid"), and must traverse various different locations to find Cores, magical crystals that will help to rebuild The Bastion.  One of the first things that people will notice about the game is the unique way that the narrative is framed.  Many of the different things that you do in the game are accompanied by a narration.  The voice actor perfectly fits the Steampunk/western style of the game, and is an absolute joy to listen to, even though he is the only voice actor in the game (aside from a few of the songs that contain lyrics and a small amount of dialogue with another character at the end).  The narration is meant to be one of the characters in the game retelling of past events, occasionally foreshadowing something or giving his personal thoughts.  The game allows you to find out about the lore of the game and the backstories of the characters as if you were actually the person listening to the story, allowing for you to decide what is true and what is made up.  Additionally, the beautiful handpainted graphics add to the atmosphere of the game in an incredible way.  You may end up feeling as if you don't want to kill any of the monsters, since they look so interesting, but avoiding them is generally not an option.  The game also explicitly mentions that many of the creatures used to be docile before The Calamity, leaving it up to the player why they suddenly want to kill The Kid (at one point, the narrator even says "At first they left the barge alone, then they saw who was riding it.").Style can only account for a part of the experience of playing a game, though, so onto the gameplay.  The game has a sort of hack-and-slash style to it, and can feel very satisfying.  The weapons are all nicely varied, allowing for many different choices, and, in addition, each combination of two weapons elicits a unique line from the narrator.  The weapon upgrading system, featuring the ability to switch between 2 paths (usually representing effects versus damage), and its feature of allowing the player to mix and match upgrades at a will, adds even more depth.  Despite feeling satisfactory, the combat can feel a bit too easy once you get the hang of it, but learning each weapon as more are introduced throughout the game is great.  The "Proving Grounds," of which there is one for each weapon, however, are a very nice challenge for the most part, and completing all of them is very rewarding, even if you as the player don't like to use the weapon that it's relating to.  The spirits that can upgrade your stats are a nice touch too, being a very unique way of upgrading and, again, eliciting a unique line of dialogue from the narrator whenever one is equipped, usually talking about its Pre-Calamity use or reputation.Of course, since the soundtrack of this game is so famous, I would be remiss to review it without mentioning the music.  The soundtrack in this game is possibly the best I've ever heard.  The area tracks fit perfectly with whatever kind of atmosphere that area wants to convey.  The musical cues are spot-on, and the few previously mentioned tracks (entitled "Build That Wall"; "Mother I'm Here"; and "Setting Sail, Coming Home," respectively) are indescribably wonderful.  Even while typing out this review, I'm listening to the soundtrack in the background.  It's THAT good, and I'd say definitely worth a look, even if you don't plan on playing the game.On release, this game recieved major critical acclaim.  I have to say that, even though I only ever played it 3 years later, the game is wholly deserving of any and all praise.  It has, very occasionally, been accused of pretentiousness, and, to this, I have to say that a game being "artsy" and it being "pretentious" are two very different things.  The handpainted backgrounds and incredible score add a level of atmosphere rarely seen in games.  The gameplay is very satisfying and rewarding, and there was a moment in the story, close to the end, that genuinely made me, a person who tries to keep my emotions to myself, burst into tears.  I won't spoil it by saying what it is, but what I can say about it is that it's one of the most emotional and well set up moments I've ever seen in anything.  I don't really know what I can add to the discussion about this game, as I'm sure that all I've said has been said elsewhere by other people, but, if you've read this far, all I can say is that this is a game worth getting.  Anyone who can appreciate games as an artform owes it to themselves to play this game.  It's fun, it's emotional, it's amazing.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												I played Bastion for the first time a few years ago. Now that I've re-played it, I just have to write a positive review about it.This game is excellent in every possible aspect. The gameplay is fun and extremely adaptable to the player's skill level: if you want to play easy you can just go on with the story without using idols or face challenges, while if you are a completist and look for something more serious you can activate all or few idols (which give enemies various kinds of buffs) and try to beat every proving ground. There's really something for every taste here.The story is nice and captivating, the kind you appreciate even more when you replay the game a second time. Is incredible with how many details the writers managed to fill the plot considering that everything is narrated by Zulf's voice while you play. Undoubtedly one of the most successful experiments in alternative narration I've ever had the pleasure to play with.Artistic direction is also really beautiful, the art, the animations, the maps, everything is so polished and detailed that it's simply a pleasure to look at this game running. And the music...is great. Just great.Really, it's hard to find a flaw in this little masterpiece of indie gaming...Zulf's voice talking over and over can be annoying sometimes, maybe? Honestly it's all I can think of when I ask myself what Bastion's defects are.What else can I say... hell, just buy this game already. You won't regret it.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Bastion is a good game ... but not a great one.  Lets get to the good stuff first.  The first thing most people will mention is the narrator and with good reason.  Everything you do in Bastion is narrated.  Whether you are fighting monsters, buying upgrades, or just standing around, the narrator always has something relavent to say.  The voice actor has a great voice for the part and he helps make something that could have been gimicy a stand out feature of the game.The art and look of the game are excellent.  Vivid colors, unique art design and locals, and a cartoony look make the game look and feel unique.  When you aren't being attacked just wondering through the different locations is a treat.  New enemies, new upgradable weapons, dreams (arenas), and boss fights keep the game feeling fresh.  Getting stuck at a certain spot, find the location to upgrade one of your weapons and go through the trial there to see if you unlock new items and upgrades.  The dreams are a good places to rack up money and face a good challenge as combinations of enemies attack you in different rounds.  The music is simple but effective.  It never gets overly complicated or stands out, it just accompanies game play and it does that well.  It may not be for everyone but I enjoyed it.The control scheme with a keyboard and mouse was a little cumbersome.  It felt hard to be precise with my movements using the WASD for my movement keys.  The mouse gave me good accuracy for targeting but given a choice I think the game would feel better being played on a controller.While it was fun upgrading my weapons, I would have liked to have ablities to unlock or upgrade on my character that would make combat even more fun and varied.  This could have lived up some of the boss fights which devolved into run far away as possible and use a missile weapon, rinse, repeat.The very end isn't a traditional boss fight.  I won't spoil it here and some may have been put off by it but I liked how it finished the story and did something other then kill the boss, roll credits.  I would recommend this game for most people to try out.  Watch the videos and if you are intrigued give it a try, I don't think you will be disappointed.

												Honestly, when I first looked at this game, I had my doubts. I have always thought that overhead action games don't work, but I'm glad I was wrong. No game is perfect, so let's look at the cons first: slow walking speed - while backtracking doesn't happen unless you miss something, it can still be a chore short game - I completed it in less than 10 hours, and I found myself wanting for more Now for the good stuff graphics - every are had breathtaking backgrounds and the stage itself was beautiful soundtrack - one of the best I've ever heard, and I've played Zelda gameplay - you unlock the ability to change the difficulty at will, and not just change a setting, but you specifically improve certain attributes on the enemies, and you increase your rewards based on which attributes you chose replayability - mulitiple endings, new game plus mode preventing you from restarting from scratch, different playstyles, and a scored mode make for excellent replayablity level design - the world being created at the kid's feet is a very nice touch that leads to a lot of explorationIn conclusion, this was one of the most delightful games I have ever played. I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes fun. Well worth the money. 9.9/10

Posted: December 24, 2012
												Bastion is what I consider the ultimate example of pacing in a videogame. The game hits you hard with major challenges early on, and steadily ramps up the difficulty while also providing a lot of new weapons and concepts to the player steadily. What's more, the game never keeps you pinned down in one spot for too long. There's always some new interesting weapon combo to try out, and new challenges to try them out on. The narrator and story presentation tie into this perfectly, keeping the storyline moving at a good stint along with the rest of the game. Bastion isn't a very long game, but it's a very dense experience - there's a lot to take in during that short time period, on all levels.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												You are greeted by the gruff voice of a stranger. A voice that will be your guide, your mind and your comfort for the next six hours. You play the character of an unnamed Kid, who's job is to protect himself and other survivors from the aftermath of a calamity, and make ends meet on The Bastion: your safe haven. To do this you have to collect cores from the various locations around The Bastion and return them.During gameplay you look down upon The Kid and fend off enemies' attacks. You can improve your weapons back at The Bastion and the narrator will comment on your progress.The voice of the narrator and the soundtrack are the two things that bring the game from fun to brilliant. “Windbags ain’t much different than normal folks,” the narrator says as you crush one of the game’s enemies with your hammer. “All they want is a place to stay and a decent meal.” This makes smashing them that much harder. As for the soundtrack, it suits the mood perfectly; the whole experience drips with passionate artistry. If you are thinking of buying this game, you have no idea what you are getting into. You will come to know of the beauty of Bastion, but you shall never understand it.

Posted: December 8, 2011
												Most undervalued, best game of the year. The narrator has a badass voice that, mark my words, is better than Morgan Freeman's. Music moved me to tears. Moral choices in the end kept me up at night. The game immerses you in "The Kid's" shoes, you make choices you deem fit in his case. A must buy for any serious gamer. Throw away your 60 dollar FPS, get a good game for once.

Posted: September 16, 2013
												The game I most appreciate and respect to this day. The project that gathered all these people (Supergiant Games) that were previously working on big titles, in big offices, feeling like they'd never have creative control so they quit their jobs and risked their livelyhood just so they could realize their dreams of making games. And Bastion is the fruit of their labor, a game overflowing with brilliant design and a great example of story and gameplay coming together. I deeply respect Supergiant as I share their philosophy of making games. I have no doubts that their next game, Transistor, will be absolutely amazing. If it manages to live up to Bastion and even surpass its legacy, I will be extremely happy that Supergiant are making games in my lifetime. Thank you for everything guys!

Posted: July 13, 2016
												A quick TL;DR, if you're buying the game on the spot; the interface is good, the story is interesting, the combat system is fun, just buy it if you're into the genre.The Interface is surprisingly user friendly. It's compatible with all sorts of things, from controllers to your plain mouse and keyboard. They're all pretty intuitive and easy to learn, so you'll get used to the controls quickly. It's also got your usual subtitles and your audio settings. You can have different profiles, which allows you to start over from scratch without destroying your perfect save. Tons of resolution options, too. Generally pretty solid.The story is pretty vague at first; you're a kid, well, you're The Kid, you wake up on a floating island miles away from sea level due to some apocalyptic event, and an omnipresent narrator voice is talking to you, describing your every move. I'd rather not go any further with the story (and you've heard this tons of times. Believe me, I also get tired of hearing this, but this is for real): you should experience it yourself. Supergiant prides itself on digging out lore out of seemingly nothing, it's practically a talent. This game has amazing replayability and you can easily get lost just slashing through everything. The game includes idols that will rise the stakes if you find it too easy. Oh, and the combat system? Love it. I'm biased, since I love hack and slash games, but this game features a diverse cast of weapons that you can mod for extra perks, letting you cherrypick your favorite perks. Will you go for extra damage, or settle for a higher critical chance? Besides weapons, you can drink spirits that will give you passive perks, from extra resistance to retaliating damage.There's not much that I can say about the artwork that hasn't been said. All of the art for the game is very impressive and, to top, very fitting. To close this, since we're talking about art, there's a reason the game is tagged with great soundtrack. The music is also very unique, the artist even giving it its own name (I seriously cannot remember what he called it, but it was a mouthful). Adds a lot of character to the game.Buy it. At best, you'll love it and play it again, and again, and again (or not, it's a 6-11 hour long game), at worst you'll play it once and be kind of okay about it. But if you're bent on getting all those achievements, you will clock out more hours than that. Just go play it. It's art.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												While on it’s surface the game looks like a pretty simple beat-em up game the gameplay is actually a lot funner than that. There’s tons of customization that allows a lot of different play styles and the ability to easily switch between them makes sure that the combat never gets boring. But where this game really shines is in it’s narration and storytelling. The narrator of this game is really ♥♥♥♥ing good and the nonlinear narration adds a really cool element of personability to the game. But out of all of that I think that story is really the best part of the game. It’s mature but not in an edgy way and really speaks a lot about everyday life and learning to move on rather than live in the past. The only bad thing I can say about this game is that it’s a little short. I was able to beat it in one sitting, ~5 hours for a full playthrough, and for some people that might not be worth $15 but the game does seem replayable.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Absolutely get this game! Everyone should play Bastion at least once. It does offer newgame plus, but I honestly wouldn't bother unless you want to give yourself a challenge or you're one of those acheivement junkies. The artstyle and graphics are great! The audio is even better. The best thing about the game is the story. It's very rich and keeps you wanting to play to find out what is going to happen. Also the narrator's voice is just perfect and makes this game complete. The overall experience is fantastic; I was actually a little sad that it ended so soon. The biggest drawback though is the length of the game. It's short. Although it says I played around 11 hours, that was becauseI had initially played around 4 hours back when I got in 2012, but I just recently decided to start a new game. So, it really only took around 7-8 hours to complete. However, I didn't finish all the weapon challenges and I didn't unlock every upgrade, so there's at least another hour or two still there. If you can get it on sale, defintly consider it! Well worth your money and time. Short, but bloody good! 9/10.

												A very cool game, with one hell of a narrator, and some of the greatest 'game writing' ever. The difficulty curve is where it should be, and skill progression felt natural. There aren't any complaints that come to mind when thinking about this game, other than a 'split choice' ending - where I really wanted to know the outcome of each choice before making it, and would have rather had one ending held off as a 'real' ending until a second playthrough - but I suppose that would have been a♥♥♥♥♥♥move. So kudos to these guys. Next stop: Transistor.

Posted: March 23, 2012
												Fantastic. Absolutely fantastic. Don't let's it's simplistic graphics fool you, Bastion is an incredible gaming experience with so much to offer, being very unique in a world filled with games that follow the same generic algorithm. It's controls are simple, easy to pick up and use but at the same time taking time and practice to master. What really makes Bastion a must-play is it's incredible voice acting, narration and soundtrack. While the enemies and combat mechanics seem a bit "Spiral Knight-ish", it's easy to overlook that when facing the big picture, Bastion has everything that Spiral Knights didn't, breath-taking music, immersive narration by a very talented actor, fantastic art style and storyline to complement it all, wrapping it all with in a neat bow for what could easily be the greatest birds-eye beat 'em up action RPG on the market.Do not miss this game, it is next to perfect!

Posted: March 22, 2014
												First off, this game is amazing, and a must buy.Let me tell you why this is so. This game has a very unique artstyle, and not in a bad way. It's probably one of the best looking games I've had the pleasure to play. The art really gives an atmosphere to the game, which is lacking in most games (In my oppinion). Another thing done to almost perfection, is the music. The music in this game blew me away, it's action-packed when needed and it's a bit.. "toned down" and emotional, when it's needed. This contributes alot to the atomphere of the game aswell.The main focus of the game, and the thing you'll be doing the most, is using various weapons to kill creatures, critters and other living things. The game ALSO does great in this part. The combat is responsive, and does not feel like a "mash-to-win" thing. It also requires an amount of skill to master. This is empathised by the game it self, as it has "Training Grounds" where you can unlock 3 tiers of rewards, depending on how good you do a task, where the third tier is perfecting the task (Which is very difficult). This combat system if what I'd call an "easy to learn, hard to master" kind of thing. The game has around 10 weapons, where around half of them are ranged and the other half melee. You also get a "secret skill" which is like a special move, but you can't use it all the time, it has a resource attached to it which you can hold 3 of. You can upgrade your weapons aswell, It's almost impossible to upgrade them all. That's all I'm going to say on that.Now I think it's time to talk about the story. It's great. I'm not a "story guy" as I apreciate good mechanics instead of a great story. But since this has great mechanics, I started to focus on the story aswell. I'm scared to say anything about it, I'd recomend you to go experience it for yourself. The levels them self don't get boring either. They are kind of being built, as you go along the path. That's the way this game does secrets aswell, which there are a few of. This makes the levels feel very dynamic, as they're kind of built on the spot. So now I'm going to repeat my self... Go buy this game. It's worth the price.

Posted: December 17, 2011

It balances awesome and satisfying gameplay with the best-told story I've encountered since the Portals.The soundtrack is phenomenal, the narration is perfect and drives the story artfully, the world is beautiful.They've accomplished their goal as far as I'm concerned - they made a video game that makes me feel what I felt playing games as a kid.

Posted: September 25, 2013
												The kid types on his keyboard about a game. "Bastion", I think it was called. The kid went on about how it was a great game. He really seemed to be into it. He looks at me, and I nod in approval to let him continue talking while he types what's intresting about the '"active narrating" doo-hickey. He says how "cool" it is to hear  a person say what you're doing in a game and actively comments; and that it immerses the player into the world. I don't understand a word of it, but I continue nodding.He then starts recounting about the times he played the game, about the "Calamity". He talks about waking up, floating in the sky in the middle of nowhere. Then something about a hammer. He starts listing all the types of weapons you get as you play, a machete. Rifle, Mortar, Shotgun, Pistol, Revolver, a Bow and Arrow. Even a flamethrower. He then lists all the monsters. Gasbags, Slimes, Crows, something about a Queen. All pretty interesting, but to a different man.+Kid talks about the "active narrating" again, saying how good it is+Then he says the controls are easy to learn,+"People with different playstyles will love it", he says+From what I've heard from the kid, the game's story is the best he's ever doneWatchin' his smile fade to a frown, he starts to complain-"Too easy", says the kid. Well if you wanted it harder, all you gotta do is♥♥♥♥♥♥off a god, I say-He goes on to say that althought it's a great story, it's mighty predictable. Hmmph.-Kid becomes a lunatic, shouting something about Birds and Spikeweeds. Don't care much for that language he uses with it.He pretends to be judge now, as he coughs and stacks a pile of cards, with the numbers 1 to 10 on 'em. Wait for it...He holds up a 9, good golly. That's gotta make some'uns day.

												Buy this, now!

Posted: December 22, 2014
												Hands down one of my favourite games on Steam. I picked it up in a Humble Bundle but it is well worth even paying full price for.The narrative experience is one unlike any other game.  There's a reason they had the guy record a commentator pack for Dota 2; his voice will make you cream your pants.Gameplay-wise, the game is very solid. I cannot help but feel like certain weapons are more powerful than others, but the game does a good job at encouraging experimentation with every one of them while not forcing prolonged use.The only negative thing I have to say is that, at times, it can be unclear in a level whether or the path you're following is for progress or for extra's, and at times backtracking is impossible, leaving the player with a missed collectible. Levels cannot be replayed, so the player will then have to complete a full playthrough to find this last pickup.

Posted: December 24, 2012
												Bastion is what I consider the ultimate example of pacing in a videogame. The game hits you hard with major challenges early on, and steadily ramps up the difficulty while also providing a lot of new weapons and concepts to the player steadily. What's more, the game never keeps you pinned down in one spot for too long. There's always some new interesting weapon combo to try out, and new challenges to try them out on. The narrator and story presentation tie into this perfectly, keeping the storyline moving at a good stint along with the rest of the game. Bastion isn't a very long game, but it's a very dense experience - there's a lot to take in during that short time period, on all levels.

Posted: May 25, 2013
												My favorite game of 2011! I love how you're constantly getting new weapons till the very end and how they each have a very different feel. And the system for constantly retuning their upgrades gave a lot of tactical decision making possibilities that changed how you use them. The flow of combat with timed shots, blocking, parries, and dodges is so well done... at least once you learn all those tricks from the training challenges. The passive upgrades and self imposed difficulty modifiers for bonus XP were really cool too (especially after they add more on the second play through).To top it off there's the beautiful music, visuals, and narration. Everything came together in to such an awesome package. Can't wait for their next game!

Posted: July 14, 2014
												I'm not going to spend too long talking about this game, now that it's several years old. Check out the gameplay, and if that appeals to you, get it. Opinions follow.Pros:+Good art+Good music+Good sound design+Good gameplay+Pretty good story+Lots of weapons to play with+Training ground for each weapon+Starts out pretty easy but allows you to make it a lot harder if you want a challengeCons:-Kind of short-You get a new weapon like every other stage. Unless you play New Game Plus, you won't have enough levels to play around with all the weapons-Sometimes hard to tell where you will and won't fall off of-Pretty linear with very minimal exploration10/10 it's pretty good.

Posted: February 24
												7/10 - Charming game, fun combat, rewarding upgrade system, an interesting story and setting, and of course the narration really makes it shine. Not much to say that hasn't already been said. Goes on maybe a bit longer than I'd have liked, and there were a few points here and there that felt either unfairly difficult (some of the challenge arenas basically requiring absolute perfect economy of movement/action) or far easier than the plot would have suggested (most of the major encounters towards the end of the game felt rather inconsequential despite the increasing significance). Still, a great game nonetheless.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												I think this may be one of the best Indie games I have ever played. The controls and combat is smooth and flowing, and handles beautifully. The art style is flat out amazing, and works extremely well with the environment and atmosphere. Even while the overall feel of the game was fantastic, neither (to me, anyway) even held a candle to the Storytelling and narration.As for the weapons, each weapon felt insanely well designed. They each were varied from every other weapon in how they were useful and upgraded enough so that each weapon had a unique handle and style of playing with it, and there weren't so many as to feel like they were just haphazardly thrown in the game. The big thing I love about how the weapons are used is one is bound to the LMB and one is bound to RMB, so you can only carry 2 at a time, and you can balance out, using pistols for fast attacks and movement in addition with your much slower, but harder hitting Hammer or Rifle.I truly recommend this game to just about everyone, it is so close to perfection, I can't really find good complaints about it. About the only thing I had slight issues with was the diagonal moving (up does not move you up, it moves you to the top right) and even then, you get used to that and adjust yourself before you even realize it. About the only other thing I felt disappointed about was how the shield worked. There was no choice of different shields (maybe one that allows you to take partial damage, but move while using it or something), the shield would block all damage, no matter what, and you can't really upgrade it. However, there is also a Parry mechanic which you cause damage if you raise your shield just as you get attacked, and that did take timing and skill.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Still pretty much the best "I wanna play 'Zelda - A Link to the Past' but don't feel like cranking out my SNES"-fix you can get.Quick gameplay, always challenging but never unfair (eventhough it gets real close at times).Great game, ten thumbs up, 12/10, etc... ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The customer came to the Steam Reviews section.  Paged down, paged down. What the hell was this one? It seemed to be talking about them, instead of to them, about the game Bastion.  "What the hell is this?" the customer thought to themselves. They considered it. Isometric - the long flat angles of hand-drawn artwork. Was it like Diablo? The ranks of monsters, of course, but were they demon-maddened, suffused with the craving for additional credit card transactions? No, definitely not, surely someone would say that if that was happening. An ordinary tale, simple characters moving direct to what they desired, and a story you could feel unspool like a cat with a ball of yarn. But what dark thing lurked beneath the fluffy colored twine? What was the thing that would roll out before you at the end and make you look back at all the mess you made? The review didn't say. The customer clicked "Add to Cart".  The customer clicked "Add all DLC to Cart". It was that kind of night.
