Posted: July 12, 2015
												Replayable for multiple playthroughs. Engaging story and characters. Action packed hack and slash combat. Narration during your entire adventure. Several weapons that come with their own unique special skills. Special alcholic beverages that server as permanent passive bonuses. Several Idols to choose from that increase the games difficulty and replayability. Several trials to overcome to help master each weapon and explore some of the characters background.This is bit a small list of things to expect during your time with Bastion, it is an amazingly well crafted game with great pacing and the story told is brilliantly narrated.

Posted: December 8, 2015
												Can't believe it took me this long to play this indie-gameSupergiant games made Bastion and Transistor, both similiar games from the way they are made.And Bastion is a truly good game, it's been ages since I enjoyed I game from start to finish.Not only are the visuals just bloody beautiful, the music fitting and gorgeos(maybe not as much as Transistor) but they nailed the gameplay.You get a ton of weapons, each with 5 of 10 possible upgrades, passive abillities, XP boost wich make the game way more difficult(for those who are truly good!) and the real time fighting is enjoyable, though I feel like I'd say something like "you will love the action ect."Story is just....great. Maybe a little short at some point, but the end choice way kinda tough.Last but not least: the narrator is always there and will make you AT MINIMUM smile every time, if not make you laugh in the heat of the battle or safe zones.Most people say Super Meat Boy, Braid, Binding of Isaac and Shovel Knight are the go to Indie games. I personally didn't enjoy them nearly enough to say that.But BastionBastion actually holds up Go love it

Posted: January 8, 2014
												The Facts~Game rating based on the ESRB: E (Everyone)Single-PlayerPlatforms: Microsoft Windows, Mac OS C, XBox 360, iOS, GoogleChrome, Linux, OnLive.Developer: Supergiant Games.Genre: Action Role-playing.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Plot-A great calamity has struck the world, and you, a lone kid has to find out why and how to fix it. You travel through the world searching for various items to restore the Bastion and to find what survivors that you can. Challenging foes and exploring what is left of the world until you finally find what you can to prevail.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Character Design-Playing through you will find that at the start, you didn't know anything about the characters, as few as there are. Through the gameplay you will find out more and more, who they were before the story began, and how it was changing them. It doesn't stop there either. Characters that have no place in the game yet were every bit as significant in the past come into play and you get to know a little about them and how they fit into the world that once was.Through the telling of the characters you will begin to feel a bit attached and even befriend the narrator through all the story.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Music & Artwork-This is where the game hits a home run in full, with music playing constantly in the background of gameplay it adds for a wonderful aura to the game, you are never left to feel alone and it is always a mellow tempo until a fight ensues, and then it picks up pace a tad. The sounds the emit from battle are flawless and the narration is one of my favorite details.The artwork is suburb, the coloration style and way the world literally builds itself before your very eyes is uncanny. It truly makes you feel more in tune with exploring. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gameplay-The controls are actually incredibly smooth for an indie game, I was very impressed. There is not much to be said other than that.Customization was a large feature in building the bastion and even in picking what weapons and special ability you wanted to have by your side in the heat of a battle.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conclusion-All in all, after getting this game, I learned never to judge a game before I play it again. This was a fantastic game and I am proud to own it. With all this said I proudly give Bastion a 10/10 with a 8.5/10 replay value.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Posted: December 13, 2014
												By this point Bastion doesn't need another positive review to solidify its standing as a must have game. With only the most bitter and caustic contrarians providing negative feedback, Bastion has an approval rate of 98%. That should speak highly of the game's value but one should always strive to understand what makes something good rather than blindly following popular opinion like one more lemming in the heard and indeed one should highlight the strengths of a thing rather than simply using popular opinion to define something's value. Rest assured however, in this case, Bastion is one cliff you'll be happy to jump off of with the rest of us.Bastion begins with a young child waking up to find his world falling apart, literally. An ominous and mysterious disaster, referred to as the Calamity, has caused the fabric of the world to collapse. Finding that only he and one other person survived, the boy must recollect the essence of the world and rebuild it. Narrated by one of the best voices on planet Earth, the boy's journey takes him through the ruins of a deep and interesting setting. Indeed Bastion has one of the most unique settings in video games, its indie origins contributing to the bravery of doing something new and interesting. The game is fairly short admittedly and to discuss too much of the plot would be to give it away but trust me in that it doesn't disappoint.Mechanically the game is remarkably solid. The purpose of collecting the shards and mcguffins is to upgrade both your base and character. There are a wide variety of weapons and enough distinction between bonuses and weapons to fit a wide variety of play styles. Being of a short length, the difficulty ramps up quickly and you must choose which upgrades are most valuable to your play style. Committing is the crux of the matter as your investments need to pay off to complete later levels.With story and mechanics blended this well, I never stopped feeling engaged. My drive maintained from start to finish which is tougher that one might think. Bastion walks a very fine line with not having any lulls in the action while at the same time not being overwhelming about it. My final analysis: Buy this game. It is great.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												If you like a good soundtrack, character customization, art style and narration then you’ll be loving every second Bastion has to offer. Bastion is an hack and slash action RPG that combines an amazing art style with an even more amazing soundtrack. The combat and movement feels smooth and unique. There is a variety of different weapons that allows you to fight enemies the way you want. One of the best things about Bastion is the freshness of the game, there aren't many games that are able to pull of an amazing art style, soundtrack, narration and combat all at the same time. The scenery never gets boring and is alway changing with lots of minor details. One of the ways they do this is by having the ground around you form as you walk near it. This can help keep people with low attention spans to keep engaged with the game.The constant improvements to your character and weapons gives a lot more replayability to the game. Leveling up allows you to quipt a buffing effect called a ‘spirit’ to your character. Weapons can be upgraded through finding materials when exploring the world. Idols make the game harder in certain aspects and are used to give the player more of a challenge, this helps give the game more replayability. The hack and slash gameplay is well made with lots of different ways to defeat your enemies. Upgrading weapons was very satisfying and fun to do. Bastion's soundtrack is very good and interesting and can be what keeps some people playing the game. The art style is also very unique and fitting with the soundtrack.One of the cons the game has (And it’s hard to come across cons in Bastion) is that the hack and slash gameplay at times can get a little repetitive. It’s also lacking in a filled in story, for example It doesn’t talk about what the world was like before the calamity, leaving the world feeling a bit empty at times. The story missions are basic and revolve around collecting one sort of object for almost every mission. But these don’t make Bastion a bad game, far from it. These are just little things I found when playing Bastion other people might and probably do disagree with.On average Bastion takes around six and a half hours to complete the story, while to complete the story and all extras takes around twenty hours. Bastion keeps the story nice and short for players looking for a short and sweet experience, while giving the game a good amount of completion hours for those wanting to spend a good extra fifteen or so hours on the game. With this and everything I’ve covered I’d recommend this game to anyone who loves good hack and slash mechanics, art and soundtrack in the games they play. I think It’s well worth the full price of fifteen dollars, but if you find it on sale it’s a must buy.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Bastion is labelled as an action role-playing game but feels more like “hack and slash” dungeon crawler due to its gameplay presentation and isometric view.  Bastion is set in a steampunk-like, post-apocalyptic fantasy world.  Quite a mouthful.A moving painting of watercolour, ink and chalk comes to mind when travelling the different areas.  The world builds as you walk along, summoned from the bottom of nothingness up right to your feet creating the area.  It fills it with which seems to be the destruction of a civilisation as well as nature moving back in or claiming it with either lushes green, invading and threatening red and sometimes the dull marshiness colour pallets.  It is definitely a visually crisp and stunning game.The story is simple enough to follow but details of the world may be lost due to how the story is presented.  You play as “The Kid”, pretty much a nameless character that not even the narrator cares enough to ask for his name.  You go through the City of Caelondia and other areas in the world collecting these crystal-like objects called Cores that will help rebuild the world.As you play, there is a dynamic voiceover by a narrator that presents the story as well as comments your unique actions in gameplay.  There is a sense of a tragic storybook feeling and the use of third-person narration (and sometimes second-person), there is disjoint between “you” as the player and “you” as “The Kid”.   You may be able to make choices in the game but “The Kid” is not you but you play as “The Kid”.  Bastion feels like a viewing of an active story instead of “playing” it.Bastion feels like a cross between a twin-stick shooter/action game and dungeon crawler.  Waves upon waves of enemies attack you and with a large variety of weapons and able to carry two of them and a unique skill, the combat is definitely fun and experimental.  Would you like to be up close and personal and later attack from a far?  You can equip a melee weapon of differing methods of damage, such as the hard hitting but slow “Cael Hammer” or the quick and range weapon able “War Machete”.  Range weapons also vary from the machine-like crossbow “Fang Repeater”, to cowboy-like “Dueling Pistols” or one-shot, long range accurate “Army Carbine”.Enemies have attack patterns that can be learned but I still found them challenging in terms of timing that hacking and slashing is the way to go most of the time.  One example of an enemy is the “Gasfella”.  Varies in a different sizes, where their damage differs as well as their pattern timing.  Then there are “Gasfellas” that spin attack, dash attack or destroys part of the world beneath your feet.Bastion has high replay value even with the new game plus feature, giving you the ability to experiment with all the weapons from the beginning as well as toggling “idols” that modifies enemies and increases the difficulty and challenge.I found the world immersive and wanting to learn more from it.  I hope it would be expanded with the mention of different tribes skilled with each weapon and how they contribute to the world.  I want to learn more about the different cultures, clashes and history of this world and replaying it again will allow me to be more attentive to it because I found the details easy to be missed because of the dynamic narration, either being distracted by fighting or roaming around.  However, its presentation of the story feels intentional.  Where the calamity has destroyed the past and is now told through the elder and experiences of the other characters becoming folk tales.Definitely a recommend.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Where do I start with this game....?I will probably be just another person telling you to buy this game but seriously you should and I will tell you why.Lets start with the graphics....the aesthetic of Bastion is beautiful, colorful, and full of taste. Not only will Bastion's graphics hold up over time for years to come, not only should the gamer enjoy the aesthetic but the team at Supergiant Games should be proud of them. Some Gamers may disagree about the games graphics but what they can't do is ignore the amount of time, expression, and hard work that has gone into creating the world of Bastion.Gameplay remains to be the very core of all video games made. In this department Bastion shines with wonderful action and tones of a role playing game. Bastion will control a lot like a normal game using the WASD for movement and left/right clicking for attacks. Bastion also introduces other key strokes for abilities that make the gameplay not only fun but strategic on how to tackle your enemy. By introducing new weapons with different play styles Bastion remains fresh in changing it up not too often but just enough to give the player a taste of what a new weapon is and how to use it.Story....Where do I begin with this.....I have been playing games for a little over 20 years and can't recall off the top of my head a game that tells an amazing story in 3rd person in such a successful way as Bastion. I was not expecting this going into the game nor did I find it odd that the main character never has a voice out loud. The decisions you make will reflect the outcome of the game with a story powerful and demanding of me to finish my first playthrough within 2 days of starting! The game length is just long enough to enjoy and sink yourself into the world but not long enough to exclude the casual gamer or multiple playthroughs. Overall I had a great time with Bastion, if anyone asks me for a recommendation or directly asks me about Bastion I would not hesitate to offer my opinion. Supergiant Games you really outdid yourself on Bastion and have gained a loyal fan to the games you create. I hope to see more from this developer in the future of gaming. If you want my review in audio/video form check out my YouTube channel for the Bastion Review.

Posted: January 8, 2012
												This is a great title (I would add 'great indie title' though the production values are quite high already!) that deserves to be in the top 10 of 2011. Innovative and quirky, it is a tad repetitive at first but soon becomes tremendously addictive and rewarding, which translates into pure gaming fun!

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Fantastic game! Probably one of the best downloadable games i've played. The game's artstyle is consistant and fantastic to look at all the way through. The game's story whilst fairly simple is very engaging and leads to some great moments, with some good characters and special mention to the brilliant narration that drives the story foward and sounds oh so good. The music also deserves a special mention, with some truely memorable tracks that have a consistant tone throughout, with vocals being used at the right moments to make reveals and gameplay segments more effective and truly memorable. Gameplay is very fun with a vast array of weapons to try out and find which best suits your play style. I couldn't recommend this game enough, so if you're in the need for a fun and gorgeous looking indie game, this is the one to choose.

Posted: November 2, 2011
												This game is beautiful, entertaining, and very smart.  I absolutely love the soundtrack (I'm glad I sprung for the soundtrack edition, now) and the narration is brilliant.  I'm a little bit put off by the sheer number of choices you have for weaponry, upgrades, buffs, and that sort of thing, but some people really like that so, yay, a game for you!  For me, I just love the lush colors and the creativity of the levels, totally worth buying and experiencing for yourself!

This is the second game I've played where for whatever reason I didn't finish on 1st, 2nd, or 3rd attempt, but the soundtrack kept pulling me back to it.  Yeah, the narration is great, but the pace of the game starts off kind of slow and the gameplay is fairly repetitive.  Overall, though, I'd still say it's worth picking up and playing :)

Posted: August 7, 2016
												This game has honestly impressed me with how much I enjoyed it. I bought this and Transistor back when they were on sale, no real expectations whatsoever but...wow I love this game.Pros- Great story/ lore- Art- Soundtrack- The Narrator- A bit of replayability with the different modes, the idols, and the survival/ dream sequencesCons- Personally coudln't find anything wrong with the game. Posted: February 23, 2015
												+ Tons of atmosphere+ Great soundtrack+ Great voice work by the narrator+ Art and visual aesthetic- Not a lot of depth in combat or other gameplay features.I've played through Bastion twice now and it's still very enjoyable.  One can't really say enough about the great job Supergiant did with building an interesting and slightly mysterious world, and crammed it with atmosphere and character.  Everything from the music, the narration, the detailed and beautiful art, and interesting plot all add up to a world you like seeing and experiencing.  The music and voicework really deserve their own mention, winning many awards (not that those mean much nowadays) for both the composer and Logan Cunningham for his portrayal as the Narrator.  The best way I can describe the soundtrack is like...acoustic frontier western folk music mixed with electronica.  It's great and can easily be listened to on it's own.  The games combat mechanics are the one thing that doesn't shine quite as bright as the rest.  What is there is very solid and controls just fine, but it tends to be a bit dull and not very challenging, especially in the first half or so of the game.  It gets a bit button mashy.  Later on, more enemies and more varied weapons and projectiles pick up the pace and things feel much better.  I just wish I had the same level of enjoyment in combat throughout all of it.  There are some city building and weapon upgrade features, which are welcome, but don't have much substance.  With more time and money in the budget, I'd love to see what Supergiant can do with a more fleshed out sequel.It's the atmosphere and aesthetics that take this good game and elevate it to something special.

Posted: August 22, 2011
												this game is bloody lovely. it's the game play of Diablo but with a much needed injection of soul.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This is a game that people often praise. But completely for the wrong reasons. They might mention some sort of narration, maybe emotional climaxes and beautiful artwork. They would be right to do so. But what really makes this game recommendable for me is the fact that it does not let all of that vision stop them from producing excellent core mechanics. Every upgrade, every button press, every Weapon, God and Liquor all work in synchronicity and in a controlled way that allow you to grasp the game and master the world, the way you choose.Sure, you might not like the narrator, but you will love the challenge. And it doesn't hurt that it's pretty, compelling and emotionally driven.

Posted: July 23, 2016
												Honestly, when I first looked at this game, I had my doubts. I have always thought that overhead action games don't work, but I'm glad I was wrong. No game is perfect, so let's look at the cons first: slow walking speed - while backtracking doesn't happen unless you miss something, it can still be a chore short game - I completed it in less than 10 hours, and I found myself wanting for more Now for the good stuff graphics - every are had breathtaking backgrounds and the stage itself was beautiful soundtrack - one of the best I've ever heard, and I've played Zelda gameplay - you unlock the ability to change the difficulty at will, and not just change a setting, but you specifically improve certain attributes on the enemies, and you increase your rewards based on which attributes you chose replayability - mulitiple endings, new game plus mode preventing you from restarting from scratch, different playstyles, and a scored mode make for excellent replayablity level design - the world being created at the kid's feet is a very nice touch that leads to a lot of explorationIn conclusion, this was one of the most delightful games I have ever played. I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes fun. Well worth the money. 9.9/10

Posted: March 8, 2013
												The bright, beautiful, and vibrant visuals of Bastion along with the outstanding narrative set this game up to be a 12 hour masterpiece. Even though the story isn't as complex as some other games, it is stil well written and thought provoking. The soundtrack? I'd pay money for it, definitely.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												A brilliant story to get lost in.The vaguely Zen-like and mysterious atmosphere will keep you spellbound until the end - I was transported back to the days of being a kid playing Super Mario 3 and The Legend of Zelda on the NES way back when - not from a gameplay perspective, but in the sense that my imagination was utterly captured from start to finish. Through the game's music, its gradual explanatory narrative and the colorful, dream-scape art direction used in creating the enviroments and everything in them - this pervading sense of sadness and loss creeps in on your psyche and leaves a lasting impression.Then it does one better:Many games have allowed me to exist in a post cataclysmic world - few, if any, have made me care about understanding why and how the world ended. Levels assemble themselves from nothingness as you walk through them, and the narrative stitches places, people and events of old together into a grand tapestry. It takes time to begin to make sense. Your actions, while pre-determined in most cases, feel as if they have real weight and truly affect the future of everyone involved with your character.You play as 'The Kid'- an apt bit of vaguness that, through the fact that the protagonist utters nary a word out loud throughout the entire ordeal and all of his decisions made in game are in the player's hands, make the game a very personal experience. At no point did I feel like I was simply along for the ride. Without trying to give too much away, in Bastion you will eventually have to make your mind up and act on a very philosophically 'grey' course of action. There is none of the clear cut 'Hero or Villain of the Wastelands' duality going on here - both outcomes are potentially horrifying when thought about.The game is beautiful in a classical sense. It's isometric, with detailed backdrops all having a 'hand-crafted' feel - every level looks like it would be right at home painted on a canvas and hung above someone's fireplace. The music deserves an honorable mention as well. While it ticks all the right boxes, being wonderfully produced and ranging from up-beat and inspiring to melancholy and nostalgic, it is, through and through, just wonderful to listen to and completely suited to what you see on-screen. From experience, many devs do not seem to have a terribly hard time tying a soundtrack and visual elements together into something that 'works'. Sometimes, though, a title comes along and you just know that without that specific soundtrack that seems to reflect the involved themes so intrinsically, the game itself would have only been half the experience. Off the top of my head, Soul Reaver and the first Unreal are good examples of this.At the most basic level, it controls similarly to an ARPG akin to Diablo and Torchlight, but it stands completely apart from titles like these in its style and execution. Nox would be a closer comparison - less focus on stats and combat and more on the experience of existing in another world (I miss you, Westwood). You gain access to a few, upgradeable weapons, but at no point does that seem to be the focus. They are each fun and unique- no endless slew of samey implements with rainbow themed tiers of quality. Sorry grinders. Story and experience are what is important here. Personally speaking, I feel the greatest value of Bastion is in what your mind takes away from it. If you have any capacity for empathy, I can almost guarantee that you will dwell on everything that happened well after the credits have rolled.Highly, HIGHLY recommended if you enjoy your gaming to be more than the endless rinse and repeat of 'clicky clicky, blood and different colored items'.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												This game is excellent. The art is beautiful and plentiful. Scenery is great and the designs of each individual part of the game are very well-done and visually very pleasing.The music is stunning. Not only is it some of the better music I've heard in a game, but some of the music is emotionally gripping as well, especially in specific parts of the game.This is helped along by the game's great story. The main criticisms launched against its story is that it focuses too much on setting and less on the interactions of characters, which i can agree with as a legitimate complaint, to an extent. However, in the face of the game's overarching plot and all, I think the complaint can be overlooked.The gameplay is spot-on. For the length of the game, the variety in combat is excellent. I'm running out of space in the recommendation but know the game is great in every aspect, the gameplay being no exception.

Posted: September 25, 2013
												The kid types on his keyboard about a game. "Bastion", I think it was called. The kid went on about how it was a great game. He really seemed to be into it. He looks at me, and I nod in approval to let him continue talking while he types what's intresting about the '"active narrating" doo-hickey. He says how "cool" it is to hear  a person say what you're doing in a game and actively comments; and that it immerses the player into the world. I don't understand a word of it, but I continue nodding.He then starts recounting about the times he played the game, about the "Calamity". He talks about waking up, floating in the sky in the middle of nowhere. Then something about a hammer. He starts listing all the types of weapons you get as you play, a machete. Rifle, Mortar, Shotgun, Pistol, Revolver, a Bow and Arrow. Even a flamethrower. He then lists all the monsters. Gasbags, Slimes, Crows, something about a Queen. All pretty interesting, but to a different man.+Kid talks about the "active narrating" again, saying how good it is+Then he says the controls are easy to learn,+"People with different playstyles will love it", he says+From what I've heard from the kid, the game's story is the best he's ever doneWatchin' his smile fade to a frown, he starts to complain-"Too easy", says the kid. Well if you wanted it harder, all you gotta do is♥♥♥♥♥♥off a god, I say-He goes on to say that althought it's a great story, it's mighty predictable. Hmmph.-Kid becomes a lunatic, shouting something about Birds and Spikeweeds. Don't care much for that language he uses with it.He pretends to be judge now, as he coughs and stacks a pile of cards, with the numbers 1 to 10 on 'em. Wait for it...He holds up a 9, good golly. That's gotta make some'uns day.

												I paid the price of a standard movie theater ticket to play this game and after playing it would have gladly thrown AAA caliber money at this game to squeeze out a little  more story from this beautifly-crafted world.If your looking for a solid Strategy-RPG and a front-row seat to a great story I would gradly recomend this game.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												I discovered this thanks to my kids actually, not sure how, but it was the great artwork that got me hooked. It's an action adventure, you have to shoot at monsters and do lots of running about. But its a mercy kind of shooting. You are "the Kid" and the beautifull part of the game is the Artwork and Narration. Now "the kid" has to shoot dead all the ghosts and slip past the defences that the core has put in place following the great "Calamity". Calamity is mildly putting it - and mildly putting it is a thing this game artfully does all over the place. Loved it to bits. You get to create the story which will have one of 2 possible endings. I said before that the Narration was unique, and slows the game action just enough to appreciate the eye candy. For example when you do "die" the Narrator tells you off like a granny who chides you for getting caught stealing cookies and then slips you one more cookie anyway. And did I mention the sweet backing tracks by Darren Korb? 5/5

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Bastion is labelled as an action role-playing game but feels more like “hack and slash” dungeon crawler due to its gameplay presentation and isometric view.  Bastion is set in a steampunk-like, post-apocalyptic fantasy world.  Quite a mouthful.A moving painting of watercolour, ink and chalk comes to mind when travelling the different areas.  The world builds as you walk along, summoned from the bottom of nothingness up right to your feet creating the area.  It fills it with which seems to be the destruction of a civilisation as well as nature moving back in or claiming it with either lushes green, invading and threatening red and sometimes the dull marshiness colour pallets.  It is definitely a visually crisp and stunning game.The story is simple enough to follow but details of the world may be lost due to how the story is presented.  You play as “The Kid”, pretty much a nameless character that not even the narrator cares enough to ask for his name.  You go through the City of Caelondia and other areas in the world collecting these crystal-like objects called Cores that will help rebuild the world.As you play, there is a dynamic voiceover by a narrator that presents the story as well as comments your unique actions in gameplay.  There is a sense of a tragic storybook feeling and the use of third-person narration (and sometimes second-person), there is disjoint between “you” as the player and “you” as “The Kid”.   You may be able to make choices in the game but “The Kid” is not you but you play as “The Kid”.  Bastion feels like a viewing of an active story instead of “playing” it.Bastion feels like a cross between a twin-stick shooter/action game and dungeon crawler.  Waves upon waves of enemies attack you and with a large variety of weapons and able to carry two of them and a unique skill, the combat is definitely fun and experimental.  Would you like to be up close and personal and later attack from a far?  You can equip a melee weapon of differing methods of damage, such as the hard hitting but slow “Cael Hammer” or the quick and range weapon able “War Machete”.  Range weapons also vary from the machine-like crossbow “Fang Repeater”, to cowboy-like “Dueling Pistols” or one-shot, long range accurate “Army Carbine”.Enemies have attack patterns that can be learned but I still found them challenging in terms of timing that hacking and slashing is the way to go most of the time.  One example of an enemy is the “Gasfella”.  Varies in a different sizes, where their damage differs as well as their pattern timing.  Then there are “Gasfellas” that spin attack, dash attack or destroys part of the world beneath your feet.Bastion has high replay value even with the new game plus feature, giving you the ability to experiment with all the weapons from the beginning as well as toggling “idols” that modifies enemies and increases the difficulty and challenge.I found the world immersive and wanting to learn more from it.  I hope it would be expanded with the mention of different tribes skilled with each weapon and how they contribute to the world.  I want to learn more about the different cultures, clashes and history of this world and replaying it again will allow me to be more attentive to it because I found the details easy to be missed because of the dynamic narration, either being distracted by fighting or roaming around.  However, its presentation of the story feels intentional.  Where the calamity has destroyed the past and is now told through the elder and experiences of the other characters becoming folk tales.Definitely a recommend.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Bastion is absolutely incredible.While the gameplay is pretty solid, the REAL meat behind it is the fantastic soundtrack, sweet artstyle, amazing story, and plenty of other compliments.And if the game isn't challenging enough for you, feel free to modify the difficulty in ways YOU find satisfactory, using the shrines. Make enemies take more damage, dish out more, reflect damage, try to blow you up when they die, and a few others.Seriously, i can't put it into words how good this game is. I am unworthy. Just pick it up. Trust me.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Bastion should be counted among those few games that not only meet, buy even exceed all the promises we get in their early description. Being one of the most beautiful and climatic games of 2011 this action RPG shines brightly even now, still as fresh and original as during its release.The game itself is not so complicated. You take up role of a Kid, waking up, all alone, surrounded by beautiful yet crumbling world falling apart into thousand pieces. What You need to do is get to the Bastion – safe heaven set up to shelter those who’d survive any crisis threatening Your homeland – city of Caelondia.

												The artwork, music, and story for this game are fantastic. The graphics and character designs are so creative and interesting, and every little bush and rock has detail. The whole atmosphere of this game lends itself to the story.As far as gameplay, however, I don't like how needlessly difficult the weapons challenges are. Posted: July 23, 2016
												Honestly, when I first looked at this game, I had my doubts. I have always thought that overhead action games don't work, but I'm glad I was wrong. No game is perfect, so let's look at the cons first: slow walking speed - while backtracking doesn't happen unless you miss something, it can still be a chore short game - I completed it in less than 10 hours, and I found myself wanting for more Now for the good stuff graphics - every are had breathtaking backgrounds and the stage itself was beautiful soundtrack - one of the best I've ever heard, and I've played Zelda gameplay - you unlock the ability to change the difficulty at will, and not just change a setting, but you specifically improve certain attributes on the enemies, and you increase your rewards based on which attributes you chose replayability - mulitiple endings, new game plus mode preventing you from restarting from scratch, different playstyles, and a scored mode make for excellent replayablity level design - the world being created at the kid's feet is a very nice touch that leads to a lot of explorationIn conclusion, this was one of the most delightful games I have ever played. I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes fun. Well worth the money. 9.9/10

Posted: November 19, 2015
												After 16.116 reviews, there's nothing else to say about this game right? Wrong.Everybody feels this game differently, that's one of its assets, but some things just never change. There are some mechanics that are not explained in the game at all and I for one would have liked to know 'em before I started playing. Hence this little reviewlike walkthrough of mine came to be:First, I'd like to say you won't regret buying this game. But you already knew that, didn't you?After all, Bastion is a really fun game, Aciton RPG oriented, with a somewhat limited combat system that wil♥♥♥♥♥♥you off from time to time but don't worry. You'll get it eventually!Where was I? Oh, right...Instead of talking about the strong suits of the game, I'd like to talk about it's flaws. 'Cause yes. It's got them.Above all, I'd say there are two ways to play Bastion. Casual or Completionist.If you're heading for casual, congratulations! This game's made for you. Most levels don't last more than ten minutes and there's a specific game mode meant for you called "painless mode".However, if you intend to get everything in this game I must warn you. It won't be easy...Know this. You're gonna have to beat the game at least twice.Enjoy your fisrt playthrough, learn the paths, try out different weapons, smash Scumbags, feel the music and try to understad what the hell's going on. Don't worry yourself about challenges and leave the Idols for later. Just enjoy!Eventually, you'll reach the grand finale and will need to face a story changing decission. To get all the achievements you need to play both scenarios, so just pick whatever you feel like and enjoy the show. Both decissions will allow you to keep playing so don't worry yourself unnecesarily. Alas, the game feels like the best options are: 1st) Left - Left.2nd) Right - Right.One down, one to go. Once you complete the stoy for the first time, you'll unlock "New Game +" mode and "Score Attack" mode. You should know that the latter counts as a New Game + for the "Calamity Kid" achievement, so there's no real need to play the NG+ mode. The second playthrough's where you'll have to give your best. Start off with no less than five Idols to get the higuest amount of money and experience possible, finish the remaining challenges and enjoy your new traits. Another special move will be unlocked in the Armory (you don't need to own Portal to get it) and the History books in the Bastion will now lead you to a brand new "Who Knows Where" battle arena.Don't push it. Battle arenas can be "easily" beaten with your mortar and pike fully upgraded. But it will take some time to complete the arenas. Strategy is key, choose the right tonics to aid you and take advantage of your surroundings.In addition, since you should already be playing in "Score Attack" mode, you can get the "Hard bargain" achievement as well. It is not an easy achevement to get, but a valid method to obtain it has already been discovered. Advance in the story until you unlock the Pipe, then equip "Black Rye" and "Whale Ale" choose a long and short range weapon in the armory, equip the "Gel Cannister" as your special move and renounce "Acobi", "Roathus" and "Olak" at the Temple leaving the remaining Idols active. All you have to do now is enter the Kid's Dream and try to keep the chain with your turrets. Have fun!!After a while, you should get all the remaining achievements. Thus concluding the completionist path. Congratulations, you did it!!!Now, regardless of the path you've chosen to enjoy this game, the experience is definitely worth it, but for he completionist gamers it feels like it is a bit harder than it should be unlike what happens in Transistor for example, the next game you should be cheking on! (^_^)

Posted: December 26, 2014
												*whistles a catchy tune from Bastion*It could be any one of the beautiful songs from the soundtrack. ONE of them will stick in your head when you play this. If you're unlucky, more than one song will stick AND YOU WILL LOVE EVERY MINUTE OF IT....and if you thought the music was catchy, the gameplay and graphics will leave you wanting more. And if you play for the stories... well, you're going to love it. The combat can be adjusted so anybody can play it happily.You want to play for the story? The No-Sweat mode will take the combat right down to the minimum. (My choice!)You feel the urge to go a-la- Dark Souls? Normal mode with all shrines invoked will cause your character to die every few minutes unless you're a pro. (Don't say I didn't warn you!)The graphics are cute, but never overly so. And no matter how cute the enemies, you WILL know they're enemies. No worries about bits of the background suddenly turning out to be a deadly boss without due warning. Only gripe in the whole game - one or two bits of scenery looked safe to walk on, even though they weren't.tl;dr - BUY THIS, YOU WILL PROBABLY LOVE THIS FOR SOME REASON. STORY, GRAPHICS, SOUNDTRACK, GAMEPLAY, OR THE WHOLE THING. YOU WILL LOVE IT FOR SOMETHING.

Posted: September 22, 2013
There's a short pro/con list at the end of this review, if you don't feel like reading this whole bunch of text.ReviewBastion is one of those games you just have to fall in love with 'cause it's incredibly intriguing from the very beginning.The story takes place in the fictional city of Caelondia and its surroundings, now fractured because of a catastrophe called the Calamity. The Calamity broke the world apart and turned nearly all its inhabitants to ash. Now, the pieces of this world float in the sky, and the Kid (the protagonist of the game) awakens on one of these pieces. He sets out to reach the Bastion, a place said to be safe in times of trouble.One of the many things I love about Bastion is how you build the world around you by exploring it. Your path forms in front of you as you fight your way through enemies and investigate the area. This, as well as the use of vivid colors, make the world feel very lively, despite the destruction the Calamity has brought upon Caelondia.Also, the soundtrack is amazing. Seriously, buy it, it's gold.Bastion is labeled as an action role-playing game, but I would specify that and call it a hack-and-slay game because of its focus on combat and variety of weapons (you're welcome to disagree with that point, but I think genres to be quite squishy anyway; Bastion just feels more like a hack-and-slay game to me). There we have another thing I love about this game: you can choose from plenty of weapons and combine them any way you want.There are 11 unique items, either melee or ranged weapons, and you can carry two at once. By default, you equip one melee and one ranged weapon, but you can replace them anytime at the Armory. You want to carry two melee weapons, for example your trusty Cael Hammer AND the War Machete? No problem. Two ranged weapons, let's say, the Scrap Musket in combination with the Breaker's Bow? Why not?The third equipment slot is reserved for Secret Skills you find, win, or buy later in the game.There are many more possibilities to customize your character, for example Spirits providing passive bonuses; let's just say, you can choose equipment from a REALLY great range of thingies.My favorite thing about Bastion, though, is the narrative style. The Kid himself is silent throughout the whole game, but there is a narrator whose voice accompanies the protagonist, providing the player with background information and reacting to what he or she chooses to do.The voice is so incredibly great; really calm but rough at the same time. It feels like it belongs to an older, experienced man who grew a little tired of all the stuff happening around him after years of turmoil - and I think that is perfect. You get the feeling that you're hanging out in a pub, and you meet an aged man who tells you stories about his life as a young adventurer. This may be the greatest thing about Bastion - that you feel like you get to know the narrator, like he personally speaks to you and no one else.All in all, I think Bastion might be one of the most beautiful games set in a post-apocalyptic world I've ever played. The art style and soundtrack go so well with the atmosphere, and the narrative style is breathtaking. The gameplay is really fun and allows for a lot of customization. I already recommend it to anyone who's into video games, and I don't think you would regret playing it.Short list for everyone who's too lazy to read this:• multiple endings• playtime (first run, didn't finish 100 % of the game) approx. 11 hoursPros:+ beautiful graphics+ amazing soundtrack+ 11 unique weapons (melee as well as ranged weapons), all upgradeable+ high customizability (e.g. weapons, Spirits, etc.)+ extraordinary narrative style+ stunning voice acting+ collectibles and side quests/challenges (e.g. mementos, proving grounds for each weapon, vigils)+ great control over difficulty level (you can activate up to 10 Idols, each making enemies stronger in some way and rewarding you with more XP and fragments in return; great system in my opinion)Cons:- New Game+ Mode doesn't offer anything too special

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Extremely good game. And at the risk of sounding overly pretentious, it's maybe more than game, and it's instead a rather unique experience. If you ever need an example to answer the question of "can video games be art?" I feel this game would easily make the list.  The gameplay itself is fun, fairly mobile but still feels like it has some impact if you use melee weapons. There's a decent mix of enemies but you will be seeing them fairly often. The game sort of does this thing where you progress through a group of monsters for a few levels, then never see them again as you move on to the next set of monsters. Then some of the older monsters may randomly show up again. There's a fair bunch of weapons to pick from, but honestly many function in a similar manner, and due to the upgrade system it's not entirely feasible to constantly swap weapons since at least on your first playthrough it's difficult to upgrade all of them to the same level so naturally some weapons will be stronger than others. I ran through most of the game with the same weapon combination (Machete and Musket). The difficulty of the game can vary wildly from a walk in the park to being rather grueling depending on the weapons you choose and the Idols you invoke. I really love the Idols system actually, it's a rather awesome way to implement difficulty as it lets the player choose HOW the game gets harder and pile on as many challenges as they want.. or not. Personally I do feel that it's necessary to invoke a couple idols otherwise the game is just too easy, by the end of the game I was running with 5 idols on all the time, and this presented a fun challenge for me that wasn't too frustrating. (You can activate up to 10 of them at a time, going with any combination of your choosing, all 10 of them, or none of them. Though I think the last 3 or so are available only on new game plus after you beat your first run through). But the gameplay isn't really what makes this game stand out. It's the art, and of course, the narrator. The story has it's moments, for sure, but I would say it's similar to the gameplay: pretty good, but not really the outstanding feature of the game. The art style and the narrator on the other hand, are both quite beautiful and unique. The music is absolutely beautiful at times, pretty good the rest of the time.The overall package is, again, a unique and awesome experience. I recommend this game without any shadow of a doubt. PS: There are some variations on the endings, I would recommend checking it out playing it yourself. I looked up an alternative on Youtube and kinda ruined it for myself. After you complete an ending you can hit the continue option in the main menu and replay the final mission, making different choices. So do yourself a favor and just go through it again, it'll be a lot more special than if you just watch a video. :PPPS: I really do believe this game deserves every bit of praise it has gotten. That said, I do believe the best parts of this game are the artistic qualities, which naturally can be very subjective. If you are unsure you will enjoy the game as much as its "hype" would suggest, I would recommend trying out the demo before purchasing, and/or getting it on sale.

												     I really don't like games where the player or character that you play is tiny and right in the middle of the screen.. But this was - a masterpiece.      The story was breath-taking and really special in its own way. It had many twists and turns that made it even better. Its also pretty fun that you can invoke and idols to make the game more difficult instead of just choosing a mode to play in. All the characters have really unique personalities and histories - which ultimately makes the game even more exciting! Really loved how there are so many weapons and upgrades that you can get to make the Kid better at fighting! (Best weapons I've ever had to use in games)     Bastion's art was fanstastic. The style was very original and cute. The environment was carefully planned as each 'world' or location had character and history. Personally I loved Tazal Terminals and the Bastion :)     Its OST was one of the most unique OSTs I've ever (Soz, can't beat BioShock Infinite's OST - Elizabeth) heard. I really enjoyed how the voice actors got to sing a single song as a theme for each of their characters.Overall, it was one of the best games I played for 2014~! :D:D:D 10/10 because everything XDDPs. PORTAL REFERENCES!!! XDDD

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Just know, I have out time into this offline, on my X-Box, and PS3! I have alot more experiance then the time it says I have put in.     Bastion is a game of story. The game is a almost 3D-isometric-ish hack and slash. There are alot of wepons, abilities, sidequests, options, and so much more. The controls are sweet too!   You wake up as a character called "The Kid"( as most characters are only referred to as The ????). After making your way throught the first level you learn a little about the story through The Narrarator. The world is expanded upon much more the there are a even a few tear jerking moments in there You can find several relics to give to people you will start pooling to the hub to learn more about the lore of The KId and the mythical world of his.   There are many wepons and abilities, as I have said. All wepons are found throughout the story along with some abilites. No wepons are missable. Stores in the hub(we'll get to that) can sell permant equipments(Spirits) and upgrades for your kicking wepons(assuming you have obtained the ingredients).   The game is traversed through the hub, the Bastion. The skyways(teleporters) can shoot you to missions or extra stages. Most of the time the game gives you several levels to choose from, although you have to complete them all, just in any order.  In the earlier mentioned extra stages you can play challenges based on one wepon. You can win money, a upgrade ingredient and a specilzed ability for that wepon.  Completing the story will allow you to upgrade the hub with stores. These range from the shrine for sidequests, to the Lost and Found to buy missed ingrediants and relics(even though you can backtrack), along with some uniqe spirits and abilites.  The story (and action) is complimented by  the awesome soundtrack, it can pump you up, get you down,♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, anything!If you didn't get the message, buy this game!

												A proper review should start with a beginning. Ain't so simple with this one. Now there's a game whose whole devs team but a bunch of friends. The screenshots look rather uninspiring but buying the game for this price, the benefits of it are worth it.    Masterfully made locations, music that can make feel chills down your spine in one moment, the other one you can't stop dancing to the groovy rhythms. And the story, along with the best narrator ever , make a combo that even casting 8 Ultimas in a row pales in comparison to this masterpiece of a game. Hell, there is so much to talk about, but i'll mention one more thing:remember to take breaka during playing. Even if it is too hard to stop playing after 5 hours straight, do it. Sharpen your senses for probably the most emotion inducing game ever made.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												And again I have feels and tears and everything, because this thing is beautiful. I love the story, the graphics, the music (which brings such an atmosphere every time, especially, the vocal songs, which are placed perfectly. They create kind of a cinematic effect and bring this feeling of wistfullness and longing and homesickness, which is beautiful), and the character are amazing. Every character has their own story, which are always about overcoming all the obstacles and trying to find their place in life no matter what. And it’s just so detailed and beautifully done (I love how after you finished the game for the first time you have a “New Game Plus” option in which the narrator is always having a deja vu, which shows us how the story repeats itself and no matter how many times we rewinded the time and prevented “the Calamity”, it happens anyway)It’s definitely one of my favourite games of all times.

Posted: July 29, 2013
												Damn, I loved it. Had my eyes on it since it came out but unfortunately missed it's bundle, finally got the chance to play it and it was awesome, 6 hours and counting because of the replay value, the only sad part is that it took me so long to get my paws on it. The narration is perfect, during the course of the story you just fall in love with it and in silent times you even miss that voice, I was always waiting to hear the next part of his tale and don't even get me started on the Soundtrack, because it's absolutely fantastic and fits so well with the narration.. I mean, damn it, it's one of the best story driven games I've ever played, every single element just adds up to give you an incredible experience. So yes, I can not recommend this enough. Play it.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												It's a short game, probably less than 10 hours, and you can finish the story in a night.  This is not a lot of time to sell the player on a character, much less a whole bespoke world. Fortunately, the game is engaging and unrelated enough to the story that you can enjoy it, while its obscure story flows around you. By its end, though, you will find yourself invested, and actually caring about this world you're living in.Because, here's the thing: This game is just so damn beautiful. Its music, its art, its story... creates a story-book atmosphere that -- I'm not kidding, here -- touches the soul. Yes, I think you should play this game.  The game, by the way, supports a mode that allows you to experience the world somewhat safely, which makes the game easy for anyone to experience and enjoy.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												One of my all time favourite games. I've played through it probably around 6 or so times (mostly on xbox 360 back in the day which explains my low play time here) and would recommend it to anybody and everybody. Seriously, you can't go wrong.Pros:-  Soundtrack.  One of the best, if not my favourite, soundtracks to any game I have played to date. I often come back to listen to it while playing other games, studying or just relaxing (I may or may not be listening to it as I type this).-  Story.  A very unique and amazing storytelling experience. Something you will remember for quite a time after playing.  Choosing to save Zulf and having "Setting Sail, Coming Home" playing in the background. The feels get me every time. -  Gameplay.  A variety of weapons, weapon uprgades, skills, tonics (perks) allowing you to play in many different ways.-  Graphics.  Pleasing artstyle that suits the game well.Neutral:-  Length.  Only a 5-6 hour story. Though it doesn't feel dragged out or too short. It's a good length for what it is, though it may leave some wanting more.-  Replayability.  There's pretty much only the main story and a few side challenges you can do. You can't go back to story areas after completing them. Though, there is a new game+ and score attack mode to keep things a little fresh after completing the game once and idols to modify the difficulty of the game if you want a challenge.Cons:- What is it bad for?  Absolutely nothing!  SAY IT AGAIN.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												My most played game on steam. Something about the story line keeps bringing me back as well as the ability to wield different weapons. Sounds kind of generic, I know but it's different for me since I can't play FPS or most 3D games so this definitely is one of the best in my opinion.I loved the soundtrack, loved the art, so I hope you will too!

Posted: August 27, 2016
												A unique aspect to Bastion, and possibly the reason of it's positive reception, is how the game engages the player: instead of having dialogue boxes, you have a voice narrating your every move in the game, whether you're countering enemy attacks, switching your weapons, and even falling off cliffs or dying. This gives a persistent idea that even the simplest action you take in the game is meaningful, an idea that I guarantee you'll enjoy.A small catch is that Bastion doesn't offer much aside from the first playthrough, but that's still a 10-20 hours of a good game, mind you, and this game definitely worth the price.

Posted: September 2, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E9 The Bastion 

			Views: 85		

			A wonderfully crafted game, although it is a bit on the short side, one playthrough lasting between 6-8; The Bastion is a strikingly beauitful world with a unique setting, characters and story.		

Bastion: A top down arcade action RPG, none would have expected such a simple and inexpensive game to do so well for itself. The game is crafted wonderfully, nothing feels wasted and is a great value for what you will end up getting when purchasing the game. Bastion is visually impressive with a lovely art style, the tone set is of hope and determination and overall is just pretty darn fun. The perspective may not lend itself to some gamers, but ultimately you would be ashamed to pass up such a great experience. You are sure to remember Bastion for years to come and the only legitimate complaint is how short the game is at the end of the day. But asking for more of something usually means its good enough to earn that right? For $15.00 USD on Steam, I can't think of many different ways to tell you to own this game already. Support SuperGiant Games and let's hope for a big, bright future for this company. Good job to all who worked on Bastion.-Double Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

Posted: November 2, 2011
												Incredible...The combat is smooth and challenging, even for a player skilled in action RPGs.The story is intricate and interesting. The world post-calamity is brightly-colored, mysterious and fanciful, yet an inexplicable gravity weighs upon the characters; they each exude a sense of loss which is emotionally profound without being melodramatic. Even the silent protagonist's personality, via the narrator's observations, comes through very well. The narration is well written, and not overdone so it does not come off as reduntant. Rather, it provides a powerful window into the world.The soundtrack is very fitting, and never gets repetitive.Absolutely brilliant and fun. Highly recommended.

Posted: July 26, 2012
												I got this cuz it was on sale. Not gonna lie, this sort of thing isn't usually my thing. I was only slightly interested based on the previews, and I didn't want to pay full price. Posted: December 27, 2011
												Boy started up this game.  He knew it was good, but he didn't know what he was getting into.  Inside was a colorful world, a world that hid its sinister side.  Hid it so well the kid was sucked in.  Then the world beat that boy to a pulp.  And he loved every moment of it.  Eventually the kid found a shotgun, and the tables were turned.  He tore his path through the world, reached out and ripped the beating heart of fun from the world.  And I'll be darned if it wasn't the most fun that little boy did ever see.
